    Each person to be engaging in the sales practices in Section 6-6 shall be issued an identification badge by the City, which shall be worn at all times that the person is engaging in said sales practices. Failure to display such badge shall be prima facie evidence that the person has not been issued a license to engage in the sales practices specified herein. 
(Ord. 98-725) 
Sec. 6-11. - Enforcement. 
    Persons engaging in the sales practices in Section 6-6 and not having a license are committing criminal acts, as well as engaging in a public nuisance. Law enforcement officers contacting such persons may arrest them and/or issue them a municipal summons and complaint and/or seize merchandise, vehicles, order books, samples or other objects used in the facilitation of these acts as evidence, and abatement of the public nuisance. 
(Ord. 98-725) 
Sec. 6-12. - Application and license fee. 
    The City Clerk shall set the application fee herein to cover costs of the City, which shall be not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) per application. The City Clerk shall set the annual license fee herein which shall be not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) per person for each license, or for each person operating under each license. 
(Prior code 5-255-7; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 98-725) 
Sec. 6-13. - Renewal of license. 
    Licenses may be renewed for subsequent one-year periods based upon continuing sales practices in the public interests and qualifications of each person operating under the license. 
(Prior code 5-255-8; Ord. 98-725) 
Sec. 6-14. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Sections 6-6 through 6-13 shall not apply to food products which are grown or raised by the person so having them for sale and which are products of the State. 
(b)  No sales license is required for local nonprofit organizations such as the Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, school districts, organized sports program, VFW, Moose Lodge and church groups. 
(c)  No license is required for persons having established routes or customers, where contact is initiated by invitation or longstanding practice. 
(Ord. 98-725) 
Sec. 6-15. - Entertainment license required. 
    No person, either as owner, licensee, manager, officer or agent or in any other capacity, shall give, conduct, produce, present or offer, for gain or profit or for admission to which the public is required to pay a fee, any of the following entertainments, exhibitions or performances, to wit: All entertainments of theatrical, dramatic or operatic character, lectures, readings, menageries, exhibitions of moving pictures, circuses, merry-go-rounds, musical entertainments, concerts, dances, bazaars and all other exhibitions, performances, entertainments or amusement devices not specifically mentioned herein, at any place in the City, other than within a duly licensed theater, opera house, hall or other enclosure or place, without a license issued for that purpose, which said license shall be issued and procured in the manner hereinafter set out in this Article. 
(Ord. 2015-995 §5) 
Sec. 6-16. - Application for license. 
    Any person desiring to produce, present, conduct or offer for gain or profit any of the entertainments, exhibitions or performances mentioned in Section 6-15, at any place within the City, other than within a duly licensed place as hereinafter provided for, shall make application to the City Clerk in writing, setting out the full name of the applicant, a description of the kind of entertainment he or she intends to offer and the place at which it is desired to produce, present, conduct or offer such entertainment, exhibition or performance. Upon the payment by such applicant to the City Clerk of the license fee hereinafter specified, the City Clerk shall issue to such applicant a license authorizing him or her to conduct, produce, present or offer the kind of entertainment specified in such license, at the place designated and for the period of time specified in such license. 
(Ord. 2015-995 §5) 
Sec. 6-17. - Special event license fee. 
    In any case where any person shall desire to produce, present, conduct or offer any entertainment specified in Section 6-15 at any place other than a duly licensed place, such as is hereinafter provided for, the amount of the license fee to be charged for the same shall be as follows: not less than two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) or more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each and every performance. 
(Ord. 2015-995 §5) 
Sec. 6-18. - Entertainment license; application fee. 
    Any person, the owner or lessee of any theater, opera house, auditorium, hall or other place at or in which it is desired or intended to produce, offer, present or carry on any of the entertainments mentioned in Section 6-15, who desires to secure a license for such theater, opera house, auditorium, hall or other place, shall be granted a license upon the following conditions: the applicant shall make an application in writing to the City Clerk setting out his or her full name and residence if an individual, and if a corporation, the full name and residence of its principal officers, and also a description of the place for which a license is desired. Thereupon the City Clerk shall issue or cause to be issued a license to such applicant upon payment to the City of Fort Lupton of the fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per year. 
(Ord. 2015-995 §5) 
Sec. 6-19. - Suspension of fee. 
    The Mayor shall have the right in his or her discretion to suspend the payment of the license fee required by Section 6-18 of this Article when the object of any entertainment mentioned in Section 6-15 hereof is to raise money for religious, charitable or other like commendable purposes. 
(Ord. 2015-995 §5) 
Sec. 6-20. - Retail mobile food vending. 
    The following mobile retail food vending vehicles are recognized by this section: 
a.  Mobile retail food establishment; retail food establishment that reports to and operates from a commissary and is readily moveable, is a motorized wheeled vehicle or a towed wheeled vehicle designed and equipped to serve food. 
b.  Pushcart: a non-self-propelled vehicle limited to serving commissary prepared or prepackaged food a non-potentially hazardous food unless the equipment tis commercially designed and approved to handle food preparation and service. 
    Mobile retail food establishments and pushcarts shall be permitted in all non-residential zoning districts subject to the following: 
a.  Mobile retail food establishments and pushcarts shall be located at least five hundred (500) feet from any restaurant. 
b.  In all other non-residential zoning district mobile retail food establishments and pushcarts shall be located at two hundred fifty (250) feet from any restaurant. 
c.  Operation in parks with permanent concession facilities is prohibited when park concessions are in operations. 
d.  Exceptions. Zoning and separation requirements do not apply during special events. 
    The criteria for operation is as follows: 
a.  A mobile retail food vending permit is required. 
b.  Permits must be kept with the mobile retail food establishment or pushcart and presented to City officials upon request. 
c.  Operations are responsible for maintaining trash receptacles and shall maintain all areas used for food vending in a safe, clean and attractive condition. 
d.  Mobile retail food establishments and pushcarts must be removed from any site at the end of each business day (unless otherwise approved). 
e.  Operator must obey all parking and traffic laws. 
f.  Mobile retail food establishments and pushcarts must not obstruct pedestrian or bicycle access/passage and must not obstruct parking lot circulation or impede traffic flow. 
g.  Structures, canopies, tables or chairs are not permitted to be set up around the mobile retail food establishment or pushcart. 
h.  Operators must dispose of all waste in accordance with Weld County Health Department regulations. 
    Upon receiving a mobile retail food vending application, the City Clerk shall collect the application fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and complete background checks as described in Section 6-9, Investigations. 
    Such permit shall be issued for one (1) year. 
(Ord. 2015-994 §18) 
Secs. 6-21-6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II - Alcoholic Beverages 

Sec. 6-31. - Definitions. 
    As used in this Article, the following words or phrases shall have the following meanings, respectively: 
    Malt liquors shall include beer and shall be construed to mean any beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops or any other combination thereof in water containing more than 3.2% alcohol by weight. 
    Operator shall be construed to mean a person licensed by law to sell 3.2% beer, malt, vinous or spirituous liquors, other than medicinal liquors, for beverage purposes at retail, and who is engaged at any time during the calendar year in such operation within the City. 
    Spirituous liquors shall be construed to mean any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation and mixed with water and other substances in solution, and includes among other things: brandy, rum, whiskey, gin and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol and which is fit for use for beverage purposes. Any liquid or solid containing beer or wine in combination with any other liquor, except as above provided, shall not be construed to be malt or vinous liquors but shall be construed to be spirituous liquors. 
    3.2% beer shall be construed to mean fermented malt beverage, containing not more than 3.2% alcohol by weight, as defined by Section 12-46-103(1.5), C.R.S. 
    Vinous liquors shall include wines and fortified wines not exceeding twenty-one percent (21%) alcohol by volume and shall be construed to mean alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural sugar contents of fruits or other agricultural produce containing sugar. 
(Prior code 5-356-1; Ord. 645 §1, 1993) 
Sec. 6-32. - Classification. 
    The business of selling at retail any 3.2% beer, malt, vinous or spirituous liquors for beverage purposes within the City is hereby defined and separately classified as such occupation for the purposes of this Article, as follows: 
(1)  Class "A" Operators: All operators who are licensed to sell malt, vinous and spirituous liquors for consumption on the premises, either at hotels or restaurant. 
(2)  Class "B" Operators: All operators licensed as retail liquor stores to sell in sealed containers malt, vinous or spirituous liquors for consumption off premises. 
(3)  Class "D" Operators: All operators licensed to sell only 3.2% beer and who sell the same solely in the original package or container for consumption off the premises. 
(4)  Class "E" Operators: All operators licensed to sell malt, vinous or spirituous liquors by the drink only to members of clubs and their guests within the premises of said club. 
(Prior code 5-356-2; Ord. 645 §1, 1993) 
Sec. 6-33. - Fee correlation to cost. 
    The City hereby finds, determines and declares that, considering the nature of the business of selling, at retail, 3.2% beer, malt, vinous and spirituous liquors for beverage purposes and the relation of such business to the municipal welfare, as well as the relation thereof to the expenditures required by the City and that a proper, just and equitable distribution of cost burdens within the City and all other matters proper to be considered in relation thereto, the classification of said business as a separate occupation is reasonable, proper, uniform and nondiscriminatory and the amount of the fee hereby imposed by this Article is reasonable, proper, uniform and nondiscriminatory and necessary for a just and proper distribution of cost burdens of the City. 
(Prior code 5-356-3; Ord. 938 §1, 2011) 
Sec. 6-34. - Fee rates. 
    Fee rates shall be set and amended by resolution of the City Council. 
(Prior code 5-356-4; Ord. 558 §1, 1987; Ord. 938 §1, 2011) 
Sec. 6-35. - When fee due. 
(a)  Such fee shall be due and payable to the City Clerk on January 1st of each year and shall be delinquent as of February 1st of the same year. Prepayment of said fee may be made in the month of December preceding the due date. 
(b)  Upon receipt of such fee, it shall be the duty of the City Clerk to execute and deliver to the operator paying the fee the occupational license showing the name of the licensed operator, fee, the date of payment, the annual period for which said license is paid and the place at which said operator conducts business. 
(c)  The operator shall, at all times during said year, keep said license posted in a conspicuous place in his or her place of business. 
(d)  No refund shall be made to any person who discontinues said business during the year. All fees provided for in this Article shall be due as provided above, except that all fees provided for in this Subsection shall be due and payable upon the beginning of business and shall be delinquent ten (l0) days thereafter. 
(Prior code 5-356-5; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 938 §1, 2011) 
Sec. 6-36. - Delinquency not to affect license. 
    No delinquency in payment of the fee herein provided for shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of any such operator by any licensing authority pursuant to state statutes and in performance of any duties imposed upon the City Council as a licensing authority by said statutes; the City Council shall exclude from consideration any delinquency in payment of the fee herein provided for. 
(Prior code 5-356-6; Ord. 938 §1, 2011) 
Sec. 6-37. - Civil action to collect. 
    The City shall have the right to recover all sums due by the terms of this Article, by referral to a collection agency and/or judgment and execution thereon in a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction; such remedy shall be cumulative with all other remedies provided herein for the enforcement of this Article. 
(Prior code 5-356-7; Ord. 938 §1, 2011) 
Sec. 6-38. - Violation. 
    Failure to comply with the terms of this Article by payment of fees, securing and posting a receipt therefor and to otherwise comply with the terms of this Article shall constitute an offense and violation of this Article. Every person violating this Article shall be fined not more than two thousand six hundred fifty dollars ($2,650.00) for each offense and delinquency, and each calendar month shall constitute a separate offense, but no conviction for such violation shall work a revocation of the license of the defendant issued under state law. 
(Prior code 5-356-8; Ord. 938 §1, 2011; Ord. 2015-994 §66) 
Sec. 6-39. - Administrative approvals for liquor licenses. 
(1)  The liquor and beer licensing authority for the City of Fort Lupton shall be the City Council ("Council"). As such, the City Council shall be known as the "Liquor Licensing Authority" or, in this Chapter, as the "Authority." 
(2)  The City Clerk shall assist the authority by receiving all applications; coordinating with other City departments when relevant; scheduling required public hearings; and exercising the Clerk's discretion in forwarding applications for renewals, transfer of ownership, change of manager of a licensee, temporary permits and special event permits. 
(3)  As set forth below, the Mayor and City Clerk are hereby vested with authority to administratively review and approve applications for liquor license renewals; transfer of ownership including corporate and trade name changes, and reports of changes for corporations, limited liability companies and partnerships, change of manager of a licensee, temporary permits and special events permits. 
a.  Renewals. The Mayor and City Clerk is authorized to administratively review and approve an application for the renewal of any previously approved liquor license where, after reasonable investigation by the City Clerk and consultation by the City Clerk with other appropriate administrative and law enforcement personnel, all of the following circumstances are found to exist: 
i.  The applicant has timely and properly submitted a complete license renewal application and tendered all required fees in accordance with this Chapter and the provisions of Title 12 C.R.S; 
ii.  The applicant's license is in good standing with the City and the State, and no violation of law has occurred during the previous year; 
iii.  To the knowledge of the City Clerk, there is no pending or proposed criminal or legal investigation or charges against the applicant or the licensed premises; and 
iv.  There is no other information known by the City Clerk that would cause the City Clerk, in her reasonable belief, to believe that some violation of applicable law has occurred or that the license should not be renewed. 
b.  Transfer of ownership, corporate and trade name changes, and reports of changes for corporations, limited liability companies and partnerships. The Mayor and City Clerk is authorized to administratively review and approve an application for the transfer of ownership, corporate and trade name changes, and reports of changes for corporations, limited liability companies and partnerships, of any previously approved liquor license where, after reasonable investigation by the City Clerk and consultation by the City Clerk with other appropriate administrative and law enforcement personnel, all of the following circumstances are found to exist: 
i.  The applicant has timely and properly submitted a complete application for transfer of ownership, corporate and trade name changes, and reports of changes for corporations, limited liability companies and partnerships and tendered all required fees in accordance with this Chapter and the provisions of Title 12 C.R.S; and 
ii.  The applicant satisfies the eligibility criteria set forth in Section 12-47-307, C.R.S. 
c.  Change of manager of a licensee. The Mayor and City Clerk is authorized to administratively review and approve an application for the change of manager for a licensed establishment where, after reasonable investigation by the City Clerk and consultation by the City Clerk with other appropriate administrative and law enforcement personnel, all of the following circumstances are found to exist: 
i.  The applicant has timely and properly submitted a complete application for change of manager and tendered all required fees in accordance with this Chapter and the provisions of Title 12 C.R.S. and the new manager has presented himself to the Police Department for fingerprinting and background investigation; and 
ii.  There is no information known by the City Clerk that could support denial of the application for change in manager under applicable law. 
d.  Temporary permits. The Mayor and City Clerk is authorized to administratively review and approve an application for a temporary permit where, after reasonable investigation by the City Clerk and consultation by the City Clerk with other appropriate administrative and law enforcement personnel, all of the following circumstances are found to exist: 
i.  The applicant has timely and properly submitted a complete application for a temporary permit and tendered all required fees in accordance with this Chapter and the provisions of Section 12-47-303, C.R.S.; and 
ii.  There is pending an application for the transfer of the liquor license corresponding to the application for a temporary permit; and 
iii.  The premises subject to the proposed temporary permit is currently subject to a valid liquor license; and 
iv.  There is no information known by the City Clerk that could support denial of the application for change in ownership under applicable law. 
e.  Special events permits. The Mayor and City Clerk is authorized to process and issue special events permits pursuant to Article 48 of Title 12, C.R.S., provided that there are no parties filing a written objection to said permit. 
(4)  Notwithstanding any authority delegated to the Mayor and City Clerk for the administrative approval of applications under this Section, the Mayor and City Clerk may, at their discretion, refer any licensing decision authorized to them under this Section to the Authority if, in the Mayor and City Clerk's opinion, the matter should be presented to the Authority. In the event the Mayor or City Clerk cannot or will not approve a transfer or renewal of a license, or the approval of a change in manager of a licensee, or the approval of a temporary permit or a special events permit, then the Mayor and City Clerk shall refer the application to the Authority for consideration in accordance with applicable law. Written notice of the time and place of such consideration shall be mailed to the applicant by regular mail at least ten (10) days in advance thereof and shall contain such facts or reasons relied upon by the Mayor and City Clerk in declining to issue the license or permit or approval. Notice of the proceedings shall also be timely published and posted on the subject premises in accordance with the requirements set forth in Section 12-47-311, C.R.S., and timely provided to any person who may have filed a protest against the issuance of the license with the City Clerk. Additionally, any license or permit applicant, or any party in interest (as defined in Section 12-47-311, C.R.S.), who is dissatisfied with a decision of the Mayor and City Clerk under this Section may appeal same to the Authority by filing a written protest with the City Clerk not more than ten (10) days after the date of the decision appealed from. The City Clerk shall promptly set the appeal for hearing before the Authority in accordance with the notice and hearing procedures described above. 
(5)  The Mayor and City Clerk shall not approve an application for the renewal, transfer or permit of a license where the Police Department has timely submitted written objections to the City Clerk concerning such action. Whenever such an objection is received, the City Clerk shall set the application for hearing before the Authority in accordance with the procedures set forth in Subsection (4) above. 
(6)  The City Clerk shall regularly report to the Authority in a timely manner all licensing actions taken by the City Clerk under the provisions of this Section. 
(Ord. 2015-988 §1) 
Sec. 6-40. - Gambling prohibited. 
    No owner, operator or other person who shall have control over the operation of any pool or billiard hall or any premises licensed to sell or dispense fermented malt beverages containing not more than 3.2% alcohol or malt, vinous or spirituous liquors, shall permit any card table or gambling devices to be kept or used upon said premises; nor shall said owner, operator or other person in control of the operation of a pool or billiard hall or premises licensed to sell or dispense fermented malt beverages containing not more than 3.2% alcohol or malt, vinous or spirituous liquors, permit any person to play any game of cards upon any of the aforementioned premises within the City. 
(Prior code 5-236-1) 
Sec. 6-41. - Standards adopted for optional premises licenses. 
    The following standards for the issuance of optional premises licenses or for optional premises for a hotel and restaurant license are hereby adopted pursuant to the provisions of Section 12-47-310, C.R.S.: 
(1)  Standards. These standards adopted herein shall be considered in addition to all other standards applicable to the issuance of licenses under the Colorado Liquor Code for optional premises licenses or for optional premises for a hotel and restaurant license. These two (2) types of licenses for optional premises will collectively be referred to as "optional premises" in these standards unless otherwise provided. 
(2)  Eligible facilities. 
a.  Optional premises licenses may only be approved when premises are located on or are a part of an outdoor sports and recreational facility as defined by state statute (now Section 12-47-103(22)(ii)(b), C.R.S.). The types of outdoor sports and recreational facilities which may be considered for an optional premises license include a golf course clubhouse and adjacent golf course, driving range and facilities, even if divided by one (1) or more public streets. 
b.  There are no restrictions on the minimum or maximum size of the outdoor sports and recreational facilities which may be eligible for the approval of an optional premises license. 
c.  The restrictions in Section 12-47-313, C.R.S., relating to distances from schools or colleges are eliminated for this class of license (optional premises). 
(3)  Number of optional premises. The local liquor licensing authority, in its discretion, may restrict the number of optional premises which any one (1) licensee may have. 
(4)  Submittal requirements. When submitting a request for the approval of an optional premises license, an applicant shall also submit the following: 
a.  All local and state license fees; 
b.  A map or other drawing illustrating the outdoor sports or recreational facility boundaries, and the approximate location of each optional premises requested; 
c.  A description of the provisions which have been made for storing vinous and spirituous liquors in a secured area on or off the optional premises for the future use of the optional premises; and 
d.  An applicant for a hotel and restaurant license who desires to sell or serve alcoholic beverages on optional premises shall file with the optional premises permit application a list of the optional premises locations. Such application and list shall be filed with the state and local licensing authorities upon initial application, and each license year thereafter. Approval of the areas must be obtained from the state licensing authority and the local licensing authority. The decision of each authority shall be discretionary. 
(Ord. 99-735, Part 1) 
Sec. 6-42. - Advance notification. 
    Pursuant to Section 12-47-310(3), C.R.S., no alcoholic beverages may be served on optional premises without the licensee having provided written notice to the state and local liquor licensing authorities forty-eight (48) hours prior to serving alcoholic beverages on the optional premises. The notice shall contain the specific days and hours during which the optional premises is to be used. In this regard, there is no limitation on the number of days which a licensee may specify in each notice. The notice may specify three hundred sixty-five (365) days a year and the maximum number of hours allowed for service of beverages as otherwise provided in the Colorado Liquor Code. 
(Ord. 99-735, Part 1) 
Sec. 6-43. - Notice and hearing procedures. 
    An application for an optional premises license, or an application for optional premises for a new hotel and restaurant license, shall be scheduled in the same manner as any other new liquor license application, and the posting, publication and hearing requirements of the Colorado Liquor Code shall apply. An application for an optional premises for an existing hotel and restaurant license shall be scheduled for public hearing not less than ten (10) days from the date of the application, and public notice shall be given by posting and publishing in accordance with the Colorado Liquor Code. At the public hearing on any optional premises application, the Board will consider the criteria of the Colorado Liquor Code and the within standards, and make findings as to whether the applicant has complied with said criteria and these standards. 
(Ord. 99-735, Part 1) 
Sec. 6-44. - Tastings. 
    Tasting permit required. 
(1)  Tastings on the licensed premises of a retail liquor store licensee or of the liquor-licensed drugstore licensee are authorized to be conducted within the City in accordance with Section 12-47-301(10), C.R.S. and are subject to the provisions of this Chapter. 
(2)  The local liquor licensing authority is authorized to issue tasting permits in accordance with the requirements of this Chapter. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct tastings within the City without having first received a tasting permit issued in accordance with this Section. 
(4)  Retail liquor store licensees and liquor-licensed drugstore licensees desiring to conduct tastings shall submit a tasting permit application to the City Clerk accompanied by the fee stated in Section 6-47 below. 
(5)  Submittal requirements. Annually, the licensee shall submit a tasting permit application provided by the City Clerk's office, complete and including the following: 
a.  Licensee information, including but not limited to name, address, contact information and state liquor license number; 
b.  Verification that the licensee and employees who will be conducting the tastings have completed a seller/server training program that meets the standards established by the Liquor Enforcement Division in the Department of Revenue and are qualified to conduct an alcohol beverage tasting. 
(6)  Advance notification. No malt, vinous or spirituous liquors and fermented malt beverages can be provided as samples during a tasting until the licensee has provided written notice to the City Clerk's office at least five (5) working days prior to conducting said tasting. 
(7)  Renewal of tasting permits shall be concurrent with the renewal of licenses for retail liquor stores and liquor-licensed drugstores. A licensee's initial tasting permit shall expire on the same date as the date the licensee's retail liquor store or liquor-licensed drugstore license expires. The initial tasting permit application fee shall not be prorated if the permit expires in less than a year. 
(8)  Tasting permits shall be conspicuously and prominently posted by the licensee on the licensed premises at all times during business hours. 
(9)  Tasting permits shall only be issued to a retail liquor store or a liquor-licensed drugstore licensee whose license is valid, not subject to a current or pending enforcement action by the City or the State and in full force and effect. 
(Ord. 939, 2011) 
Sec. 6-45. - Limitation on tastings. 
    Tastings within the City shall be subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  Tastings shall be conducted only by a person who has completed a server training program that meets the standards established by the Liquor Enforcement Division of the Department of Revenue, and who is either a retail liquor store licensee or a liquor-licensed drugstore licensee or an employee of a licensee, and only on a licensees' licensed premises. 
(2)  The alcohol used in tastings shall be purchased through a licensed wholesaler, licensed brew pub or winery, licensed pursuant to Section 12-47-403, C.R.S., at a cost that is not less than the laid-in cost for such alcohol. 
(3)  The size of an individual sample shall not exceed one (1) ounce for malt or vinous liquor or one-half (1/2) ounce of spirituous liquor. 
(4)  The licensee shall not serve more than four (4) individual samples to a patron during a tasting. 
(5)  Tastings shall not exceed a total of five (5) hours in duration per day, which need not be consecutive. 
(6)  Tastings shall be conducted only during the operating hours in which the licensee, on whose premises the tastings occur, is permitted to sell alcoholic beverages, and in no case earlier than 11:00 a.m. or later than 7:00 p.m. 
(7)  The licensee shall prohibit patrons from leaving the licensed premises with an unconsumed sample; 
(8)  The licensee shall promptly remove all open and unconsumed beverage samples from licensed premises or shall destroy the samples immediately following the completion of the tastings. 
(9)  The licensee shall not serve a person who is under twenty-one (21) years of age or who is visibly intoxicated. 
(10)  The tasting samples used in the tastings shall be served in clear, open containers and shall be provided to a patron free of charge. 
(11)  Tastings may occur on no more than four (4) of the six (6) days from a Monday to the following Saturday, not to exceed twenty-five (25) per year. 
(12)  No manufacturer of spirituous or vinous liquor shall induce a licensee through free goods or financial or in-kind assistance to favor the manufacturer's products being sampled at an alcohol tasting, and the licensee shall bear the financial and all other responsibility for an alcohol tasting. 
(13)  The licensee shall maintain on the licensed premises a log of all tastings, on provided forms, to be submitted to the City Clerk each year with the tasting permit renewal application; and during all business hours, the log shall be subject to inspection by City and state officials authorized to enforce the Colorado Liquor Code and/or this Code upon request. 
(Ord. 939, 2011) 
Sec. 6-46. - Violations. 
(a)  A violation of law or regulation by a retail liquor store or a liquor-licensed drugstore licensee, whether by the licensee's employees, agents or otherwise, shall be the responsibility of the retail liquor store or liquor-licensed drugstore licensee who is conducting the alcohol tasting. 
(b)  Retail liquor stores and liquor-licensed drugstore licensees conducting tastings, shall be subject to the same revocation, suspension and enforcement provisions as otherwise apply to those licenses. The local liquor licensing authority shall conduct a hearing with regard to any violation of this Article in accordance with this Chapter of this Code, its rules and regulations and Section 12-47-601, C.R.S. 
(Ord. 939, 2011) 
Sec. 6-47. - Tasting permit fees. 
    Permit fees shall be set by resolution of the local liquor licensing authority. 
(Ord. 939, 2011) 
Secs. 6-48-6-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III - Amusement Devices 

Sec. 6-71. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this Article, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed hereafter: 
    Amusement center means a place of business where any person maintains mechanical amusement devices as a sole business or in conjunction with some other business. 
    Amusement device means any device which upon insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, or payment of a consideration, may be used by the public for use as a game, entertainment, amusement or a test of skill, either mental or physical, whether or not registering a score. It shall include such devices as marble machines, pinball machines, skill ball, mechanical grab machines, pool tables and all games, operations or transactions similar thereto under whatever they may be indicated. 
    Applicant means any person requesting a license pursuant to this Article. 
    Jukebox means any music-vending machine, contrivance or device which upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, or payment of any price, operates or may be operated for the emission of songs, music or similar amusement. 
(Prior code 5-489-1; Ord. 645 §1, 1993) 
Sec. 6-72. - License required. 
    Any person displaying for public patronage or keeping for operation any jukebox or mechanical amusement device shall be required to obtain a license from the City, upon payment of a license fee prior to conducting business of an amusement center. Application for such license shall be made upon a form to be supplied by the City Clerk for that purpose. Schools are specifically exempted from the licensing requirements of this Article. 
(Prior code 5-489-2) 
Sec. 6-73. - License application. 
    The application for such license shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The applicant's name and address, age and date and place of birth; 
(2)  Any convictions of the applicant; 
(3)  The name and address of the amusement center; 
(4)  Description of machines to be covered by the license; and 
(5)  Number of machines to be covered by the license. 
(Prior code 5-489-3) 
Sec. 6-74. - License application approval. 
    The Chief of Police shall investigate the location wherein it is proposed to operate such machines, ascertain if the applicant is a person of good moral character and either approve or disapprove the application. In addition, the applicant must present to the City Clerk approval of all wiring and connections to the machines as determined by the State Electrical Inspector. 
(Prior code 5-489-4) 
Sec. 6-75. - License fees. 
    Each applicant, before being granted a license, shall pay an annual license fee for the privilege of operating or maintaining for the operation each jukebox or mechanical amusement device of ten dollars ($10.00) per machine on the premises for any portion of the period for which the license is issued pursuant to this Article. 
(Prior code 5-489-5) 
Sec. 6-76. - Term of license. 
    All licenses granted pursuant to this Article shall be for a term of one (1) year. Said term shall commence on January 1st of each year and terminate December 31st of the same year. Applications for a license occurring at any other time during the year shall be treated the same as if they were made for one (1) calendar year and shall terminate on the same date as all other licenses issued pursuant hereto. No proration shall be permitted. 
(Prior code 5-489-6) 
Sec. 6-77. - License display. 
    The license or licenses provided for in this Article shall be posted permanently and conspicuously at the location of the machine, in the premises wherein the device is to be operated or maintained to be operated. 
(Prior code 5-489-7) 
Sec. 6-78. - License renewal. 
    The renewal of any of the licenses granted pursuant to this Article may be had by payment of the licensing fee along with a statement that the information listed on the original license application is still true and correct to the applicant's knowledge, or a statement listing those items of information required for a license application which have changed in the year since the license was granted or last renewed. 
(Prior code 5-489-8) 
Sec. 6-79. - Age of manager. 
    No person under the age of nineteen (19) years shall serve in the capacity of manager of any establishment licensed pursuant to the provisions of this Article. 
(Prior code 5-489-9) 
Sec. 6-80. - Gambling prohibited. 
    Nothing in this Article shall be construed to permit any unlawful gambling or wagering within the City. 
(Prior code 5-489-10) 
Sec. 6-81. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
    The City Clerk may suspend or revoke any license granted pursuant to this Article upon a finding of any of the following factors: 
(1)  That any of the devices maintained upon the premises are being used for gambling purposes; 
(2)  That repeated disturbances of public peace have been occurring within the licensed establishment or upon any parking areas, sidewalks, access areas or grounds immediately adjacent to the licensed premises involving patrons, employees or the holder of the license of the establishment; 
(3)  That the holder of the license or any employees thereof are illegally offering for sale or illegally allowing to be consumed upon any parking areas, sidewalks, walkways, access ways or grounds immediately adjacent to the licensed premises narcotics, dangerous drugs or liquor; 
(4)  That the holder of the license or any employees thereof are violating ordinances of the City; or 
(5)  That the conduct of the business constitutes a breach of the peace or is a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(Prior code 5-489-11) 
Secs. 6-82-6-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV - Building Contractors 

Sec. 6-111. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this Article, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed hereafter: 
    Building contractor means a person or company in the business of remodeling, fix-up type construction, roofing, siding, concrete, excavations or other work requiring permits under the International Building Code or regulated under other related codes and ordinances as adopted by the City. 
    Electrical contractor means a person or company involved in electrical work that requires permits under the National Electrical Code or is regulated under other related codes and ordinances as adopted by the City. 
    General building contractor means a person or company in the business of new construction. This contractor is one who builds one (1) or more dwelling units or commercial or similar business-type buildings per year. 
    Heating, ventilating and air conditioning contractor means a person or company involved in installing furnaces, heaters, ventilating equipment, air conditioning or other work requiring permits under the International Mechanical Code or regulated under other related codes and ordinances as adopted by the City. 
    Plumbing contractor means a person or company involved in plumbing that requires permits under the International Plumbing Code or is regulated under other related codes and ordinances as adopted by the City. 
(Ord. 2013-972) 
Sec. 6-112. - License fees. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity to perform any work described herein without first obtaining the required license. 
(b)  Fees shall be charged in the City on a calendar year and licenses shall be required as follows: 
(1)  General Building Contractor "G." Any general building contractor as defined in Section 6-111 above shall be required to hold a General Building Contractor "G" license. An individual who builds only one (1) single-family residential dwelling with the intent of personal occupancy shall be excluded from this licensing requirement. 
(2)  Building Contractor "B." Any building contractor as defined in Section 6-111 above shall be required to hold a Building Contractor "B" license. 
(3)  Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning Contractor "H." Any heating, ventilating and air conditioning contractor as defined in Section 6-111 above shall be required to hold a Heating, Ventilating and Air Conditioning Contractor "H" license. An individual who builds only one (1) single-family residential dwelling with the intent of personal occupancy or completes work as an owner/occupant of a single-family residential dwelling shall be excluded from this licensing requirement. 
(4)  Plumbing Contractor "P." Any plumbing contractor as defined in Section 6-111 above shall be required to hold a Plumbing Contractor "P" license. Prior to issuance of this license, the plumbing contractor shall be required to provide a copy of a current master plumber's license as issued by the State. An individual who builds only one (1) single-family residential dwelling with the intent of personal occupancy or completes work as an owner/occupant of a single-family residential dwelling shall be excluded from this licensing requirement. 
(5)  Electrical Contractor "E." Any electrical contractor as defined in Section 6-111 above shall be required to hold an Electrical Contractor "E" license. Prior to issuance of this license, the electrical contractor shall be required to provide a copy of a current master electrician's license as issued by the State. An individual who builds only one (1) single-family residential dwelling with the intent of personal occupancy or completes work as an owner/occupant of a single-family residential dwelling shall be excluded from this licensing requirement. 
(Ord. 2013-972) 
Sec. 6-113. - Insurance. 
    All contractors shall be required to submit a certificate of general liability insurance with coverage of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injury to or death of one (1) person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injury to or death of more than one (1) person in any single accident or event, and for not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage or destruction. All contractors shall be required to submit a certificate of workers' compensation insurance if employees are being compensated for labor as required by state law. 
(Prior code 5-550-3; Ord. 671, 1995) 
Sec. 6-114. - Fees for moving buildings. 
(a)  All buildings to be moved within the City limits shall be inspected by the Building Official prior to the move. Approval by the Building Official is required prior to any permit being issued for the relocation and rehabilitation of the building within the City limits. Any building approved by the Building Official will be required to meet the same standards as new construction. 
(b)  The following fees for moving of buildings shall be charged: 
(1)  A seventy-five-dollar inspection fee shall be payable for each building inspected for the purpose of moving the building to a location within the City limits, excluding mobile homes and modular homes. 
(2)  In the event the move originates outside the City, a mileage fee charge of thirty cents ($.30) per mile shall also be imposed. This fee shall be calculated based on an estimate of round trip distance to and from the location of the building to be moved. 
(3)  All fees included in this Section shall be payable prior to inspection of the building. 
(4)  These fees are in addition to normal building permit fees. 
(Prior code 5-550-4; Ord. 671, 1995) 
Sec. 6-115. - Fee changes. 
    Amendments of the fee structure set forth in this Article shall be done by resolution from time to time as the City Council may determine. 
(Prior code 5-550-5; Ord. 671, 1995) 
Secs. 6-116-6-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V - Massage Parlors 

Sec. 6-131. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this Article, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed hereafter: 
(1)  Apparatus means any appliance, piece of equipment or any other project used in the application of a massage; provided that apparatus shall not include furniture, towels, linen, oils or showers used in conjunction with the application of a massage. 
(2)  Apprentice means a person employed by a massage establishment and working under a licensed massage technician or massage therapist for the purpose of learning the method and practice of massage. 
(3)  External baths means but is not limited to water vapor, steam, oil, powder, sweat, electric, salt, alcohol rubs or any other kind or character of massage. 
(4)  Massage means pressure on, friction against, stroking, rubbing, kneading or other manipulation of the body by any means with or without apparatus, including but not limited to vibrators, infrared heat, sun lamps and external baths. 
(5)  Massage establishment means an establishment having a place of business where any person engages in, conducts or carries on, or permits to be engaged in, conducted or carried on, any business of the manipulation of the body by means of massage as herein defined. 
(6)  Massage technician or massage therapist means any person who administers to another person, for any form of consideration or hire, a massage, alcohol bath, electric or magnetic procedure, manipulation of the body or other similar procedure. 
(7)  Operator or massage establishment operator means any person owning or operating a massage establishment. In the event of a corporate owner, the operator shall mean the manager or the person in charge. 
(8)  Recognized school means any institution of learning which has for its purpose the teaching of theory, method, profession or work of massage, in which requires a resident course of not less than five hundred (500) hours for graduation. If a school meets state requirements, it shall be considered a recognized school for purposes of this Code. 
(Prior code 5-421-1; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 659 §1, 1994) 
Sec. 6-132. - Exceptions. 
    The following classes of persons and establishments are exempted from this Article: 
(1)  Physicians, osteopaths, physical therapists, podiatrists, chiropractors and massage therapists licensed in the State; 
(2)  Registered nurses and licensed practical nurses who are licensed in the State, performing such services in their usual nursing duties; 
(3)  Beauticians and barbers duly licensed under the laws of the State in the course of the practice of their usual and ordinary licensed vocation and profession, as defined by the laws of this State; 
(4)  Massage practices at the athletic department of any state accredited school, college, university or seminary, or in connection with the conduct of professional athletics; 
(5)  Hospitals, clinics, nursing and convalescent homes, and other similar institutions dedicated to medical and nursing practices, licensed under the laws of the State, where massage and baths may be given. Employees of the respective institutions shall be exempt from this Article while in the normal course of their employment with such institution; 
(6)  Massage practiced at a recognized school as defined in Section 6-131(8); and 
(7)  A facility which is operated for the purpose of massage therapy to be performed by a massage therapist is not a massage parlor or massage establishment and is therefore also exempt from the requirements of this Article. 
(Prior code 5-421-2; Ord. 659 §§2, 3, 1994) 
Sec. 6-133. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a massage establishment without first having obtained a license to do so as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to perform the services of a massage technician, therapist or apprentice without first having obtained a license to do so as hereinafter provided. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for an operator of a massage establishment to permit any person in his or her massage establishment to act as a massage technician, therapist or apprentice unless such person is duly licensed as provided in this Article. 
(d)  Each licensee shall reapply for a license annually by application, and such license shall issue without reexamination, provided that application for reissue is made prior to expiration of the outstanding license. The license shall be valid for a period of one (1) year from the date of issuance. Application for renewal of the license may be submitted along with the appropriate annual fee as hereinafter provided not less than forty-five (45) days prior to the date of expiration. 
(Prior code 5-421-3) 
Sec. 6-134. - Classification of license. 
(a)  Unlimited. This license permits the performance of massage activities by any means defined or permitted in this Article. 
(b)  Apprentice. 
(1)  This license permits the performance of massage upon any person only under the direct supervision and direction of a licensed massage technician or massage therapist who must be present in the establishment at all times while an apprentice is performing massage in any form. 
(2)  No apprentice license shall be issued to any person who has not completed a minimum of one hundred (100) hours in massage theory from a recognized school. 
(3)  The license issued under this Section shall be valid for a period not to exceed one (1) year, and no extension or reissue shall be granted unless satisfactory evidence shall be shown that the applicant has completed five hundred (500) hours of training from a recognized school or has completed the course of instruction from such school. Only one (1) extension or reissue shall be granted to any apprentice. 
(Prior code 5-421-4; Ord. 645 §1, 1993) 
Sec. 6-135. - License fees. 
(a)  Application fees for a license shall be as follows: 
(1)  Massage establishment: fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(2)  Massage technician or massage therapist: fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(3)  Apprentice: fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(b)  The annual licensing fees shall be as follows: 
(1)  Massage establishment: one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(2)  Massage technician or massage therapist: fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(3)  Apprentice: twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(c)  Such fees are for the purpose of defraying the cost of administration of this Article and shall not be refundable if for any reason a license is not issued. The application fee shall be submitted at the time the application is made, and if a license is issued, license fees are due and payable at that time. Fees shall not be prorated or refunded for any reason once they have been paid. 
(Prior code 5-421-5) 
Sec. 6-136. - Applications. 
(a)  Operator. The owner of a massage establishment seeking to obtain a license shall submit a written application to the City Clerk so that it may be determined that: 
(1)  The applicant is twenty-one (21) years of age or older. 
(2)  The applicant, including each member of the firm, partnership or association if the applicant is a firm, partnership or association, and including the actual manager of the business if the applicant is a corporation, is of good moral character. If the applicant is a corporation, the date and the state of incorporation, the name and address of the registered agent for the State, and names and addresses of officers and directors of said corporation shall be stated. 
(3)  The applicant, if he or she performs the duties of a massage technician or massage therapist, or manages or supervises the therapists, is a licensed massage therapist. 
(4)  The applicant, including each of the persons mentioned in Subsection (2) above, shall submit two (2) portrait photographs and shall be fingerprinted by the Police Department, where such parties are actively involved in the operation of the establishment. 
(5)  The applicant, including each of the persons mentioned in Subsection (2) above, has been examined by and has been issued a health certificate from a medical doctor stating that said applicant has, within thirty (30) days immediately prior to application, been examined and found to be free from any contagious or communicable diseases, where such parties are actively participating in the operation of the establishment. 
(6)  The applicant, including each of the persons mentioned in Subsection (2) above, has not been previously convicted of any violation involving moral turpitude or any offense against the decency of the community. 
(b)  Massage therapist or apprentice. Any person seeking to obtain a license as a massage technician, massage therapist or apprentice shall submit written application to the City Clerk containing but not limited to the following information: 
(1)  The full name and present address of the applicant, and all aliases by which the applicant is or may be known; 
(2)  The previous street and city addresses of the applicant for the two (2) years preceding the application; 
(3)  At least three (3) references from residents of the State stating that the applicant is of good moral character; 
(4)  Written proof that the applicant is twenty-one (21) years of age or older; 
(5)  The applicant's height, weight, color of eyes and hair; 
(6)  Two (2) portrait photographs at least two (2) inches by two (2) inches, one (1) of which must be attached to the application; 
(7)  Business, occupation or employment of the applicant for the three (3) years immediately preceding the date of application; 
(8)  The massage or similar business history of the applicant; whether such person in previously operating in this or any other city or state under license has had such license revoked or suspended, the reason therefor, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action, suspension or revocation; 
(9)  All convictions involving moral turpitude or any offense against the decency of the community for the five (5) years preceding the application; 
(10)  A certificate from a medical doctor stating that the applicant has, within thirty (30) days immediately prior to the application, been examined and found to be free of any contagious or communicable diseases; 
(11)  The applicant must furnish a diploma or certificate of graduation from a recognized school or other institution of learning wherein the method, profession and work of massage technician is taught; 
(12)  Such other identification and information necessary to discover the truth of the matters hereinbefore specified as required to be set forth in the application; 
(13)  The applicant shall be fingerprinted by the Police Department upon submission of the application; 
(14)  Classification of license desired, whether unlimited or apprentice. 
(Prior code 5-421-6) 
Sec. 6-137. - Investigation. 
    The City Clerk and the Chief of Police shall investigate the validity of the statements contained in each application for a license required by this Article. 
(Prior code 5-421-7) 
Sec. 6-138. - Disclosure. 
    An applicant for any license provided for herein shall completely disclose all information required by the application. Willful refusal to submit a true and accurate application shall be grounds for the City Clerk to refuse to accept such application or refuse to issue said license until such time as the application is accurately completed. Any applicant who willfully misrepresents himself or herself in any of the information given on the application to acquire such license may have the license revoked by action of the City Council. 
(Prior code 5-421-8) 
Sec. 6-139. - Display of license. 
    Every person to whom a massage establishment license shall have been granted under this Article shall display such license in a conspicuous place so that the same may be readily seen by persons entering the premises where the massage, bath or treatment is given. Every person to whom is granted a massage technician or apprentice license under this Article shall affix a name plate or similar means of identification conspicuously to the garment of the person so that the person's identity may be readily ascertainable. 
(Prior code 5-421-9) 
Sec. 6-140. - Facilities. 
    No massage establishment license shall be issued or renewed unless inspection by the County Health Department and City Building Inspector indicates that the establishment complies with the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  A readable sign, in compliance with all provisions of Chapter 16 of this Code, shall be posted at the main entrance identifying the business as a massage establishment. 
(2)  Minimum lighting shall be provided in accordance with the Uniform Building Code, and in addition, either direct or indirect lighting of not less than forty (40) foot-candles shall be provided in each room or enclosure where services are performed on patrons, and each minimum lighting shall be in use when services are being performed. 
(3)  Minimum ventilation shall be provided in accordance with the Uniform Building Code. 
(4)  Adequate equipment shall be provided for disinfecting and sterilizing instruments used in administering or practicing any of the subjects or methods of treatment. Such instruments shall be sterilized after each use. 
(5)  Hot and cold running water shall be provided at all times. 
(6)  Closed cabinets or other approved storage facilities shall be provided and used for the storage of clean linens. 
(7)  Adequate bathing, dressing, locker and toilet facilities shall be provided for patrons. A minimum of one (1) tub or shower, one (1) dressing room, one (1) toilet and one (1) washbasin, and facilities to provide a safe and secure place to keep valuables and personal items, shall be provided in every massage establishment; provided, however, that if male and female patrons are to be served simultaneously at said establishment, a separate massage room or rooms, separate dressing facilities and separate toilet facilities shall be provided for male and female patrons. 
(8)  All walls, ceilings, floors, pools, showers, bathtubs, steamrooms and all other physical facilities for the massage parlor must be in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. Wet and dry heat rooms, steam or vapor rooms or cabinets, shower compartments and toilet rooms shall be thoroughly cleaned each day the business is in operation. Bathtubs and massage tables shall be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected after each use. Clean and sanitary linens shall be provided for each patron of the massage establishment. The tables shall be provided with clean and sanitary linens, paper towels or sheets for each patron. 
(9)  A minimum of one (1) separate wash facility shall be provided in each massage establishment for the use of employees of such establishment, which basin shall provide soap or detergent and hot and cold running water at all times and shall be located within or as close as practical to the area devoted to the performing of massage services. In addition, there shall be provided at each washbasin sanitary towels or other approved facilities placed in permanently installed dispensers. 
(10)  The establishment shall be in compliance with all other applicable ordinances of the City. 
(Prior code 5-421-10; Ord. 645 §1, 1993) 
Sec. 6-141. - Employees. 
    The operator of a massage establishment shall keep and maintain up-to-date a register of all employees, including their addresses, dates of birth, sex, duties and other information as the City Council may require. Upon hiring or discharging any massage therapist, the operator shall immediately notify the City Clerk in writing and shall include in such notice the aforesaid personal data. 
(Prior code 5-421-11) 
Sec. 6-142. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  Any operator of any massage establishment or any massage technician or other employee of such massage establishment and the licensee or any person or patron in or upon the premises is hereby prohibited from: 
(1)  Engaging in prostitution, masturbation, deviate sexual intercourse, oral copulation or other act designed or intended to arouse or gratify the sexual desires of any other person; or 
(2)  Soliciting, directly or indirectly, any person to engage in prostitution, masturbation, deviate sexual intercourse, oral copulation or other acts designed or intended to arouse or gratify the sexual desires of any other person, whether such prostitution, oral copulation, deviate sexual intercourse, masturbation or other acts are intended to occur on or off the premises of the massage establishment; or 
(3)  Engaging in the display of his or her genitals or pubic areas. For purpose of this Subsection (3), the term display shall be defined to include the exposure of those parts of the body described hereinabove when they are less than opaquely covered. 
(b)  Any operator who knows or reasonably should know that any acts prohibited by this Section have occurred or are occurring in or upon the premises of his or her establishment shall be deemed guilty of committing such act and shall be held liable as a principal. 
(c)  No operator, massage technician or other person in the employ of the massage establishment shall violate any federal or state law or City ordinance or any provisions of this Article in or upon the premises of any massage establishment. Any operator who knows or reasonably should know that any violation of this Code or provisions of this Section is occurring or does occur in or upon the premises of said establishment, and does not immediately act to prevent the same and report the same to the proper authorities, shall be deemed guilty of committing such act and shall be held liable as a principal. 
(d)  Each operator of a massage establishment shall conduct his or her establishment in a decent, orderly and respectable manner, shall not serve or permit the consumption of spirituous, vinous or malt liquor or 3.2% beer on the premises, and shall not permit within or upon the premises the loitering of habitual drunkards or intoxicated persons, known prostitutes, lewd or indecent displays, profanity, rowdiness, undue noise or other disturbance or activity offensive to the sense of the average citizen or to the inhabitants of the neighborhood in which the establishment is located. 
(Prior code 5-421-12) 
Sec. 6-143. - Inspections. 
    The City shall request the County Health Department from time to time and at least twice each year to make an inspection of each massage establishment in the City to determine compliance with the provisions of this Article. Nothing herein shall preclude members of the Health Department, Fire Protection District or Police Department from making inspections of the premises at any reasonable time during the hours of operation. It shall be unlawful for any operator of a massage establishment to refuse to allow the aforementioned inspections. Inspections of the premises shall be limited to those areas not in actual use at the time of the inspection; provided however, this shall not preclude inspections of those areas when not in use. Nothing herein shall be construed to preclude a peace officer from inspecting any area where he or she has probable cause to believe that a violation of this Article or other provisions of this Code is being committed. 
(Prior code 5-421-13) 
Sec. 6-144. - Records to be kept. 
    Every operator of a massage establishment shall keep a record of all treatments rendered either on or off the premises and shall describe the address where the treatment was rendered, name and address of the patron, name and address of the technician rendering the treatment, and the date of such treatment. Said records shall be maintained for a period of one (1) year. 
(Prior code 5-421-14) 
Sec. 6-145. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator of any massage parlor to allow any massage activity or other acts prohibited by this Article either on or off the premises between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Prior code 5-421-15) 
Sec. 6-146. - Revocation and suspension. 
(a)  Any license issued pursuant to this Article shall be subject to revocation or suspension whenever the holder thereof shall violate any of the provisions of this Article or other applicable provisions of this Code relating to massage establishments. 
(b)  Upon commencement of revocation and suspension proceedings, the City Council shall set a time and place for the hearing of the matter. 
(c)  The City Clerk shall give the licensee notice of the time, place and nature of the hearing, the authority and jurisdiction under which it is to be held, and the violation asserted. Such notice shall be served personally or by mailing by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last address furnished to the City by the licensee, at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing. 
(d)  The City Council may preside over the hearing or, in the alternative, may appoint a hearing officer who may be a Councilmember, a municipal judge or other qualified person, or a special committee of the City Council to preside over such hearing. 
(e)  The hearing officer or the chairman of the special committee shall have the power to administer oaths and issue subpoenas. 
(f)  All evidence shall be recorded electronically. If the hearing is before a hearing officer, he or she shall prepare a summary of the evidence and shall make recommendations in writing to the City Council within ten (10) days after the close of the hearing. A copy of his or her summary and recommendation shall be forwarded to the licensee at the same time. At its next regularly scheduled meeting following receipt of the summary and recommendations, the City Council shall consider the same. In its discretion, the City Council may reject the hearing officer's recommendations, may refer the matter back to him or her for further proceedings, may adopt the recommendations with or without modification, or may order a new hearing, either before the entire City Council or a committee or member thereof. 
(g)  The Mayor may summarily suspend any license hereafter issued to any person pursuant to the Article whenever the holder thereof shall violate any of the provisions of this Article under which such license was issued or whenever, in the judgment of the Mayor, the public welfare requires the same. Any person may appeal to the City Council from the Mayor's suspension, and it may terminate such suspension. Appeal from the Mayor's suspension of the license shall be to the City Council under the procedures hereinbefore stated. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on or engage in the business as herein described in this Article while any suspension or revocation is in effect. 
(Prior code 5-421-16) 
Sec. 6-147. - Sale or transfer. 
(a)  No license shall be transferable from one (1) license holder to another. A new application shall be made by any individual desiring to own or operate a presently licensed massage establishment. A fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be payable for each such application involving the sale or transfer of any interest in a presently licensed massage establishment. Such fee shall not be refundable in the event the license shall not issue. The new license shall be valid only for the unexpired portion of the originally licensed establishment. The provisions for application and fees for licensing such establishments shall thereafter apply in the same manner as though such license has not been transferred. 
(b)  Any sale or any conveyance of any interest in an existing massage establishment or any application for an extension or expansion of the premises or removal of the massage establishment to another location shall require inspection and shall require compliance with all applicable provisions of this Code. 
(Prior code 5-421-17) 
Sec. 6-148. - Operation contrary to provisions. 
    Any massage establishment operated, conducted or maintained contrary to the provisions of this Article shall be and is declared to be unlawful and a public nuisance. At the direction of the City Council, the City Attorney, in addition to all other remedies set forth hereunder, may institute action to revoke the license pursuant to the procedures set forth in this Article; may commence an action or actions, proceeding or proceedings, for the abatement, removal and enjoinment thereof, in the manner provided by law; and shall take such other steps and apply to such other court or courts as may have jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate or remove such massage establishments and restrain and enjoin any person from operating, conducting or maintaining establishments contrary to the provisions of this Article. 
(Prior code 5-421-18) 
Secs. 6-149-6-160. - Reserved.

(2)  Said sales shall be limited in duration to forty-eight (48) hours and to four (4) such sales per property per year. 
(3)  Said sales shall follow the sign code, Chapter 16, Article VII.

Sec. 6-181. - Definitions. 
    It shall be unlawful to conduct, keep or maintain any hotel, rooming house or lodging houses by whatever name designated in which space is let by the owner or operator to three (3) or more persons who are not husband or wife, son or daughter, mother or father, or sister or brother of the owner or operator, without obtaining a license therefor as hereinafter set forth; provided, however, that apartment houses and multiple dwellings shall not be required to be licensed hereunder. Such license shall be displayed in a conspicuous place within sight of the main entrance of the rooming house or lodging houses at all times. Such license shall not be transferable. Every person holding such a license shall give notice in writing to the City Clerk within twenty-four (24) hours after having sold, transferred, given away or otherwise disposed of ownership or interest in or control of any hotel, rooming house or lodging houses. Such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such hotel, rooming house or lodging houses. The former owner shall not be relieved of responsibility until such notice if filed. 
(Ord. 2015-994 §21) 
Sec. 6-182. - Registration book required; contents; inspection; exceptions. 
    It shall be the duty of every person keeping a hotel, rooming house, lodging houses or boarding and rooming house, either as principal or by an agent, within the City, to keep at the place where such business is carried on a record or register of the name, address, date of arrival, date of departure and number or other description of the room occupied, of all roomers, lodgers, transients and other persons rooming, lodging or boarding and rooming at such hotel, rooming house, lodging houses or boarding and rooming house; such record shall be kept legible and shall be open to inspection by any law enforcement officer at all hours. The provisions of this Section shall not apply to private residents keeping permanent roomers. 
(Ord. 2015-994 §21) 
Sec. 6-183. - Application, approval of department heads; supervisors; revocation. 
(a)  Before any license is granted, an application shall be filed by the applicant with the City Clerk containing such information as the City Clerk shall require, including two (2) or more references as to the integrity and moral character of the applicant. 
(b)  Such license or license renewal shall be issued upon payment of the license fee and upon certification of the Building Official of the City of Fort Lupton, City of Fort Lupton Fire Protection District's Fire Chief and the Director of the Weld County Health Department that the premises to be licensed or relicensed comply with existing applicable building, fire and safety codes, and the regulations enforced by the Health Department. 
(c)  Any person whose application for a permit to operate a rooming house has been denied may request in writing and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the City Clerk. Such hearing shall be held at such time and place as the City Clerk shall direct, not to exceed ten (10) days following the date of filing such request for hearing. The decision of the City Clerk shall be in writing, and shall state whether or not there is compliance with the laws of the State and this Code. Failure to comply with such laws shall be specifically stated; provided, however, that failure of the City Clerk to state noncompliance with any law or Code shall not relieve the applicant from responsibility for compliance therewith. 
(d)  Any license issued hereunder shall be subject to suspension or revocation in the event that the licensee has permitted his or her hotel or rooming house to become a fire, health or safety hazard to his or her customers or where he or she has permitted it to become either a nuisance, a place of prostitution, a place for gambling or a place for other activities or conditions prohibited by statute or ordinance, or has failed to comply with any provision of this Chapter. 
(e)  Whenever upon inspection of any hotel, rooming house, lodging houses or boarding and rooming house, the City Clerk finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provision of this Chapter or of any provision of the Housing Code or any rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto, the City Clerk shall take appropriate enforcement action in writing to the operator of such establishment to correct such conditions or practices. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy for sleeping or living purposes any rooming unit in any hotel, rooming house or lodging houses of which the license has been suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. 2015-994 §21) 
Sec. 6-184. - License fee. 
    The license fee for conducting such a hotel, rooming house or lodging houses where not more than twenty (20) rooms are kept for rent shall be the sum of five dollars ($5.00) per year, and where more than twenty (20) rooms are kept for rent, the license fee therefor shall be the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) per year. 
(Ord. 2015-994 §21)

ARTICLE VIII - Hazardous Materials and Transportation 

Sec. 6-201. - Adoption of Hazardous Materials Tables and Communications Section. 
    There is hereby adopted by reference by the City Council, Part 172 of Title 49, Transportation, Code of Federal Regulations, known as Hazardous Materials Tables and Hazardous Materials Communications Regulations. This Part 172 is promulgated by the Department of Transportation of the Executive Department and Agency of the Federal Government, National Archives and Records Service, GAS, Washington, D.C. 20408. This Part 172 is a part of Title 49, Code of Federal Regulations and is revised as of October 1, 1981. This Part 172 lists and classifies those materials which the Department of Transportation has designated as hazardous materials for purposes of transportation and prescribes the requirements for shipping papers, package marking, labeling and transport vehicle placarding applicable to the shipping and transportation of those hazardous materials. One (1) copy of the Code has now been filed in the office of the City Clerk and the same is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length, and from the date on which this ordinance codified in this Article shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the City. 
(Prior code 10-508-1) 
Sec. 6-202. - Permits required. 
    Any person doing business within the corporate City limits who uses, stores or manufactures hazardous materials as defined in Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations must: 
(1)  Apply for a permit for such activity with the office of the City Administrator. Permits will be required of all such entities already doing business within the City limits and said entities shall obtain permits within sixty (60) days from the effective date of this Article or be in violation thereof. 
(2)  Accompanying the permit application, such entities must specifically note the type, quantity and description of the defined hazardous materials in storage, use or manufacture. Any additions or deletions of hazardous materials must be immediately reported to the office of the City Administrator. Such lists of hazardous materials will also be delivered to the Chief of Police and to the Fire Chief before any permit will be granted. 
(3)  Fees for such permits will be determined by the City Administrator; they should be of a sufficient amount to cover administrative costs. 
(4)  After the appropriate application for a permit has been made and the fee paid, a hearing will be scheduled before the City Council at one (1) of its regular meetings to grant or deny the issuance of the permit. In determining whether to grant or deny the permit, the City Council will consider the effect of the proposed use on the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City. Restrictions and conditions may be made a part of the issuance of the permit. Only in the most extreme cases will the financial hardship of the applicant for a permit be considered in the decision of whether to grant or deny the permit requested. 
(Prior code 10-508-2) 
Sec. 6-203. - Location. 
(a)  No person who uses, stores or manufactures hazardous materials may do so within one thousand (1,000) feet of any residential area, school, hospital or area zoned for residential use. Uses in violation of this provision at the time of the enactment of the ordinance codified in this Article shall be considered a nonconforming use and a nonconforming use permit may be issued. Such a nonconforming use shall not be expanded, increased or enlarged. The discontinuance of a non-conforming use for a period of more than thirty (30) days shall terminate the nonconforming use, and any future use shall be in compliance with the provisions of this Article. 
(b)  Excepted from the prohibitions contained in this Article are gasoline service stations where the storage of approved quantities of flammable liquids is a normal part of the operation of such business. However, such flammable liquid storage and use is subject to fire, zoning and building codes of the City, the Fire Protection District, the County and the State. 
(Prior code 10-508-3; Ord. 645 §1, 1993)
