(b)  If the owner or occupant of the premises upon which marijuana is being grown, cultivated, manufactured, prepared, processed or packaged denies authorized officials of the City permission to inspect the residential structure or property, authorized law enforcement personnel may request the Municipal Court to issue a search warrant for the inspection of the premises pursuant to procedure and standards as set forth in Rule 241 of the Colorado Municipal Court Rules of Procedure. Any such issued search warrant shall comply with the applicable provisions of Rule 241 of the Colorado Municipal Court Rules of Procedure. 
(Ord. 2014-976 §1) 
Sec. 10-298. - Violations constitute nuisances. 
    In addition to any other lawful method of enforcement which methods shall not be deemed exclusive, a violation of this Article is declared to be a public nuisance that may be abated as provided for in Section 7-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. 2014-976 §1) 
Secs. 10-299-10-310. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 11 - Streets, Sidewalks and Public Property 
ARTICLE I - Sidewalks, Curbs and Gutters 

Sec. 11-1. - Removal of snow. 
    The purpose and intent of this section, in the interest of public safety and the general welfare of the City of Fort Lupton is to facilitate snow removal from curb to curb on City streets, as efficiently and expeditiously as possible after a snow event. The compilation of snow and/or ice removal policy and level of service known as "City of Fort Lupton Snow/Ice Removal with Level of Service Policy and Procedure" as approved and adopted by resolution. 
(Prior code 14-209-1; Ord. 2015-994 §44) 
Sec. 11-2. - Sidewalk construction. 
(a)  All sidewalks constructed under the provisions of this Article shall be constructed in conformity to grade as established by the City Engineer and/or Public Works Director and in conformity with specifications as to materials and size as required by the City Engineer and/or Public Works Director. 
(b)  Any property owner desiring to construct a sidewalk shall construct such sidewalk in like manner as to location and type of sidewalk as may have been previously approved for the block in which such sidewalk shall be constructed, and no sidewalk shall be constructed other than in the manner herein provided. 
(c)  All sidewalks constructed adjacent to corner lots shall extend to the curb lines of the intersection streets. 
(Prior code 14-231-1; Ord. 2015-992 §1; Ord. 2015-994 §31) 
Sec. 11-3. - Sidewalk construction; authority of City Council. 
    Whenever the owners of a majority of the frontage of the lots or land adjacent to or abutting upon any street, alley or designated portion thereof in the City shall petition the City Council in writing to require any sidewalk or sidewalks to be constructed along either or both sides of any portion or portions of any street, streets, alley or alleys described in said petition, and whenever, in the opinion of the City Council, it shall be necessary to make such improvements and construct or cause to be constructed such sidewalk or sidewalks, it shall be the duty of the City Council, after official grades therefore are established, to order by ordinance that said improvements be made, describing the same and further stating therein that if the same is not made and constructed by the property owner or owners chargeable therewith within thirty (30) days from the date said ordinance takes effect under the laws of the State and the ordinances of the City specifying therein said date, then the City will construct or cause the same to be constructed and charge the costs thereof against the owner or owners of the adjacent property and collect the costs thereof as provided by law, which ordinance and the publication thereof shall be notice to all persons affected thereby of the contents and requirements thereof as to making said improvements. 
(Prior code 14-133-1; Ord. 645 §1, 1993) 
Sec. 11-4. - Sidewalk construction; when, costs, notice, hearing, assessment certified, County Treasurer collection. 
(a)  If any person shall fail or refuse to construct any sidewalk adjacent to his or her premises, when so ordered and within the time so provided, the City Council shall proceed to construct the same by contract, which contract may include all portions of said improvements not constructed by the owners thereof described in said ordinance. Upon the completion of any such sidewalk or sidewalks and the acceptance of the same by the City Council, the Finance Director shall prepare a statement of the costs thereof, including the costs of inspection and the services of the City Engineer and/or Public Works Director, in properly locating the same, and therein apportion the costs thereof so that each lot or parcel of land shall be charged for the construction of that portion of said sidewalk which is adjacent to or abutting on said lot or parcel of land. Said statement when completed shall be subject to inspection of any person interested. The Finance Director shall thereupon by advertisement for a period of thirty (30) days, in a newspaper of general circulation published in the City, notify the owner or owners of property to be assessed that said improvements have been or are about to be completed and accepted, specifying the lots or lands to be assessed, the amounts to be assessed on each thereof, and the names of the owners thereof, and also designating therein a time and place at which the City Council shall sit for the purpose of hearing complaints and objections that may be made as aforesaid and shall thereupon make corrections. Upon the day designated, the City Council shall sit for said purposes and to hear any complaints and objections that may be made as aforesaid, shall thereupon make any such changes in said charges as may in its judgment be necessary, equitable and just, and shall thereupon finally determine the amount of such assessments and thereupon assess the costs of such improvements. 
(b)  If said assessments shall not be paid by property owners to the City Clerk within thirty (30) days after said assessments have been so finally determined and made by the City Council, the City Clerk shall certify said assessments to the County Treasurer who shall extend the same upon the tax roll and collect the same as other taxes assessed against said property. 
(Prior code 14-133-2; Ord. 2015-994 §32) 
Sec. 11-5. - Sidewalk repair to protect the traveling public. 
    If it appears to the City Council that any sidewalk is so much out of repair as to endanger the traveling public, it may upon its own motion, by resolution, order that the same be repaired forthwith, and in case the same is not repaired within three (3) days after notice given thereof to the owner, the City may repair the same and assess the costs thereof against the adjacent property and the owner or owners thereof, and if not paid within thirty (30) days, the City shall certify and collect the same as above provided. 
(Prior code 14-133-4) 
Sec. 11-6. - Damage to sidewalks. 
    If any person shall willfully break or otherwise injure any sidewalk, he or she shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction be fined in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-72 of this Code. 
(Prior code 14-204-74; Ord. 645 §1, 1993) 
Sec. 11-7. - Riding of animals and vehicles on sidewalks prohibited. 
    Any person who shall ride or drive any horse, burro or other animal upon any public sidewalk in the City, or any person who shall ride a bicycle, motorcycle or other riding machine or vehicle upon any public sidewalk thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, be fined in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-72 of this Code. This Section shall not apply to law enforcement officers while engaged in their duties. 
(Prior code 14-204-73; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-697 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 11-8. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this Article, or who shall change, disturb, remove or alter any grade stakes or pins set by the City Engineer and/or Operations Manager, either upon any special work done by the City Engineer and/or Public Works Director or the regular pins or monuments set by the City Engineer and/or Public Works Director in establishing grades, as in the ordinance provided, shall upon conviction thereof be fined in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-72 of this Code. 
(Prior code 14-133-5; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 2015-994 §33) 
Secs. 11-9-11-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II - Excavations 

Sec. 11-21. - Permit required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to construct, reconstruct, make or alter any street, driveway, curb, sidewalk or excavation, and/or alter any opening or perform work of any kind within any existing or improved public right-of-way maintained by the city that results in physical alterations or disrupts the normal flow of traffic unless applicant has obtained a permit for the performance of work. All work performed in the City right-of-way shall be in conformance to the City requirements of the engineering design standards and construction specifications. Any person desiring to perform work, as designated above, shall file for an application with the Public Works Director on a form or forms to be refurnished by the City. The Public Works Director may require engineered drawing showing the proposed work in sufficient detail to permit determination of compliance with the City's regulations and standards. All work must be protected with suitable traffic control devices for the safe control of vehicular and pedestrian traffic around the work site. The Public Works Director may require a written traffic control plan to be submitted and approved prior to issuance of a permit and/or commencing of work. 
(Prior code 5-481-1; Ord. 2015-992 §2; Ord. 2015-994 §34) 
Sec. 11-22. - Application for permits. 
    Each and every person desiring to perform any work of any kind described in Section 11-21 in a public way within the City shall make application for a permit with the City Clerk on such forms as the City shall require, and such application shall be supported by plans, specifications and sketches showing the proposed work in sufficient detail as required by the City. 
(Prior code 5-481-2; Ord. 645 §1, 1993) 
Sec. 11-23. - Permit fees. 
    The permittee shall pay the following permit fees at the time the permit is issued: 
(1)  Construction of sanitary sewer line: fifteen dollars ($15.00), plus twenty-five cents ($0.25) a linear foot; 
(2)  Construction of a water line: fifteen dollars ($15.00), plus twenty-five cents ($0.25) a linear foot. 
(3)  Curb, gutter and sidewalk: fifteen dollars ($15.00), plus twenty-five cents ($0.25) a square foot or if sidewalk is poured separately, an additional permit fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) is charged. 
(4)  Street paving: fifteen dollars ($15.00), plus one dollar ($1.00) a linear foot for one-half (1/2) of a street, or if the entire street is paved, the fee shall be ten dollars ($10.00), plus two dollars ($2.00) a linear foot. 
(5)  All other construction: fifteen dollars ($15.00), plus twenty-five cents ($0.25) a foot if linear measurements are applicable, as determined by the City. 
(6)  Right-of-way permits are subject to a seventy-five dollar ($75.00) permit fee. 
(7)  Test holes/pot holes shall be assessed a five dollar ($5.00) permit fee. 
(Prior code 5-481-3; Ord. 2015-994 §35) 
Sec. 11-24. - Additional charges. 
    Additional charges to cover the reasonable cost and expenses of any required engineering review, inspection and work site restoration associated with each undertaking shall be charged by the City to each permittee, in addition to the permit fee, as determined by the City Administrator or City Engineer and/or Public Works Director. The permittee shall be required, at the time of application for permit, to pay an estimated amount to cover the costs of the engineering review, inspection and site restoration. 
(Prior code 5-481-4; Ord. 2015-994 §36) 
Sec. 11-25. - Insurance. 
    Before being issued the permit, each applicant shall provide the City with a certificate of insurance in forms acceptable to the City indicating that the applicant is insured against claims for damages for personal injuries and for property damage which may arise from or out of the performance of the work. 
(Prior code 5-481-5) 
Sec. 11-26. - Bond. 
    Each permittee, before being issued a permit, shall provide the City with an acceptable corporate surety bond of not less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) or a cash deposit to guarantee faithful performance of the work authorized by the permit. The amount of the bond may be increased at the discretion of the City Administrator or City Engineer and/or Public Works Director whenever it appears that the amount and cost of the work performed may exceed the amount of the bond or cash deposit. Public utilities may submit a corporate bond without sureties. 
(Prior code 5-481-6; Ord. 2015-994 §37) 
Sec. 11-27. - Hold harmless. 
    The permittee agrees to save the City, its officers, employees and agents harmless from any and all costs, damages and liabilities which may accrue or be claimed to accrue by reason of any work performed under said permit. 
(Prior code 5-481-7) 
Sec. 11-28. - Contractor's license. 
    Before the applicant, their contractors and/or subcontractors the applicant needs to obtain a contractor's license as described in Chapter 6, Article IV of the Fort Lupton Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 2015-994 §38) 
Sec. 11-29. - Emergency work. 
(a)  Any person maintaining facilities in the public right-of-way may proceed with work on the existing facility without a permit when emergency circumstances demand the work be done immediately, provided that a permit could not practicably and reasonable be obtained beforehand. 
(b)  Any person commencing such emergency work in the public right-of-way without a permit shall immediately thereafter apply for a permit or give notice on the first business day after commencement of such work. 
(c)  In the event emergency work is commenced on or within the public right-of-way, the police department will be notified within the hour from the time the work is commenced. Persons responsible for conducting such emergency work shall take the necessary safety precautions to protect the public and to direct and control traffic in accordance with current requirements of the Public Works Department. 
(Ord. 2015-994 §39) 
Sec. 11-30. - Duration and limits of permits. 
(a)  Each permit application shall state the starting date and estimated completion date. The permit shall be valid only for the time period specified. If work is not completed during the specific time period the applicant may apply for an extension to the Public Works Director. An extension may be refused if the Public Works Director funds that the work under the original permit has not been satisfactory performed. The Public Works Director may require additional financial security as a condition to the extension request. 
(b)  The Public Works Director shall have the right and authority to regulate work under any permit issued by the City with respect to hours and days of work and measures required for the protection of traffic, persons and property. 
(c)  Permit will not be transferable or assignable and work shall not be performed in any place other than that specified on the original permit. Applicant may use subcontractors under a permit provided that the holder of the permit shall be and remain responsible for the performance of the work and all insurance and financial security as required. A copy of the permit shall be available for inspection upon demand at the job site at all times. 
(Ord. 2015-994 §40) 
Sec. 11-31. - Suspension or revocation of permits. 
(a)  Any permit may be revoked or suspended by the Public Works Director and such revocation or suspension shall take effect immediately after notice to the applicant or person performing work for any of the following: 
(1)  Violation of any condition of the permit. 
(2)  Violation of any provision or any other ordinance or law relating to the work. 
(3)  The existence of any condition which does constitute or cause a condition endangering life or property. 
(b)  Any suspension or revocation of the permit by the Public Works Director may be appealed as herein provided. 
(Ord. 2015-994 §41) 
Secs. 11-32-11-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III - Streets and Public Property 

Sec. 11-41. - Unlawful acts. 
    It shall be unlawful to: 
(1)  Construct or place any covering or bridge over any gutter; 
(2)  Plant or transplant any tree upon any public highway or right-of-way; 
(3)  Burn or set fire to any material whatsoever on any street in the City; and 
(4)  Construct any driveway or approach to private property except as provided in Section 11-42 below. 
(Prior code 14-229-1; Ord. 645 §1, 1993) 
Sec. 11-42. - Driveway or private approach to property. 
    Before any private approach or driveway to any property from any street within the City shall be constructed, the owner of the property abutting upon such street shall obtain a permit therefor from the Public Works Department, the charge for which shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for each such driveway or approach, and such driveway shall be constructed only in accordance with such permit and in conformity with the stakes set by the Public Works Director and in conformity with specifications approved by the City Engineer and/or Public Works Director. 
(Prior code 14-229-2; Ord. 2015-994 §42) 
Sec. 11-43. - Repair and restoration. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued by the Public Works Director which will allow an excavation or opening in a newly paved or constructed street less than three (3) years old unless the applicant can clearly demonstrate that the public safety or interest requires the proposed work, an emergency condition exists, or the cut is necessary for a newly constructed residence, building to be served with required utilities and the applicant acquired ownership of the land or lot on which the newly constructed building is situated after completion of the last paving or repaving. 
(b)  Restoration work performed in a newly paved or constructed street less than three (3) years old may be required to higher engineering and construction standards than those ordinarily required so that the restoration will conform to the qualities of the existing street. Any additional cost incurred as a result of the higher standards will be borne solely by the applicant. 
(c)  All utility, street cuts and construction work in the public right-of-way shall be done under the supervision of the Public Works Director or his representative and the cost of making these cuts and restoring the paving thereafter shall be borne by the applicant. In addition, the applicant making the request shall bear the entire cost of any repair or restoration projects required because of the latter settling at the site of excavation and/or repair. 
(Ord. 2015-994 §43) 
Secs. 11-44-11-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV - Hillside Cemetery 

Sec. 11-61. - Transfer of cemetery title. 
(a)  The City Council is hereby empowered to accept from the Hillside Cemetery Association, a Colorado corporation, all of the right, title and interest of said Association in and to Hillside Cemetery, located in the North Half (N1/2) of Section Eight (8), in Township One (1) North of Range Sixty-six (66) West of the Sixth P.M. in Weld County, Colorado. 
(b)  The City Council is hereby empowered to accept donations from any source to be used for the management and care of said cemetery. 
(Prior code 2-215-1, 2-215-2) 
Sec. 11-62. - Establishment of Hillside Cemetery. 
    All that portion and parcel of the following described land in the County and State, heretofore obtained from the Hillside Cemetery Association by the City exclusively for cemetery purposes, is hereby set aside and dedicated as a burial place for the dead, to be known as Hillside Cemetery: 
Part of the E1/2 NE1/4, Section 8, Township 1 North, Range 66 West of the 6th P.M., Weld County, State of Colorado, described as beginning 30 feet South of the NW corner of NE1/4, thence South 0°15' East 525 feet, thence South 89°50' East 598 feet, thence North 0°15' West 525 feet, thence North 89°50' West 598 feet to point of beginning, containing 7.207 acres more or less. 
(Ord. 575 §1, 1989) 
Sec. 11-63. - Survey of cemetery; plat, lots and maps. 
    The City Council shall cause said cemetery to be surveyed, laid out and platted into lots, duly numbered, by a professional engineer and land surveyor registered with the State, and a map thereof made and certified under the hand of said engineer and filed with the City Clerk; a copy of said plat, duly certified by the Mayor and City Clerk, shall be filed with the County Clerk and Recorder. 
(Ord. 575 §2, 1989) 
Sec. 11-64. - Sale of lots. 
(a)  Upon the filing of such plat with the City Clerk, as aforesaid, the office of the City Clerk shall maintain records that list each lot and affix the price for each lot which may be sold. Upon the payment to the office of the City Clerk of the price of any said lot or lots by the purchaser, the City Clerk is hereby authorized and empowered to execute and deliver to said purchaser or purchasers a good and sufficient deed. 
(b)  A purchaser of a pre-need lot who later decides he or she does not want said lot must sell the lot back to the City for the amount originally paid. No lot or lots are to be sold other than back to the City. 
(Ord. 575 §3, 1989; Ord. 2000-761, Part 1) 
Sec. 11-65. - Burial permits, removal. 
    No interment/inurnment shall be made in Hillside Cemetery or removal of any body made therefrom until all permits required by law and all the information necessary to complete the records of the cemetery shall have been furnished to the City Clerk. No body shall be removed from the cemetery after the burial of such body except upon written permission according to the laws of the State as in such case made and provided. 
(Ord. 575 §4, 1989; Ord. 2000-761, Part 1) 
Sec. 11-66. - Perpetual care fee and perpetual care fund. 
    Every purchaser of a lot or burial space in a cemetery owned by the City shall be required, in addition to the payment of the price fixed for said lot, to pay a perpetual care fee in connection with the purchase of such lot or burial space. Such fee shall be in the amount established from time to time by the City Council, which fee shall be invested, and the interest thereof shall be used by the City to grade and seed lawn grass and take perpetual care of the lots and burial spaces for which such fees are paid. It shall be the duty of the Finance Director to keep a separate fund, and the fund so created shall be known and designated as the "Perpetual Care Fund." (Ord. 575 §6, 1989; Ord. 2000-761, Part 1) 
Sec. 11-67. - Burial in approved cemeteries within City required. 
    The interment/inurnment of any deceased person within the corporate limits of the City, except in platted and duly authorized cemeteries, shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. 575 §7, 1989; Ord. 2000-761, Part 1) 
Sec. 11-68. - Injuries to cemetery grounds, ornaments and/or monuments. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully ride or drive upon any place within Hillside Cemetery other than platted driveways, or to willfully deface, injure or destroy any monument, tomb, grave, or gravestone, grass plot, walkway, driveway, building or any other part thereof associated with Hillside Cemetery. 
(b)  It shall be further unlawful for any person to enter the grounds of Hillside Cemetery at any time between sunset and sunrise without the written permission of the Public Safety Director (Police Chief). 
(Ord. 575 §8, 1989; Ord. 2000-761, Part 1) 
Sec. 11-69. - Rules and regulations. 
    The compilation of cemetery rules known as the "Hillside Cemetery Rules and Regulations" as approved and adopted by reference by Resolution of the City Council are hereby adopted into this Section. These rules may be referred to as "Cemetery Rules" and the City Clerk shall maintain copies of the Cemetery Rules. The City Clerk is authorized to promulgate procedures to implement the Cemetery Rules. 
(Ord. 2000-761, Part 1; Ord. 2007-898) 
Sec. 11-70. - Modifications. 
    Modifications to the Cemetery Rules may be by ordinance or resolution adopted by the City Council. 
(Ord. 2000-761, Part 1) 
Sec. 11-71. - Memorial Fund. 
    The Memorial Fund is hereby established for the purpose of receiving and holding gifts and donations in trust on behalf of the Hillside Cemetery. It shall be the duty of the Finance Director to keep a separate trust fund, and the fund so created shall be known and designated as the "Memorial Fund." (Ord. 2000-764, Part 1) 
Secs. 11-72-11-80. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 12 - Enterprises 
ARTICLE I - Utility and Storm Water Enterprises 

Sec. 12-1. - Utility Enterprise. 
    The existing Water and Sewer Enterprises of the City, consolidated as one (1) "Utility Enterprise," is hereby formally recognized as a government owned and operated business pursuant to Article X, Section 20(2)(d) of the Colorado Constitution, Section 37-45.1-101, et seq., C.R.S. and other applicable statutes and Chapter 13 of this Code and, by and through its governing body, continues to be authorized to issue its own revenue bonds. The Utility Enterprise of the City shall have no authority to levy or collect any taxes, whether sales taxes, use taxes, ad valorem taxes or otherwise. The City shall continue to maintain separate financial accounts for the receipt and disbursement of funds related to the operation of this enterprise. 
(Ord. 95-675; Ord. 98-733) 
Sec. 12-2. - Reserved. 
Sec. 12-3. - Storm Water Drainage Facility Enterprise. 
    The existing Storm Water Drainage Facility Enterprise of the City is hereby formally recognized as a government owned and operated business pursuant to Article 10, Section 20(2)(d) of the Colorado Constitution, Section 37-45.1-101, et seq., C.R.S., and Chapter 13 of this Code and, by and through its governing body, continues to be authorized to issue its own revenue bonds. The Storm Water Drainage Facility Enterprise of the City shall have no authority to levy or collect any taxes, whether sales taxes, use taxes, ad valorem taxes or otherwise. The City shall continue to maintain separate financial accounts for the receipt and disbursement of funds related to the operation of this enterprise. 
(Ord. 95-675) 
Sec. 12-4. - Board of Commissioners created. 
    There is hereby created a Board of Commissioners to manage the City's Utility Enterprise and Storm Water Drainage Facility Enterprise, to be known as the Fort Lupton Utilities Enterprise Board (the "Board"), which shall be the governing body of the Utility Enterprise and the Storm Water Drainage Facility Enterprise. 
(Ord. 95-675; Ord. 98-733) 
Sec. 12-5. - Board membership. 
    The Board shall consist of the elected Mayor and members of City Council. The City Administrator and Finance Director shall be ex officio, nonvoting members. The City Clerk shall serve as secretary to the Board. 
(Ord. 95-675) 
Sec. 12-6. - Board meetings. 
    Meetings of the Board shall be open, public meetings, subject to the requirements of the Open Meetings Law, Section 24-6-401, et seq., C.R.S. Executive sessions may be held as provided in the Open Meetings Law. Records of the Board are public records, subject to the provisions of the Open Records Law, Section 24-72-201, et seq., C.R.S. 
(Ord. 95-675) 
Sec. 12-7. - Board meeting procedures. 
    The Board shall establish and prescribe the time and place of its meetings, provided that the Board shall meet at least once per month. Meetings may coincide with City Council meetings. The Secretary shall record the minutes of all meetings, including the votes of all members on all questions, and shall separately maintain and preserve the records of the Utility Enterprise and Storm Water Drainage Facility Enterprise. 
(Ord. 95-675; Ord. 98-733) 
Sec. 12-8. - Staff support. 
    The City Administrator shall provide staff support to the Board. 
(Ord. 95-675) 
Sec. 12-9. - Power and authority. 
    The Board shall have and exercise the full power and authority of the City in connection with the Utility Enterprise and Storm Water Drainage Facility Enterprise and the property and rights connected therewith or incidental thereto, including all authority available by law to water activity enterprises, and may utilize revenue from any lawful source, subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  The Board shall establish and may amend from time to time the rates and fees for service by the enterprises. Different rates and fees may be established for different cases of service. Rates must be sufficient, together with other revenues, to meet all expenditures, including: 
a.  All operations and maintenance. 
b.  All debt service requirements and current capital expenditures; 
c.  Reasonable and prudent reserves; 
d.  Rates for service outside the City limits, if authorized by City Council, shall be no less than one hundred fifty percent (150%) of rates for comparable service inside the City limits; 
(2)  Rates and fees shall be established or amended by resolution of the Board, following the same procedures as are prescribed for an ordinance of the City Council, including publication. 
(3)  The Board shall establish separate annual budgets for these enterprises, and develop long-range plans and budget projections with the City Administrator. The City Administrator and City Council shall establish separate annual budgets for the Utility Enterprise and Storm Water Drainage Facility Enterprise and long-range plans and budget projections. All actions of the Board shall be consistent with the budgets approved by City Council. There are hereby created separate funds for the Utility Enterprise and the Storm Water Drainage Facility Enterprise to account for their separate revenues and expenditures. 
(4)  The management of the Utility and Storm Water Drainage Facility Enterprises, and the authority over the personnel thereof shall be as set forth in Article III of Chapter 2 of this Code as amended by Ordinance 94-633. 
(5)  The Board shall have no authority to levy or collect any taxes, whether sales taxes, use taxes, ad valorem taxes or otherwise. 
(Ord. 95-675; Ord. 98-733) 
Secs. 12-10-12-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II - Golf Course Enterprise 

Sec. 12-21. - Golf Course Enterprise. 
    The existing Golf Course Enterprise of the City is hereby formally recognized as a government owned and operated business as defined by Article X, Section 20(2)(d) of the Colorado Constitution and other applicable statutes and by and through its governing body continues to be authorized to issue its own revenue bonds. The principal function of the Golf Course Enterprise will be the financing and operation of the City golf course. The Golf Course Enterprise shall have no authority to levy or collect any taxes, whether sales taxes, use taxes, ad valorem taxes or otherwise. The City shall continue to maintain separate financial accounts for the receipt and disbursement of funds related to the operation of this enterprise, and shall maintain separate operating records for this enterprise. 
(Ord. 95-679 §1) 
Sec. 12-22. - Governing body. 
    The City Council is the governing body of the Golf Course Enterprise. Meetings of the Council as the governing body of this enterprise shall be open, public meetings, subject to the requirements of the Open Meetings Law, Section 24-6-401, et seq., C.R.S. Executive sessions may be held as provided in the Open Meetings Law. Records of the Board are public records, subject to the provisions of the Open Records Law, Section 24-72-201, et seq., C.R.S. Meetings may coincide with City Council meetings. The management of the Golf Course Enterprise and the authority over the personnel thereof shall be as set forth in Article III of Chapter 2 of this Code as amended by Ordinance 94-633, or may be contracted for by the City Council in whole or in part. If, as contemplated, management of the golf course is contracted for, in whole or in part, the City shall select the representative of the City who shall, with consultation and approval of the Council, have authority to coordinate the operation of the golf course with the representative of the management company. The governing body shall approve the budget for the golf course and regulate the water use and carry out the augmentation program, and approve the compensation owed to the City by the Golf Course Enterprise for these and other matters, such as administrative costs incurred by the City. The governing body may delegate to appointed officials or executives of the City the responsibility and authority for signing documentation needed in the financing and operation of the enterprise. 
(Ord. 95-679 §1) 
Secs. 12-23-12-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III - Recreation Enterprise 

Sec. 12-41. - Recreation Enterprise. 
    The Recreation Enterprise of the City is hereby formally recognized as a government-owned and -operated business as defined by Article X, Section 20(2)(d) of the Colorado Constitution and applicable statutes of the state and, through its governing body, is authorized to issue its own revenue bonds. The Recreation Enterprise has been functioning as such since January 1, 2004. The Recreation Enterprise may also be referred to as the Recreation Department. The functions of the Recreation Enterprise shall include: 
(1)  Administering, implementing and co-coordinating recreation, youth and senior programs and other leisure activities, and 
(2)  Managing, maintaining and operating City recreational facilities, including but not limited to the Community Center and Recreation Center. 
(Ord. 2004-820, Pt. 1) 
Sec. 12-42. - Board of Commissioners created. 
    There is hereby created a Board of Commissioners to manage the Recreation Enterprise, to be known as the Recreation Board, which shall be the governing body of the Recreation Enterprise. 
(Ord. 2004-820, Pt. 1) 
Sec. 12-43. - Board membership. 
    The Recreation Board shall consist of the Elected Mayor and members of the City Council, unless the City Council, by resolution, appoints different persons to serve as Recreation Board members. The City Administrator and Finance Director shall be ex officio, nonvoting, member of the Recreation Board. 
(Ord. 2004-820, Pt. 1) 
Sec. 12-44. - Board meetings. 
    Recreation Board meetings shall be held pursuant to Section 12-26 of this Code, or as otherwise provided by City Council resolution. 
(Ord. 2004-820, Pt. 1) 
Sec. 12-45. - Chief Financial Officer. 
    The Finance Director of the City shall be the Chief Financial Officer of the Recreation Enterprise. The City shall maintain separate financial accounts for the receipt and disbursement of funds related to the operation of the Recreation Enterprise. 
(Ord. 2004-820, Pt. 1) 
Sec. 12-46. - Chief Executive Officer and Chief Operating Officer. 
    The City Administrator shall be the Chief Executive Officer of the Recreation Enterprise, and the Recreation Director of the City shall be the Chief Operating Officer of the Recreation Enterprise, unless otherwise established by City Council resolution. 
(Ord. 2004-820, Pt. 1) 
Sec. 12-47. - City support. 
    The City may provide administrative support and staff services to the Recreation Enterprise. The City may charge the Recreation Enterprise for any such support and services. 
(Ord. 2004-820, Pt. 1) 
Sec. 12-48. - Taxes. 
    The Recreation Enterprise shall have no authority to levy any taxes, whether sales taxes, use taxes, ad valorem taxes or otherwise. The Recreation Enterprise receives and will continue to receive operating funds from a voter-approved ad valorem tax, initiated by the City, which are not subject to the revenue and expense provisions of TABOR, as provided by that initiative. 
(Ord. 2004-820, Pt. 1) 
Sec. 12-49. - Recreation Foundation. 
    There is hereby created, within the Recreation Enterprise, the Fort Lupton Recreation Foundation, in order to receive and disburse grants, contributions and other gifts directed to it for the benefit of the Recreation Enterprise. Recreation Foundation accounts shall be kept separate and apart from other Recreation Enterprise or City funds. Recreation Foundation accounts may not be used for, borrowed from or pledged to any other City funds. Recreation Foundation funds may be used to pay for services for the Recreation Foundation provided by the City or outside vendors for Recreation Foundation purposes (i.e. the cost of planting a tree donated to the Recreation Foundation). Recreation Foundation grants, contributions or gifts must be used in the manner and purpose under which they are given, if a use is so specified and if such use is approved by the Recreation Board; or, if no specific use is specified, for the general benefit of the Recreation Enterprise, and the people it serves. One of the authorized purposes of the Recreation Foundation may be to support low-cost or no-cost admission and use of facilities. 
(Ord. 2004-820, Pt. 1) 
Secs. 12-50-12-60. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 13 - Municipal Utilities 
ARTICLE I - Sewer System 

Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this Article, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed hereafter: 
    Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty degrees (20°) Centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain shall mean that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a draining system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called house connection. 
    Combined sewer shall mean a sewer intended to receive both wastewater and storm or surface water (not permitted). 
    Easement shall mean an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    Floatable oil is oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. Wastewater shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    Garbage shall mean the animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and serving of foods. 
    Industrial wastes shall mean the wastewater from industrial processes, trade or business as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes. 
    May is permissive - see shall , below. 
    Natural outlet shall mean any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer overflows, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or groundwater. 
    pH shall mean the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen-ion concentration. The concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams, per liter of solution. Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of 7 and a hydrogen-ion concentration of the log (1/H +). 
    Properly shredded garbage shall mean the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half (1/2) inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer shall mean a common sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public utility. 
    Sanitary sewer shall mean a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions together with minor quantities of ground, storm and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
    Sewage is the spent water of a community. The preferred term is wastewater, defined in below. 
    Sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water. 
    Sewer plant investment fee shall mean a fee charged for the privilege of connecting into the City's sewer system. 
    Sewer tap means an opening or connection in the mains through which wastewater is discharged. 
    Shall is mandatory - see may , above. 
    Slug shall mean any discharge of water or wastewater which, in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration, or flows during normal operation, and shall adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater treatment works. 
    Storm drain (sometimes termed storm sewer) shall mean a drain or sewer for conveying water, groundwater, subsurface water or unpolluted water from any source. 
    Suspended solids shall mean total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of or is in suspension in water, wastewater or other liquids and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" and referred to as nonfilterable residue. 
    Unpolluted water is water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
    Wastewater shall mean the spent water of a community. From the stand-point of source, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present. 
    Wastewater facilities shall mean the structure, equipment and processes required to collect, carry away and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. 
    Wastewater treatment works shall mean an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with waste treatment plant or sewer treatment plant or wastewater treatment plant or water pollution control plant. 
    Water requirements means Colorado Big Thompson (CBT) or Windy Gap water shares, or cash-in-lieu of such water shares, required to be conveyed or paid to the City at the time of the development of land. (See Sec. 13-122.) 
    Watercourse shall mean a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or intermittently. 
(Prior code 12-530-4; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-698 §1; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-2. - Management of sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities. 
    The Operations Director is the manager of the sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities for the purpose of management, maintenance, care and operation of the sewer system and wastewater treatment plant. 
(Prior code 12-530-1; Ord. 96-698 §1) 
Sec 13-3. - Powers of Operations Director; City Administrator. 
    The Operations Director shall have the immediate control and management of all things pertaining to City sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities, and the Operations Director shall perform all acts necessary for the prudent, efficient and economical management and protection of said sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities. The Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board shall have the power, by written resolution, to prescribe such other and further rules and rates as it may deem necessary. Technical services of a qualified engineer may be used in all cases wherein the Operations Director does not have the requisite engineering knowledge and experience to make decisions requiring such technical services. The City Administrator is authorized to promulgate regulations, guidelines and procedures adopted by the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board, consistent with this Code, as are reasonably necessary and appropriate to implement the rules and policies of the Board. 
(Prior code 12-530-2; Ord. 96-698 §1; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-4. - Receipts and deposits. 
    The Finance Director shall keep a correct account of all receipts and materials furnished to consumers and shall collect the same and deposit the proceeds so collected to the credit of the Utility Enterprise Fund in accordance with the direction of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. 
(Prior code 12-530-3; Ord. 96-698 §1; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-5. - Composition of sewer utility. 
    All sewer mains and collection lines, sewer lift stations, wastewater treatment plant and appurtenances thereto, machinery, equipment and supplies used by the City to supply its sewer users with service shall be known as the sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities; provided, however, that the sewer service line from the sewer main including the sewer tap saddle or wye, to the structure or property served shall be regarded as the property of the owner of said structure or property served. 
(Prior code 12-530-7; Ord. 96-698 §1; Ord. 2015-994 §45) 
Sec. 13-6. - Damage to sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities property prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to in any way damage property, equipment or appliances constituting a part of the sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities. It shall be unlawful for any person to cast, place, dump or deposit any substance or material into the sewer system or wastewater treatment facilities which will in any manner injure or obstruct the system or facilities or pollute or contaminate the water. 
(Prior code 12-530-8; Ord. 96-698 §1) 
Sec. 13-7. - Change of sewer use. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to alter, change, enlarge or extend in any manner whatsoever the type of use for which the sewer system was approved by the Operations Director, except as provided herein. 
(Prior code 12-530-10; Ord. 96-698) 
Sec. 13-8. - Inspections; repairs. 
    Whenever the Operations Director deems it necessary, the Operations Director may inspect the condition of all pipes and sewer fixtures or the manner in which the sewer is used. The Operations Director shall have the authority to make, or cause to be made, any repairs or alterations to sewer user's service as the Operations Director deems reasonably necessary. The Operations Director shall be vigilant to protect and remedy all abuses or other improper use of sewer. 
(Prior code 12-530-6; Ord. 96-698 §1) 
Sec. 13-9. - Safety and access. 
(a)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in Section 13-8 above, the Operations Director or duly authorized employees of the City shall observe all reasonable safety rules applicable to the premises established by the owner or occupant of the premises. The owner and occupant shall be held harmless for injury or death to the City employees, and the City shall indemnify the owner and occupant of the premises against loss or damage to its property by City employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the owner and occupant of the premises growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the owner and occupant of the premises to maintain safe conditions as required. 
(b)  The Operations Director and other duly authorized employees of the City bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the City holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the wastewater facilities lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Prior code 12-530-25; Ord. 96-698 §1) 
Sec. 13-10. - Interference with sewer facilities prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass upon the property of the City, to tap any sewer mains or to make any connections therewith, without first having obtained a permit to do so. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to in any manner interfere with the City or the property, equipment, pipes, valves or any other appliances of the City, or to change or alter the position of any valve or appliance regarding the flow of sewer in any pipeline. 
(Prior code 12-530-9) 
Sec. 13-11. - Authority during emergency situations. 
    In the event of an emergency that should require the immediate curtailment of sewer service, the City Administrator shall have the authority to make such restrictions as deemed necessary for the protection of the public. 
(Prior code 12-530-21) 
Sec. 13-12. - Connections to sewer lines and mains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any connections with any sewer pipeline main which forms a part of the sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities except pursuant to and in accordance with the permit required by this Article. It shall be unlawful to make any connections with any privately owned sewer mains or pipelines which are connected with the sewer utility or to change, alter or renew any presently existing private main or pipeline connected with the sewer utility with any pipe larger than that in use. 
(Prior code 12-530-11; Ord. 96-698 §1) 
Sec. 13-13. - General regulations for sewer service lines. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than a licensed plumber or the City's authorized representative to install a sewer line from the main to the building or connection. All service lines shall be of material and size as specified in the current City's specifications. 
(b)  The service line from the sewer main, including tap, to the structure served shall be installed, maintained and repaired by the sewer user at his or her expense. No claim shall be made against the City on account of breaking or for failure of the service of sewer, and no reduction in the rates will be made for any time that service pipes or fixtures are frozen or are not in proper working order. All connections, taps and lines that are or will become the responsibility of the City for maintenance shall be inspected by the City's authorized representative prior to being backfilled and used. 
(c)  The City shall be responsible for all maintenance and repairs to the sewer mains. 
(d)  Cross-connections with any water supply is strictly prohibited. 
(e)  The sewer service line from the main to the sewer collection system of the building to be served with sewer shall be of sufficient size to furnish an adequate flow to meet the requirements of the building and premises at peak demand and in no case shall be less than four (4) inches in diameter. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the City, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said City, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the City, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said City, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this Article. 
(h)  Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. 
(i)  The owner of every house, building or property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the City and abutting on any other street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the City, is hereby required at the owner's expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this Article, within one hundred twenty (120) days after date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within four hundred (400) feet of the property line. 
(j)  New services to replace existing services shall not be approved by the City until the old service lines are completely disconnected from the main. 
(Prior code 12-530-16; Ord. 2015-992 §3; Ord. 2015-994 §46) 
Sec. 13-14. - Installation of lines. 
    All lines shall be installed in accordance with the current City specifications in effect at the time of installation. 
(Prior code 12-530-17; Ord. 2015-994 §47) 
Sec. 13-15. - Excavation and backfilling. 
    All excavation and backfilling in the street or alley shall be in conformity with current City specifications in effect at the time of work being done. 
(Prior code 12-530-18; Ord. 2015-994 §48) 
Sec. 13-16. - Installation prior to street paving. 
    Before any street containing a sewer line is paved, the City shall cause to be installed all service lines as the City determines necessary to serve said property when fully developed. 
(Prior code 12-530-19) 
Sec. 13-17. - Repairs and extensions of mains. 
    The City reserves the right to stop service from any street main when necessary to make repairs or extensions of the sewer mains or to perform any other work necessary to maintain the sewer utility. Unless it is an emergency situation, the City will attempt to give reasonable notice to the sewer users. No claim shall be made against the City by reason of any breakage or for any other damage that may result from lack of sewer service for repairing or replacing mains or other connections. 
(Prior code 12-530-20) 
Sec. 13-18. - Supplying sewer service to others. 
    No occupant or owner of any building or lot into which sewer service is introduced will be allowed to supply sewer service to other persons, families or firms, except as approved by the Operations Director. The Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board agrees to furnish service for a specified sum. If a sewer user furnishes other persons sewer service for building purposes or permits sewer service to be used without the knowledge and consent of the Operations Director the owner or occupant shall be deemed in violation of contract, and sewer users so offending will be required to pay double the price of service so used, and the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board reserves the right to shut off the water supply for abuses of privileges. When the water has been turned off for violation thereof, the water will not be turned on again until all fees and penalties have been paid. 
(Prior code 12-530-22; Ord. 96-698 §1) 
Sec. 13-19. - Use outside City corporate limits. 
    Use of sewer service outside the corporate limits shall be permitted subject to the paramount rights of users within the corporate limits. The use of sewer service outside the City corporate limits shall be at the sole discretion of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. In case there shall be insufficient capacity to provide for users both within and without the corporate limits, the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board may reduce, curtail or shut off the sewer users outside the City corporate limits during such period of capacity shortage. The rates for sewer use outside the City corporate limits shall be adopted by written resolution of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. 
(Prior code 12-530-23; Ord. 96-698 §1) 
Sec. 13-20. - Use of public sewers. 
(a)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any nonsanitary waters such as stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff or subsurface drainage to any sanitary sewer, except by written permission of the Operations Director. 
(b)  Stormwater other than that exempted under Subsection (a) above and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager and other regulatory agencies. Unpolluted industrial cooling water or process water or air conditioning wastewater may be discharged, on approval of the Operations Director and/or the Wastewater Plant Manager, to a sanitary sewer as permitted. 
(c)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged to any public sewer any of the following described domestic, commercial or industrial water or wastes not meeting the following limitations: 
(1)  Must have an instantaneous pH value in the range of five and one-half (5.5) to nine (9.0) standard units. Must not contain pollutants which will cause corrosive effects, damage or hazards to structures, equipment or personnel of the treatment works or Public Works Department. 
(2)  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the collecting system or wastewater facilities such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails, paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(3)  Must not contain improperly shredded garbage that has not been ground or comminuted to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely in suspension under flow conditions normally prevailing in the wastewater system to which the user is connected. At all times, no particle shall be greater than one-half (1/2) inch in any direction. 
(4)  Must not contain explosive mixtures consisting of liquids, solids or gases which by reason of their nature or quantity are, or may be, sufficient either alone or by interaction with other substances to cause fire or explosion or be injurious in any other way to the operation of sewers or the treatment works. At no time shall two (2) successive readings on an explosion hazard meter at the point of discharge into the wastewater system be more than five percent (5%), nor may any single reading be over ten percent (10%) of the lower explosive limit (L.E.L.) of the meter. Prohibited materials include but are not limited to: arsenic, cadmium, chromium, chromium, copper, lead, mercury, molybdenum, nickel, selenium, silver, zinc, benzene, BTEX, gasoline, kerosene, fuel oil, naphtha, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides and sulfides. 
(5)  Must not contain pollutants which create a fire or explosion hazard in the treatment works, including but not limited to waste streams with a closed cup flashpoint of less than eighty-six degrees (86°) Centigrade (187° Fahrenheit) using the test methods specified in 40 C.F.R § 261.21. Pollutants must not contain any flammable substance with a flashpoint lower than eighty-six degrees (86°) Centigrade (187° Fahrenheit). 
(6)  Must not contain heat in amounts which will inhibit biological activity in the treatment works resulting in interference, but in no case heat in such quantities that the temperature at the treatment works exceeds forty degrees (40°) Centigrade (104° Fahrenheit). At no time shall the temperature of the water or wastes at the point of discharge into the public sewer be less than thirty-two degrees (32°) Fahrenheit or more than one hundred fifty degrees (150°) Fahrenheit. 
(7)  Must not contain grease or oil or other substances that will solidify or become viscous between thirty-two degrees (32°) degrees Fahrenheit and one hundred fifty degrees (150°) Fahrenheit. 
(8)  Must not contain insoluble substances in excess of ten thousand (10,000) parts per million. 
(9)  Must not contain solids in excess of twenty thousand (20,000) parts per million. 
(10)  Must not contain insoluble substances having a specific gravity greater than 2.65. 
(11)  Must not contain gases or vapors either free or occluded in concentrations toxic or dangerous to humans or animals. 
(12)  Must not contain toxic, carcinogenic, poisonous, irritating, noxious or malodorous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, which could contaminate the sludge of any municipal system, injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, create a hazard to treatment plant employees, Public Works employees or create any hazard in or have an adverse effect on the waters receiving any discharge from the treatment works. 
(13)  Must not have a chlorine demand greater than fifteen (15) parts per million. 
(14)  Must not contain any pollutant, including oxygen demanding pollutants (BOD, etc.) released at a rate and/or concentration which has a reasonable potential, in the opinion of the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager to adversely affect the treatment plant (inhibition, pass-through of pollutants, sludge contamination, or endangerment of treatment plant workers and/or Public Works employees). 
(15)  Must not have a BOD in excess of three hundred twenty-five (325) milligrams per liter. 
(16)  Must not contain in excess of fifty (50) parts per million of fat, grease or any other fat or grease products from animal or vegetable origin, or both. Oil, floatable oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil or any substance from mineral or petroleum origin, or both, including but not limited to: Cooling or quenching oils, lubrication oils, cutting oils and nonsaponifiable oils must not exceed ten (10) parts per million. 
(17)  Must not contain organic toxic pollutants, introduced by the intentional or accidental dumping of solvents, used in operations involving degreasing, surface preparation, tank washing, paint thinning, paint equipment cleaning or any other process. 
(18)  Shall not be any trucked or hauled pollutant, except as approved by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager and discharged at a point designated by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager. 
(19)  Must not contain storm water, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff or subsurface drainage without first obtaining a permit from the control authority for such a discharge. 
(20)  Must not contain the following pollutants in excess of the following limits as measured at the point of discharge into the wastewater system: 
Pollutant Milligrams per Liter Total Iron 1.5 Total Cadmium 0.05 Total Chromium 4.5 Total Copper 0.5 Total Lead 2.0 Total Mercury 0.007 Total Nickel 10.0 Total Zinc 4.0 Total Arsenic 0.1 Total Cyanide 1.0 Total Phenols 10.0 Total Silver 0.5 Total Selenium 12.0  
    (21) Must not contain any radioactive wastes or isotopes. 
(d)  The following described substances, materials, waters or wastes shall be limited in discharges to municipal systems, to concentrations or quantities which will not harm either the sewers, wastewater treatment processes or equipment, will not have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or will not otherwise endanger lives, limb or public property or constitute a nuisance. The limitations or restrictions on materials or characteristics of wastes or wastewaters discharged to the sanitary sewer which shall not be violated without approval of the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager are as follows: 
(1)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded (See Subsection (c)(3) above). Garbage grinders may be connected to sanitary sewers from homes, hotels, institutions, restaurants, hospitals, catering establishments or similar places where garbage originates from the preparation of food in kitchens for the purpose of consumption on the premises or when served by caterers. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, lead, zinc and similar objectionable or toxic substances (See Subsection (c)(20) above) to such a degree that any such material received in the composite wastewater at the wastewater treatment plant exceeds the limits established by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager for such materials. 
(3)  Any waters or wastes containing grease, oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil or any oily substance from petroleum or mineral origin, or both (See Subsection (c)(16) above), to such a degree that any such material received in the composite wastewater at the wastewater treatment plant exceeds the limits established by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager for such materials. 
(4)  Any waters or wastes containing floatable oil, fat, grease or any oily substance of vegetable or animal origin, or both (See Subsection (c)(16) above) to such a degree that any such material received in the composite wastewater at the wastewater treatment plant exceeds the limits established by the Operations Director and/Wastewater Plant Manager for such materials. 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the treatment plant. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes containing noxious or odor-producing substances exceeding limits which may be established by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager. 
(7)  Quantities of flow, concentrations or both which constitute a slug as defined in Subsection 13-1(20). 
(8)  Waters or wastewaters which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the wastewater treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such a degree that the wastewater treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(9)  Any waters or wastes which, by interaction with other waters or wastes in the public sewer system, release obnoxious gases, form suspended solids which interfere with the collection system or create a condition deleterious to structures and treatment processes. 
(e)  If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged, to the public sewers that contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in Subsection (d) above, and which in the judgment of the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager may have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater facilities, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or safety or constitute a public nuisance, the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges under the provisions of Subsection (j) below. 
    When considering the above alternative, the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager shall give consideration to the economic impact of each alternative on the discharger. If the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager. 
(f)  Grease, oil and sand interceptors or traps should be cleaned quarterly, or at the discretion of the Operations Director. The Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager may take samples as needed and apply surcharges accordingly. All testing charges are to be paid by owner. Grease, oil and sand interceptors or traps or best available technology shall be provided when, in the opinion of the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease in excessive amounts as specified in Subsection (c)(16) above, or any flammable wastes, sands or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors or traps shall be of a type and capacity approved by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspections. In the maintaining of these interceptors, the owner shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captured material and shall maintain records of the dates and means of disposal which are subject to review by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager. Any removal and hauling of the collected materials not performed by the owner's personnel must be performed by currently licensed waste disposal companies, firms or persons. 
(g)  Where pretreatment of any flow-equalizing facilities are provided or required for any waters or wastewaters, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner and at the owner's expense. 
(h)  When required by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer service carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable structure together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such structures, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager. The structure shall be installed by the owner at the owner's expense and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(i)  The Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager may require a user of sewer services to provide information needed to determine compliance with this Article. The requirements may include: 
(1)  Peak wastewater discharge rates and volumes over a specified time period; 
(2)  Chemical analyses of wastewaters; 
(3)  Information on materials being discharged that affect wastewater characteristics; 
(4)  Quantity and disposition of specific liquid, sludge, oil, solvent or other materials important to sewer use control; 
(5)  A plot plan of sewers of the user's property showing sewer and pretreatment facility location; 
(6)  Details of wastewater pretreatment facilities; 
(7)  Details of systems to prevent and control the losses of materials through spills to the municipal sewer; and 
(8)  Additional information that affects the volume or characteristics of discharges and, as such, may be required by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager to determine compliance with this Article. 
(j)  All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this Article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods of the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association. Sampling methods, location, times, durations and frequencies are to be determined on an individual basis subject to approval by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager. 
(k)  No statement contained in this Section shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or characteristic may be accepted by the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board for treatment. 
(l)  All regulations contained in this Section shall be considered a part of the contract of every person receiving sewer service from the sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities, and no person may be served from the sewer utility unless the person agrees to and abides by all rules and regulations of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board pertaining to the use of said sewer system. 
(m)  Any directives, approvals, disapprovals or other administrative actions issued by the Operations Director and/or Wastewater Plant Manager to a discharger can be requested by the discharger to be referred to the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board for review. The Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board shall act on such issues referred to it for review, and its decisions shall be the final authority regarding interpretations, actions and other compliance issues associated with the City's sewer and wastewater treatment ordinance. 
(Ord. 616 §1, 1992; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-698 §1; Ord. 99-739; Ord. 2015-994 §49) 
Sec. 13-21. - Application for sewer service. 
(a)  Application for sewer shall be made to the Planning and Development Department by the owner, occupant, developer or agent of the property to be benefited and must designate the location of the property, owner of the property, size of sewer taps, location of sewer taps and sewer service line, the approximate date of construction of the facility; and shall state the purpose for which sewer service is required. 
(b)  All sewer tap permits issued shall be issued for a period of one hundred eighty days (180) days, in the same manner as building permits are issued. 
(Prior code 12-530-5; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-698 §1; Ord. 2001-778) 
Sec. 13-22. - Types of permits. 
    There shall be the following types of permits to make connections with the sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities: 
(1)  Sewer tap permit to connect to the sewer system for the purpose of discharging into the sewer system for normal municipal purposes; that is, domestic, commercial or industrial. At the time this permit is granted, the sewer plant investment fee in effect at the time of application, together with all other costs associated with the granting of permission to connect with the sewer system of the City, shall be paid. 
(2)  Sewer tap permit to enlarge or replace an existing sewer tap to the sewer system for the purpose of discharging into the sewer system for normal municipal purposes; that is, domestic, commercial or industrial. At the time the permit is granted, the additional sewer plant investment fee, if any, shall be paid. 
(3)  Permit to discharge into the sewer system to serve property situated outside the corporate limits of the City. This permit shall be issued only under such terms and conditions as the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board may provide by ordinance or resolution. At the time the sewer tap permit is granted, the sewer plant investment fee shall be paid for each individual sewer service. 
(4)  40 CFR Section 03.3(q) requires industries designated as a "significant users" to acquire a discharge permit through the state of Colorado. The City of Fort Lupton does not currently issue these permits. It is a requirement that any industry contact the Colorado Department of Public Health and environment treatment division to determine if a discharge permit is required. 
(Prior code 12-530-12; Ord. 96-698 §1; Ord. 2015-994 §50) 
Sec. 13-23. - Permit contents. 
    Required sewer permits shall be issued by the Planning and Development Department and shall state the name of the person to whom the permit is issued, the date of the permit, the size of the tap, the owner of the premises and the premises to be served by the sewer system. 
(Prior code 12-530-13; Ord. 96-698; Ord. 96-698; Ord. 2001-778) 
Sec. 13-24. - Taps. 
    All taps or connections to any part of the sewer utility shall be made in accordance with current City specifications and terms and conditions of the permit issued. All such taps and connections shall be made by a licensed plumber or the City's authorized representative, at the owner's expense, and all materials for such taps or connections shall be at the owner's expense and shall be inspected by the City prior to use. 
(Prior code 12-530-14; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 2015-994 §51) 
Sec. 13-25. - Separate connections required. 
    Two (2) or more premises cannot be served from one (1) and the same connection, nor can two (2) or more buildings on the same premises be served from one (1) and the same connection. All properties that require separate sewer service billings shall have their own connection and service line. 
(Prior code 12-530-15) 
Sec. 13-26. - Sewer rate schedules. 
(a)  Each user of the sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities shall be charged a monthly sewer user charge. Such charge shall be established, and amended from time to time, by written resolution of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board, and such amendments after January 1, 1997, shall be after publication and a minimum of two (2) public meetings, which amends the process described in Ordinance 95-675, Section 12-9 (2). 
(b)  For all metered residential, commercial and industrial users who irrigate lawn or other landscaping during the months of May through October, the sewer use charge on bills may be adjusted to reflect the average monthly water use reflected in the preceding January, February and March sewer billings (represents the usage of December, January and February); however, wastewater facility users obtaining the rate benefits of this Section may be required to submit to a review of their water use at such times as may be designated by the Operations Director. 
(c)  The Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board shall review the wastewater facilities' total annual costs of operation, maintenance, replacement and debt service at least once every year. Rates may be revised if necessary to generate revenue, combined with all other revenues of the utility, sufficient to pay all said costs. Such rates shall be established to proportionately recover all operation, maintenance and replacement costs from users of the wastewater facilities, including those costs associated with mitigating inefficiency, infiltration and inflow. 
(d)  From and after July 1, 1999, the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board may, notwithstanding any other provision of this Section, approve a negotiated rate or rates for sewer utility service for a large and/or unique user, taking into consideration the requirement of Subsection (c) above that such negotiated rates recover the operation and maintenance and replacement costs occasioned as a consequence of such user. Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection (a) above, any such negotiated rates shall be effective upon approval by the Utility Enterprise Board by majority vote. 
(Ord. 626 §1, 1992; Ord. 634 §1, 1992; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-698 §1; Ord. 99-739; Ord. 99-750, Part 1; Ord. 2009-909 §1) 
Sec. 13-27. - Sewer plant investment fees. 
(a)  All sewer plant investment fees shall be determined by the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. Such fees shall be established and amended from time to time by written resolution of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. 
(b)  Upon payment of the sewer plant investment fee, the Planning and Development Department shall issue a permit and allow a fee service line tap into the City's sewer system.
