(c)  The sewer plant investment fee shall be placed into the Sewer Plant Investment Fee Account. Said account shall be used for future improvements or additions to the sewer system and wastewater treatment facilities. 
(Prior code 12-530-27; Ord. 96-698 §1; Ord. 99-739; Ord. 2001-778) 
Sec. 13-28. - Nonmetered sewer accounts. 
    Services which are on well water and which are connected to the City's wastewater treatment system shall be billed for sewer consistent with regulations under Section 13-26. 
(Ord. 99-739) 
Secs. 13-29-13-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II - Drainage 

Sec. 13-41. - General purpose. 
    The drainage fee is hereby established for the purpose of raising funds for the construction, enlargement and maintenance of storm water drainage systems to assist in solving drainage problems caused or contributed to by development of property. The drainage fees shall be computed on the basis of the area of the property being developed and shall be applied to all newly developed property in the City limits. 
(Ord. 538 §1, 1985) 
Sec. 13-42. - Drainage facilities fee. 
    The fee imposed shall be calculated on the gross lot area of the real property being developed as determined by the Building Inspector. There shall be a minimum fee charge as set forth in the fee schedule. Construction of churches, public clinics and hospitals, schools and public structures shall be exempt from the drainage facilities fee. 
(Ord. 538 §2, 1985) 
Sec. 13-43. - Payment of drainage fees. 
(a)  The drainage fee or fees shall be paid at the time application is made for a building permit. Under no circumstances shall the Building Official issue a certificate of occupancy until the drainage facilities fee is paid in full. 
(b)  If more than one (1) building is to be constructed on the property being developed, as for example, in the case of a planned unit development or a planned residential unit, the total fees shall be allocated among the several buildings in proportion to the square footage of the buildings, and a pro rata portion of the drainage fees shall be paid as each application for a building permit is made. 
(Ord. 538 §3, 1985) 
Sec. 13-44. - Drainage fee schedule. 
    The fee schedule shall be set by resolution of the City Council and may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. 538 §4, 1985; Ord. 2000-762, Part 1; Ord. 2001-778) 
Sec. 13-45. - Storm water drainage fee. 
(a)  There is hereby created a storm water drainage fee to be assessed against residential and nonresidential utility customers in order to provide revenue to improve, repair and maintain the City's storm water drainage infrastructure. 
(b)  All nonresidential utility customers will be assessed on the square footage of flat area (nongreenbelt) of their property, and all residential customers will be assessed a flat fee established from the average size of their property using an ERU (equivalent residential unit). 
(c)  The fee rate shall be set by resolution of the Utility Enterprise Board and may be amended from time to time by resolution. The initial fee rate is set by Resolution 2007-005. 
(Ord. 2007-886) 
Secs. 13-46-13-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III - Water System and Water Treatment Facilities 

Sec. 13-61. - Creation of water system and water treatment facilities. 
    There is hereby created and established a water system and water treatment facilities for the purpose of management, maintenance, care and operation of the water system and water treatment facilities of the City. 
(Prior code 12-510-1; Ord. 96-698 §2) 
Sec. 13-62. - Powers of Operations Director; City Administrator. 
    The Operations Director shall have the immediate control and management of all things pertaining to the City waterworks system, and the Operations Director shall perform all acts necessary for the prudent, efficient and economical management and protection of said waterworks. The Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board shall have the power, by written resolution, to prescribe such other and further rules and rates as it may deem necessary. Technical services of a qualified engineer may be used in all cases wherein the Operations Director does not have the requisite engineering knowledge and experience to make decisions requiring such technical services. The City Administrator is authorized to promulgate regulations, guidelines and procedures, consistent with this Code adopted by the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board, as are reasonably necessary and appropriate to implement the rules and policies of the Board. 
(Prior code 12-510-2; Ord. 96-698 §2; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-63. - Receipts and deposits. 
    The Finance Director shall keep a correct account of all receipts and materials furnished to water users and shall collect the same and deposit the proceeds so collected to the credit of the Utility Enterprise Fund and in accordance with the policies of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. 
(Prior code 12-510-3; Ord. 96-698 §2; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-64. - Inspections; repairs. 
    Whenever the Operations Director deems it necessary, the Operations Director may inspect the condition of all pipes, motors, meters and water fixtures, or the manner in which the water is used. The Operations Director shall have the authority to make, or cause to be made, any repairs or alterations to the water user's service as the Operations Director deems reasonably necessary. The Operations Director shall be vigilant to protect and remedy all abuses, whether from waste or other improper use of water. 
(Prior code 12-510-5; Ord. 96-698 §2) 
Sec. 13-65. - Composition of water system and water treatment facilities. 
    All water and water rights, water mains and lines, water meters, water treatment plant, water storage, water pressure systems water wells and appurtenances thereto, machinery, equipment and supplies used by the City to supply its water users with water shall be known as the "Water System and Water Treatment Facilities"; provided however, that the water service line from the curb stop to the structure or property served shall be regarded as the property of the owner of said structure or property served. 
(Prior code 12-510-6; Ord. 96-698 §2) 
Sec. 13-66. - Control and operation of fire hydrants. 
(a)  All fire hydrants shall be a part of the City water systems. Every hydrant shall be tested at least annually. 
(b)  No person shall use or operate any hydrant or other valves on the City water system other than authorized City employees and members of the Fire Department for fire suppression purposes and which is accessible to any public highway, alley or private way open to or generally used by the public, unless such person first secures a permit for use from the Public Works Director and the City Administrator. 
(c)  Only wrenches specifically designed for operation of fire hydrants shall be used in said operation, and all other tools are strictly forbidden. 
(Prior code 12-510-7; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 2015-994 §52) 
Sec. 13-67. - Use of water; Operations Director to manage. 
    Users of water from a designated City fire hydrant shall be assessed a permit fee which shall be valid for a period of one (1) year. The user shall also be required to pay for water at the then-current rate. There shall be no charge for unmetered standby fire protection service the Fort Lupton Fire Protection District. The Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board reserves the right to cause the water to be shut off in the water mains when the Operation Director deems the shut off to be necessary. The Operations Director, for the purpose of repairing or making connections for extensions to the water system or water treatment facilities or for the purpose of cleaning the same, may shut off the water at any time; provided that before the water shall be turned off from any school or public building, the Operations Director shall notify the occupant or person in charge of such building; and in all cases of turn off for such repairs or connections not determined to be an emergency by the Operations Director, affecting industrial, commercial or residential buildings, the Operations Director shall notify the occupant or person in charge of such buildings. 
(Prior code 12-405-16; Ord. 96-698 §2; Ord. 99-739) 
Secs. 13-68-13-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV - Water Policies 

Sec. 13-81. - Damage to water system and water treatment facilities property prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to in any way damage property, equipment or appliances constituting a part of the water system and water treatment facilities. It shall be unlawful for any person to cast, place, dump or deposit any substance or material into the water system which will in any manner injure or obstruct the water or water treatment facilities system or pollute or contaminate the City water. 
(Prior code 12-510-8; Ord. 96-698 §3) 
Sec. 13-82. - Interference with water facilities prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass upon the property of the City to tap any water mains or to make any connections therewith, without first having obtained a permit to do so. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to in any manner interfere with the City or the property, equipment, pipes, valves or any other appliances of the City, or to change or alter the position of any valve or appliance regarding the flow of water in any pipeline. 
(Prior code 12-510-9) 
Sec. 13-83. - Change of water use. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to alter, change, enlarge or extend in any manner whatsoever the type of use for which water was taken and used from the water system and water treatment facilities, except as approved by the Operations Director. 
(Prior code 12-510-10; Ord. 96-698 §3) 
Sec. 13-84. - Connections to water lines and mains. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any connections with any water pipeline main which forms a part of the water system and water treatment facilities except pursuant to and in accordance with the permit required by this Article. It shall be unlawful to make any connections to any privately owned water mains or pipelines which are connected with the water utility or to change, alter or renew any presently existing private main or pipeline connected with the water utility with any pipe larger than that in use, unless approved by the Operations Director. 
(Prior code 12-510-11; Ord. 96-698 §3) 
Sec. 13-85. - Backflow prevention and cross connection control program. 
(a)  Purpose. 
(1)  The purpose of the Section and the Program adopted herein is to provide for the preservation and promotion of the public health, welfare and safety of the inhabitants of the City and of the public and for the preservation and promotion of the convenience, good order, tranquility, prosperity, happiness, morals, best interest and general welfare of said people. The intent is to protect the public water system from contaminants or pollutants that could enter the distribution system by backflow from a customer's water supply system through the service connection. 
(2)  The Fort Lupton Backflow Prevention and Cross Connection Control Program is designed to provide the City procedures for the implementation, maintenance and enforcement of backflow prevention practices pursuant to federal and state regulations pertaining to cross-connection control. 
(b)  Pursuant to Title 31, Article 16, Parts 1 and 2, C.R.S., there is hereby adopted by reference the Fort Lupton Backflow Prevention and Cross Connection Control Program, prepared and maintained by the City Public Works. The City Clerk shall certify to the passage of this Section and make one (1) copy of the adopted plan available to the public during regular business hours. 
(c)  Authority. The authority to implement this program is contained in the following statute, legislation and regulations and acts: 
(1)  Article 1-114 and Article 1-114.1 of Title 25 of the Colorado Revised Statutes (CRS). 
(2)  Section 39 of 5 CCR 1002-11, Colorado Primary Drinking Water Regulations. 
(3)  Colorado Plumbing Code. 
The Public Works Director shall have the authority to survey all service connections within the distribution system to determine if the connection is a cross-connection. 
The Public Works Director shall have the authority to control all service connections within the distribution system if the connection is a cross-connection. 
The Public Works Director shall maintain records of cross-connection surveys and the installation, testing and repair of all backflow prevention assemblies installed for containment and containment by isolation purposes. 
Except as otherwise provided herein, the Public Works Director shall administer, implement and enforce the provisions of this Ordinance. 
(d)  Applicability. This Ordinance applies to all commercial, industrial and multi-family residential service connections within the public water system and to any persons outside the City who are, by contract or agreement with the public water system, users of the public water system. This Ordinance does not apply to single-family-residential service connections unless the Public Works Director becomes aware of a cross connection at the single family connection. 
(e)  Requirements. 
(1)  Commercial, industrial and multi-family service connections shall be subject to a survey for cross connections. If a cross connection has been identified, an appropriate backflow prevention assembly and or method shall be installed at the customer's water service connection within one hundred twenty (120) days of its discovery. The assembly shall be installed downstream of the water meter or as close to that location as deemed practical by the Public Works Director. If the assembly or method cannot be installed within one hundred twenty (120) days the Public Works Director must take action to control or remove the cross connection, suspended service to the cross connection or receive an alternative compliance schedule from the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment. 
(2)  Backflow prevention assemblies and methods shall be installed in accordance with Chapter 3 of the City's Standards, the City's Construction Specifications and Colorado Plumbing Code. 
(3)  The Public Works Director shall require inspection, testing, maintenance and as needed repairs and replacement of all backflow prevention assemblies and methods, and of all required installations within the owner's plumbing system in the cases where containment assemblies and or methods cannot be installed. 
(4)  All costs for design, installation, maintenance, testing and as needed repair and replacement are to be borne by the customer. 
(5)  No grandfather clauses exist except for fire sprinkler systems where the installation of a backflow prevention assembly or method will compromise the integrity of the fire sprinkler system. 
(6)  For new buildings, all building plans must be submitted to the Public Works Director and approved prior to the issuance of water service. 
(f)  Inspection, Testing and Repair. 
(1)  Backflow prevention assemblies or methods shall be tested by a Certified Cross-Connection Control Technician upon installation and tested at least annually, thereafter. The tests shall be made at the expense of the customer. 
(2)  Any backflow prevention assemblies or methods that are non-testable, shall be inspected at least once annually by a certified cross-connection control technician. The inspections shall be made at the expense of the customer. 
(g)  Reporting and Recordkeeping. 
(1)  Copies of records of test reports, repairs and retests, or replacements shall be kept by the customer for a minimum of three (3) years. 
(2)  Copies of records of test reports, repairs and retests shall be submitted to the Public Works Director by mail, facsimile or e-mail by the testing company or testing technician. 
(h)  Right of entry. A properly credentialed representative of the Public Works Director shall have the right of entry to survey any and all buildings and premises for the presence of cross-connections for possible contamination risk to and for determining compliance with this section. This right of entry shall be a condition of water service in order to protect the health, safety and welfare of customers throughout the public water system's distribution system. 
(i)  Compliance. 
(1)  Customers shall cooperate with the installation, inspection, testing, maintenance, and as needed repair and replacement of backflow prevention assemblies and with the survey process. For any identified uncontrolled cross-connections, the Public Works Director shall complete one (1) of the following actions within one hundred twenty (120) days of its discovery: 
a.  Control the cross connection. 
b.  Remove the cross connection. 
c.  Suspend service to the cross connection. 
(2)  The Public Works Director shall give notice in writing to any owner whose plumbing system has been found to present a risk to the public waters system's distribution system through an uncontrolled cross connection. The notice and order shall state that the owner must install a backflow prevention assembly or method at each service connection to the owner's premises to contain the water service. The notice and order will give a date by which the owner must comply. 
a.  In instances where a backflow prevention assembly or method cannot be installed, the owner must install approved backflow prevention assemblies or methods at all cross-connections within the owner's water supply system. The notice and order will give a date by which the owner must comply. 
(j)  Violations and Penalties. Any violation of the provisions of this ordinance, shall, upon conviction be punishable as provided in all applicable statutes, laws, and regulations. 
(k)  Conflict with other codes. If a dispute or conflict arises between the Colorado Plumbing Code as adopted herein, and any plumbing, mechanical, building, electrical, fire or other code adopted by the State, then the most stringent provisions of each respective code shall prevail. 
(Ord. 2016-999 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. 2016-999 adopted June 6, 2016, repealed the former §13-85 and enacted a new §13-85 as set out herein. The former §13-85 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the prior code 12-544-1, 12-544-2, 12-544-4; and Ord. 2015-994 §53. 
Sec. 13-86. - Separate connections required. 
    Two (2) or more premises cannot be supplied from one (1) connection and the same connection nor can two (2) or more buildings on the same premises be supplied from one (1) and the same connection, unless provided with separate shut-off cocks located at the public street right-of-way line or easement. All properties that require separate water service billings shall have their own connection and service line with shut-off cocks and meter pit located at the public street right-of-way. 
(Prior code 12-510-15; Ord. 2015-994 §54) 
Sec. 13-87. - General policies for water service lines. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than a licensed plumber or the City's authorized representative to install a water service line from the main to the meter pit or curb stop. All service lines, corporation cocks, meter risers or curb stops shall be of material and size as specified in the current City's specifications. 
(b)  The service line from the meter pit or curb box to the structure served shall be installed, maintained and repaired by the water user at his or her expense. No claim shall be made against the City on account of breaking of service pipes or apparatus or for failure in the supply of water, and no reduction in the rates will be made for any time that service pipes or fixtures are frozen or are not in proper working order. All connections, taps and lines that are or will become the responsibility of the City for maintenance, shall be inspected by the City's authorized representative prior to being backfilled and used. 
(c)  The City shall be responsible for all maintenance and repairs to service pipes and fixtures installed between the City main and meter pit or curb box, whichever is closer to the City main. 
(d)  Cross-connections with any other water supply is strictly prohibited. 
(e)  The water service line from the street main to the water distribution system of the building to be served with water shall be of sufficient size to furnish an adequate flow of water to meet the requirements of the building and premises at peak demand and in no case shall be less than three-fourths (3/4) of an inch in diameter. 
(f)  New services to replace existing services shall not be approved by the City until the old service lines are completely disconnected from the curb stop or meter pit and the water is turned off at the corporation cock shut-off at the main and inspected by City staff. 
(Prior code 12-510-16; Ord. 99-739; Ord. 2015-992 §4; Ord. 2015-994 §55) 
Sec. 13-88. - Installation of lines. 
    All lines shall be installed in accordance with the current City specifications in effect at the time of installation. 
(Prior code 12-510-17; Ord. 2015-994 §56) 
Sec. 13-89. - Excavation and backfilling. 
    All excavation and backfilling in the street or alley shall be in conformity with current City specifications in effect at the time of work being done. 
(Prior code 12-510-18; Ord. 2015-994 §57) 
Sec. 13-90. - Installation prior to street paving. 
    Before any street containing a water line is paved, the City shall cause to be installed all service lines with meter pits or curb stops and meter risers, as the City determines necessary to serve said property when fully developed. 
(Prior code 12-510-19) 
Sec. 13-91. - Shut-off for repairs and extensions and mains. 
    The City reserves the right to shut off the water from any street main when necessary to make repairs or extensions of the water mains or to perform any other work necessary to maintain the water utility. Unless it is an emergency situation, the City will attempt to give reasonable notice to the water users. No claim shall be made against the City by reason of any breakage or service pipe or service cock, or for any other damage that may result from shutting off water for repairing or replacing mains, hydrants or other connections. 
(Prior code 12-510-20) 
Sec. 13-92. - Waste of water prohibited. 
    Consumers shall prevent unnecessary waste of water in all uses of water and keep all hydrants, appliances and fixtures in good repair. 
(Prior code 12-510-21; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-93. - Restrictions on sprinkling. 
    The use of water from the water utility for lawn sprinkling may be prohibited or restricted as determined by the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. A notice of such determination shall be published once in a newspaper circulated within the City. Upon publication of such notice, the prohibition or restriction shall become effective as stated, and any violator may be punished by penalties as provided in this Code. The setting of sprinklers or nozzles so as to interfere with traffic or sidewalks is prohibited. 
(Prior code 12-510-22; Ord. 96-698 §3) 
Sec. 13-94. - Authority during emergency situations. 
    In the event of a major fire, drought or other emergency that should require the immediate curtailment of the use of water, the City Administrator shall have the authority to make such restrictions as deemed necessary for the protection of the public. 
(Prior code 12-510-23; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-95. - Authority to turn water off or on. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than a duly employed person of the City to turn water on or off to any premises, lot, building or house, unless the turn-off or turn-on is made by a City authorized repair person with a City provided key, for leak or repair purposes, only. 
(Prior code 12-510-24; Ord. 96-698 §3) 
Sec. 13-96. - Supplying water to others. 
    No occupant or owner of any building or lot into which water is introduced will be allowed to supply water to other persons, families or firms, except as approved by the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board, or by the Operations Director in times of emergencies. The Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board agrees to furnish water for a specified sum. If, therefore, consumers furnish other people or supply water for animals, sprinkling, washing vehicles or for building purposes, or permit water to be taken without the knowledge and consent of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board, it is a violation of contract and consumers so offending will be required to pay double the price of water so used, and the Fort Lupton Utility Board reserves the right to shut off the supply for abuses of water privileges. When the water has been turned off for violation thereof, the water will not be turned on again until all water rent and penalties have been paid. 
(Prior code 12-510-25; Ord. 96-698 §3) 
Sec. 13-97. - Using water from another connection prohibited; additional fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any consumer to permit water to be taken through his or her service pipe for the use of any person whose premises are not connected for the use of water through the City's mains unless the consumer shall pay to the City one (1) additional minimum fee for each premises so accommodated, except as provided herein. 
(Prior code 12-405-14) 
Sec. 13-98. - Use outside City corporate limits. 
    Use of water outside the City corporate limits shall be prohibited, with the exception of the emergency water use required by the Fort Lupton Fire Protection District. 
(Prior code 12-510-26; Ord. 96-698 §3) 
Sec. 13-99. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or take water from the City waterworks without a permit therefor, to make any fraudulent representation for the purpose of obtaining water, to take or use water from the waterworks for a different purpose or purposes than provided for in the customer's permit, to willfully or unreasonably waste water, or to violate any of the regulations set forth in this Article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper or interfere with any meter or accessory to so arrange water service or piping that the use of water will not actuate the meter, or to draw water through any connection in a service line from a point between the water main and the meter. The cost of repairing bypass damage and any other damage to the water meter caused by the metered water user shall be borne by the user and added to and considered a part of the charge for water. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to interfere with any authorized personnel who are enforcing any of the terms or provisions of this Article or any other ordinance or resolution which may be enacted concerning the water system. 
(d)  No person shall make any tap or install any device or plumbing connection within the meter pit without written permission from the City. 
(e)  Lawn taps on service lines between the water main and the meters are prohibited. 
(f)  All water service facilities, including meters and reading devices required for water service, shall be subject to inspection by any duly authorized officer of the City at any and all reasonable times. It shall be unlawful to hinder or prevent such inspection. In the event of refusal on the part of any licensee or user of water to permit such inspection, the water service may be thereupon discontinued in addition to the user being subject to other penalty provisions of this Article. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful to irrigate lawns, gardens and areas outside buildings except during the time prescribed by resolution of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. It shall further be unlawful to violate any provision or restriction prescribed by said resolution. A finding by a duly authorized representative of the City of any violation as prescribed by written resolution of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board shall constitute presumptive evidence of a violation of this Section by the head of the household occupying the premises where such violation is found to occur. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder or prevent the duly authorized person of the City to inspect, investigate or have access to any property or information concerning any possible source of water contamination within the City, including water sources from surface water, irrigation ditches, water wells or any other source water from which such contamination is or may be introduced into the water supply of the City. 
(Prior code 12-510-27; Ord. 586 §4, 1990; Ord. 96-698 §3; Ord. 99-739; Ord. 2002-808) 
Sec. 13-100. - Tampering with any bypass prohibited. 
(a)  Unless specifically authorized by the City, it shall be unlawful for any person to adjust or tamper with any meter, or to install or use any bypass or other device whereby water may be drawn from a service pipe. 
(b)  After initial metering of existing taps by the City, all new meters shall be furnished and installed by the City and paid for by the developer, landowner or water user. Repair of meters shall be by the City or its contractor only, and at the cost to the water user, if the necessity for the repair or maintenance was caused by the water user. Type and placement of meters shall be controlled by the Operations Director. Two (2) feet of pipe is required for inside installation of a water meter. 
(Prior code 12-405-11; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-698 §3) 
Sec. 13-101. - Use of private wells. 
(a)  Any person now using or who shall hereafter use any private well for domestic or household use within the City shall, within ten (10) days from the effective date of the ordinance codified in this Code, or within ten (10) days from the commencement of use of such well, report such use to the City. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the owner of such well to have said well and the water therefrom examined by the County Department of Health within thirty (30) days from the effective date of the ordinance codified herein or, if such well is hereafter put in use, before using such well for household or domestic use, and to have said well so examined per County health regulations and forward a copy of all reports to the City within fifteen (15) days. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the owner of such well to file with the City Clerk a written report from the County Department of Health of each examination required by this Article. 
(d)  The provisions of Subsections (a), (b) and (c) above shall not be applicable to wells used exclusively for irrigation. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any private well to connect such well in such manner as to permit the water therefrom to enter any pipe connected with the public water mains of the City. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use any private well for domestic or household purposes after the waters from said well are found by the County Department of Health to be unsafe or injurious to health. 
(Prior code 12-230-1, 12-230-2, 12-230-3, 12-230-4, 12-230-5, 12-230-6, 12-230-7; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-102. - Duty of consumer. 
    It shall be the duty of the water consumer to use all necessary precaution to keep the meter from freezing and from injury, and if the meter shall be injured by freezing or by carelessness of the consumer, then the consumer shall pay all necessary costs of repairs occasioned by such injury, and failure to pay such costs of repair shall warrant and authorize the City in turning off the water. 
(Prior code 12-405-12) 
Sec. 13-103. - Pollution of water prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or cast any substance into any reservoir, well, trench, pipe or drain used in and necessary for the construction, maintenance or operation of the City waterworks system which may tend to fill up such reservoir or well, to obstruct the flow of water in such trench, pipe or drain, or to pollute the water therein. 
(Prior code 12-405-15) 
Sec. 13-104. - Regulations part of contract. 
    All regulations contained in this Article shall be considered a part of the contract of every person taking water from the waterworks of the City, and no person may be served with water from the water utility unless he or she agrees to and abides by all the rules and regulations of the City pertaining to the use of said water. 
(Prior code 12-510-28) 
Sec. 13-105. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this Article shall be subject to a fine as set forth in Section 1-72 of this Code. 
(b)  In addition, water service will be discontinued immediately to any user who violates the provisions of this Article until the user has paid all water fees and required repairs to the metering system. 
(Ord. 586 §5, 1990) 
Secs. 13-106-13-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V - Water Service 

Sec. 13-121. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this Article, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed hereafter: 
    Commercial and institutions means any nonresidential use of water. 
    Consumer means any person receiving water from the City waterworks. 
    Mains means the main pipes and connections forming a part of the City waterworks. 
    Service pipe means a branch pipe with its fittings and connections through which water is taken. 
    Street means any street, avenue, alley, lane or other thoroughfare. 
    Tap means an opening or connection in the mains through which water is taken. 
    Water plant investment fee means a fee charged for the privilege of connecting into the City's water system. 
(Prior code 12-405-2; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-698 §4) 
Sec. 13-122. - Statement of annexation / development water requirements. 
(a)  Any person annexing land to or developing within the City, or adding any new water taps within the City limits connecting to the City's water system, who has not previously made an adequate water dedication or cash-in-lieu-of-water fee payment or has had that requirement waived, shall make a cash-in-lieu-of-water payment in an amount as determined by the City or, as provided in Subsection (e) below, convey water rights or shares of sufficient quantity and water quality as determined by the City, free and clear of all liens and encumbrances. If water shares are to be tendered, they must meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Said water rights or shares will be of an amount to meet the annual water requirement of all the development or annexation as measured by the number and size of water meters. Raw water requirements per meter will be based on the schedule referenced in Subsection (d) below. 
(2)  In the event that the land to be annexed has no water rights or shares or has an amount of water rights or shares that is not sufficient to meet the requirement, an additional water dedication shall be made to the City to satisfy the requirements of this Section. 
(3)  The City Administrator shall determine a cash-in-lieu-of-water fee on a quarterly basis, or as needed, based upon the then-current market price for Colorado-Big Thompson (CBT) water shares. This will be done by contacting water brokers, water consultants and those with knowledge of current water prices. This cash-in-lieu-of-water fee will be used as the basis for assessing water dedications required for new water taps. 
(4)  The Utility Committee and the Planning Commission shall make recommendations to the City Council in all annexation proceedings on matters appropriate to their jurisdictions, specifically in the matters of the landowner's membership in the Northern Colorado Water Conservancy District and how the membership relates to the foregoing water requirement in this Section. 
(5)  The cash-in-lieu-of-water fee will be paid in full or water rights will be conveyed to the City prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
(b)  A customer request for an increase in water meter size will be granted upon payment of the difference in the cash-in-lieu-of-water fee for the meter size requested and the meter size existing at the time of the request. 
(c)  No refund shall be made to any customer for a decrease in size of water meter or abandonment of water service. In addition, water dedications shall remain with a tap and will not be decreased or transferred for any reason. 
(d)  The water dedication requirements schedule shall be established, and amended from time to time, by resolution of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board, to meet the needs of the City. 
(e)  The cash-in-lieu-of-water fee requirements may be suspended or modified, from time to time, by resolution of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board, to meet the needs of the City. 
(f)  For platted lots as of January 1, 1997, any person or entity not having established water service for any such lot prior to February 28, 2002, and not having a prior written agreement to do so, shall dedicate water shares as provided herein unless, by December 31, 2002: (1) preparation for water service has been made (i.e., tap fee purchased, water meter purchased); (2) the minimum monthly service fee begins to be and continues to be paid; and (3) by February 28, 2004, a building permit is applied and paid for to develop the property for industrial, commercial or residential use. Mere irrigation of the property does not constitute such use. If these three (3) criteria are met, the water dedication requirement shall be adjusted to be a cash-in-lieu fee paid by the applicant to the City equal to the difference between the base water share cost of eleven thousand dollars ($11,000.00) as of February 28, 2002, and the market rate as of the time of the building permit, if the cost of water shares exceeds eleven thousand dollars ($11,000.00) at that time. If it does not, there shall be no dedication fee. Failure to begin water service and develop the subject property as specified in the building permit within one (1) year of its issuance shall cause the water tap to be declared inactive and void. In such a case, the water tap fee and cash-in-lieu fee shall be returned to the applicant. None of the building permit fee shall be refunded. Water service shall not thereafter be provided to the property unless available from the City and an applicant meets all standard requirements then in effect when water service may later be requested. 
(Ord. 591 §1, 1990; Ord. 640 §1, 1993; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-693 §1; Ord. 96-698 §4; Ord. 99-739; Ord. 99-751; Ord. 2000-760, Part 1; Ord. 2001-778; Ord. 2002-798; Ord. 2004-841) 
Sec. 13-123. - Water tap permit required. 
(a)  No water tap shall be made on any water main or other portion of the waterworks of the City without first securing a permit therefor. The application for a water tap permit shall be made in writing upon a form furnished by the Planning and Development Department and shall state clearly the tap size, address and name of the person applying for the tap, the owner of the premises and any other information which the Operations Director may reasonably require. 
(b)  All water tap permits shall be issued for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days in the same manner as building permits are issued. 
(Prior code 12-405-3; Ord. 96-698 §4; Ord. 2001-778) 
Sec. 13-124. - Water plant investment fee. 
(a)  All water plant investment fees shall be determined by the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. Such fees shall be established, and amended from time to time, by written resolution of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. 
(b)  Upon payment of a Water Investment Fee, the Planning and Development Department shall issue a permit and allow to connect a service line tap into the City's water system. 
(c)  The water plant investment fee shall be placed into the Water Plant Investment Fee Account. Said account shall be used for future improvements or additions to the water system and water treatment facilities, including capital additions or acquisitions of water for the City. 
(d)  In the addition of a building or structure which adds a complete living unit in the case of a multifamily residence, or which adds pads to a mobile home court, or which adds rooms or apartments to an apartment house or any addition not listed herein which adds any plumbing fixtures, there shall be required the additional payment of an extension charge to be computed according to the water plant investment fee schedule. 
(Prior code 12-405-3, 12-405-4; Ord. 96-698 §4; Ord. 99-739; Ord. 2001-778) 
Sec. 13-125. - Inside City water line modifications. 
    The City recognizes its responsibilities as related to water service to existing, developed, platted property within the City which is already served by water mains and fire hydrants which may be inadequate for conformance with sound engineering and public safety standards. When necessity arises for enlarging, replacing or otherwise upgrading the water distribution system in an existing, platted, developed area already served by the City water, the improvements will be made by the City. If such improvements are made necessary by the development of a new subdivision which is to be served by a water main passing through an area described above, then the City will require the developer to negotiate a participation agreement with the City for the cost of the improvements. 
(Prior code 12-405-17; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-126. - Inside City main extensions; individual. 
    For an individual property owner desiring water service on an undeveloped, unplatted area of the City, where City water mains do not exist, the City's policy will be the same for the individual as for a subdivision in the same circumstance. 
(Prior code 12-405-18) 
Sec. 13-127. - Oversizing; City participation. 
    If the size line required to serve a subdivision or individual is smaller than the size line the City wishes installed for sound future planning, then the City will participate in the oversizing of the pipe from a minimum of six (6) inches to the size the City desires to be installed. 
(Prior code 12-405-19; Ord. 645 §1. 1993) 
Sec. 13-128. - Building occupied by more than one tenant; owner to pay. 
    Owners or agents in charge of business blocks or other buildings occupied by more than one (1) tenant using water from the same service pipe shall be required to pay the water rate for the whole of such buildings. 
(Prior code 12-405-13) 
Sec. 13-129. - Water service for individuals. 
    Any individual desiring an extension of the City water system to serve his or her property shall pay the entire cost of extending the City water service to his or her property and shall deed to the City all water lines and improvements necessary to extend the service to his or her property. The City shall pay the cost of any oversize pipe which the City requires to serve any individual property as a result of any master plan which is adopted by the City for water service within or outside of the existing City limits. All extensions shall conform to City specifications. 
(Prior code 12-405-10) 
Sec. 13-130. - Water service for subdivisions. 
(a)  The developer of any subdivision desiring water service from the City shall pay the entire cost of extending the City water service to his or her subdivision and shall deed to the City all mains and service connections required to serve his or her subdivision. The City shall pay the difference pursuant to Section 13-127 for any oversize pipe which is required as a result of any master plan adopted by the City for service of water to any area either within or outside of the existing City limits. All extensions shall conform to City specifications. 
(b)  For subdivisions inside or outside the City limits, the City's main extension policy shall be as follows: 
(1)  The City will extend or require the subdivider to extend the required water main to the subdivision to be served. If the subdivider is required to extend the main, then the City will negotiate a repayment agreement with the subdivider which will allow said subdivider to recoup as much of the cost of the extension between the boundary of his or her subdivision and the nearest properly sized City water main as can be agreed upon. It shall be the City's policy that the subdivider shall pay for the extensions of any water line for his or her subdivision. 
(2)  In the event no agreement can be made between the City and the subdivider, then the City shall not be responsible to extend the main. 
(Prior code 12-405-9; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-131. - Water and sewer billing and collection. 
(a)  Statements for the charges of water services will be dated and mailed out to the water users monthly no later than fourteen (14) days after the water meter read date. In the event a water bill is not paid by the end of the following month in which it was sent, the Finance Director or City's agents shall serve upon or mail the water user a delinquent notice in writing, giving a minimum of ten (10) days from the date of the notice for payment to be made or the water will be turned off on the premises served. In the event such bill is not paid by the due date given on this notice, the Finance Department or City's agents shall be authorized to cause the turn-off of the water service forthwith on the premises served until the delinquent bill has been paid, together with any service charges, plus any exceptional costs. 
(b)  The City shall have as security for the collection of such water utility charges, service charges and fees, a lien upon the real property served, which lien shall become effective immediately upon the supplying of such water and shall not be discharged until all charges for water service, service charges and fees as provided herein have been paid. 
(c)  In the event the lien provided in Subsection (b) above is not discharged by payment, the Finance Director is authorized by City Council and the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board to collect such delinquent charges for water service, service charges and fees, and charge such collected amounts in the same manner as taxes, pursuant to Section 31-15-302, C.R.S. 
(d)  Alternately, upon the election of the City Council, proceedings may be instituted for the collection of amounts due by the County Treasurer pursuant to Section 31-20-105, C.R.S. 
(e)  In the event of any collection process, the City shall also be entitled to collect from the water user or the property owner all attorney's fees and costs incurred in the collection process. 
(f)  The City Administrator is authorized to resolve billing disputes and adjust any customer's utility bill for good reason and consistent with this Code. A copy of any adjustment so made shall be sent to the Water and Sewer Advisory Committee and the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board with an explanation. 
(Ord. 574 §1, 1989; Ord. 615 §1, 1991; Ord. 96-698 §4; Ord. 99-739; Ord. 2014-973 §1) 
Sec. 13-132. - Water meter requirements and provisions for costs. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the policy of the City Council and the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board to require the installation of water meters for all newly constructed buildings and/or other new uses requiring water so that all new connections to the City water system will be equipped with outside water meters. 
(b)  The cost of the meters and all necessary accessories, including labor, shall be at the expense of the developer, property owner or water user. 
(c)  All new connections shall have a main meter for each tap, regardless of the number of structures, units or persons to be served by that tap. In addition to the main meter, for each separate unit receiving water service from a single tap, if it is desired to set up more than one (1) account for billing purposes, separate service lines from the main meter and a separate meter on each such service line must be installed for each account desired. 
(d)  Services which are on City water but not on City sewer shall be metered and shall be charged for the actual water used. All such services shall not pay any sewer-related charges but shall pay any applicable water base fees. 
(Ord. 586 §1, 1990; Ord. 96-698 §4; Ord. 99-739; Ord. 2001-778; Ord. 2015-994 §58) 
Sec. 13-133. - Water meter maintenance, installation and records. 
(a)  All meters and accessories are the property of the City and shall be maintained by the City, and may be tested or inspected as deemed necessary. If any meter is repaired or replaced because of a defect in the meter, such repair or replacement due to obsolescence shall be performed at the expense of the City. If a meter is repaired or replaced due to damage other than damage caused by the City personnel, the cost of repair or replacement, including materials and labor, shall be charged to the user's account. If a meter is replaced due to a change by the user to a larger size meter, such replacement shall be performed at the expense of the user. 
(b)  All meters, readouts, pits and other materials shall be of a size, type, design and quality approved by the City and shall be installed in a readily accessible location for the meter reader. Each meter shall be inspected and found to be correct and properly adjusted before installation. 
(c)  Water meters shall be installed in an outside meter pit with a remote reading device at a location specified by the City. The City shall have the right to specify the location for the placement of the meter and readout. 
(d)  A record shall be made and preserved of each meter installed, giving the location, serial number and size of the meter. 
(Ord. 586 §2, 1990; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-134. - Connection and inspection. 
(a)  The owner of property for which a building permit has been issued shall notify the Operations Director when ready to connect to the water system so all installations can be properly inspected. 
(b)  In new subdivisions, water service lines shall be extended from the water main to the meter pit or curb stop for all new taps to enable street improvements to be completed. All water plant investment fees shall be paid before water service is provided. 
(Ord. 586 §3, 1990; Ord. 96-698 §4) 
Sec. 13-135. - Water meter readings. 
(a)  The schedule of water rates shall be applied to water used or consumed as determined by the water meter readings which are made by the City. 
(b)  The schedule of water rates shall be applied to water used or consumed as determined by the water meter readings which are made by the City. 
(c)  Water meters are to be read to the nearest one thousand (1,000) gallons, thus any meter containing a portion of one thousand (1,000) gallons should be rounded off to the nearest one thousand (1,000) gallons. 
(Prior code 12-405-7) 
Sec. 13-136. - Water rate schedules. 
(a)  Each user of the water system and water treatment facilities shall be charged a monthly user charge. Such charge shall be established, and amended from time to time, by written resolution of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board, and such amendments after January 1, 1997, shall be after publication and a minimum of two (2) public meetings, which amends the process described in Ordinance 95-675, Section 12-9 (2). 
(b)  The Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board shall review the water facilities' total annual costs of operation, maintenance, replacement and debt service at least once every year. Rates may be revised if necessary to generate revenue, combined with all other revenues of the utility, sufficient to pay all said costs. Such rates shall be established to proportionately recover all operation, maintenance and replacement costs from users of the water facilities, including those costs associated with mitigating inefficiency and line loss. 
(c)  From and after July 1, 1999, the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board may, notwithstanding any other provision of this Section, approve a negotiated rate or rates for water utility service for a large and/or unique user from the City's municipal well water system only, taking into consideration the requirement of Subsection (b) above that such negotiated rates recover the operation and maintenance and replacement costs occasioned as a consequence of such user. Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection (a) above, any such negotiated rates shall be effective upon approval by the Utility Enterprise Board by majority vote. 
(Ord. 631 §1, 1992; Ord. 96-698; Ord. 99-739; Ord. 99-750, Part 2; Ord. 2009-909 §2) 
Sec. 13-137. - Water plant investment fees. 
    All plant investment fees shall be determined by the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. Such fees may be established, and amended from time to time, by written resolution of the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board. 
(Prior code 12-510-30; Ord. 96-698 §4) 
Sec. 13-138. - Water use outside corporate limits. 
    Consistent with other Code provisions, the City shall not serve users outside of the City corporate limits. 
(Prior code 12-309-4, 12-309-5; Ord. 645 §1, 1993) 
Sec. 13-139. - Application for water service. 
    Application for water service shall be made to the Finance Department by the owner, occupier, developer or agent of the property to be benefited and must designate the location of the property, size of taps, location of taps and service line, the owner of the property and state the purpose for which the water is required, and any other information the Operations Director deems reasonably appropriate. 
(Prior code 12-510-4; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-698 §4; Ord. 2001-778) 
Sec. 13-140. - Types of permits. 
    There shall be the following types of permits to make connections with the water system and water treatment facilities: 
(1)  Permit to connect to the water utility for the purpose of taking and using water for normal municipal purposes, that is, domestic, commercial or industrial. At the time this permit is granted, the plant investment fee in effect at the time of application, together with all other costs associated with the granting of permission to take and use water from the utility, shall be paid. 
(2)  Permit to enlarge or replace an existing tap to the water utility for the purpose of taking and using water for normal municipal purposes, that is, domestic, commercial and industrial. At the time the permit is granted, the additional plant investment fee, if any, shall be paid. 
(Prior code 12-510-12; Ord. 510 §12, 1983; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-698 §4) 
Sec. 13-141. - Permit contents. 
    Permits required shall be issued by the Planning and Development Department and shall state the name of the person to whom the permit is issued, the date of the permit, the size of the tap, the owner of the property, corporation cock and water service line and the premises upon which the water is to be used, and any other information the Operations Director deems reasonably appropriate. 
(Ord. 510 §13, 1983; Ord. 96-698 §4; Ord. 2001-778) 
Sec. 13-142. - Taps. 
    All taps or connections to any part of the water utility shall be made in accordance with current City specifications, terms and conditions of the permit issued. All such taps and conditions shall be made by a licensed plumber or the City's authorized representative, at the owner's expense, and all materials for such taps or connections shall be at the owner's expense and shall be inspected by the City prior to use. 
(Prior code 12-510-14; Ord. 2015-994 §59) 
Sec. 13-143. - Procedure for suspension of water and/or sewer service. 
(a)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in Section 13-131 herein, water or sewer utility service may be suspended for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Noncompliance with any rule, regulation or ordinance with respect to the municipal water and sewer system; 
(2)  Performance of any act prohibited in this Section; 
(3)  Failure to pay proper water or sewer rates, fees, tolls or charges, or other water or sewer assessments when due; or 
(4)  Noncompliance with the terms of a permit for water or sewer service. 
(b)  Written notice of a proposed suspension of service shall be mailed to the last known address of the customer as shown on City records, and a notice shall also be mailed to the owner or occupant at the address for the property to which service is being supplied or at which premises the cause for suspension arose, if the premises address differs from the address to which billings are sent. Said notice shall include the following: 
(1)  Notification that water and/or sewer service will be suspended on the date specified in the notice, which date shall be no sooner than ten (10) working days after the date of mailing of the notice; 
(2)  The reasons for suspension of service; 
(3)  An advisory to the owner or occupant that, if the owner or occupant does not believe reasonable causes exist for the proposed suspension, the owner or occupant may have a hearing with the City Administrator prior to suspension; and 
(4)  The City telephone number to be called to request a hearing. 
(c)  Upon request of the owner or occupant received within the five-day period above specified, a hearing will be immediately scheduled with the City Administrator. If no hearing is requested or payment of delinquent charges has not been made, or if the City Administrator finds that other reasonable cause still exists for suspension prior to 12:00 p.m. on the date specified in the notice, water or sewer service, as the case may be, shall be suspended and shall not be reinstated until the cause for suspension has been cured. Prior to reinstatement of service to the premises, all charges due, including disconnection and reinstatement charges referred to in this Article, shall be paid. 
(d)  Appeals. Any appeal from the decision of the City Administrator with respect to suspension of service shall be submitted in writing to the Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board within twenty (20) working days from the date of the City Administrator's decision. Such an appeal shall set forth with particularity the grounds therefor. Notwithstanding such appeal, service shall be or remain suspended unless the appeal is accompanied by: 
(1)  A payment of the amount in dispute; or 
(2)  An amount determined as being sufficient to insure continued compliance with all applicable ordinances, rules and regulations, which amount shall be specified in the City Administrator's decision. 
(e)  The Fort Lupton Utility Enterprise Board shall review the proceedings before the City Administrator and, within twenty (20) working days after receipt of the appeal, shall enter the Board's written ruling based thereon, a copy of which ruling shall be sent by certified mail to the owner or occupant. In the event the decision is adverse to the owner or occupant, all administrative recourse in connection with the suspension of service shall be deemed to have been exhausted, and the owner or occupant may thereupon pursue such further remedy as the owner or occupant may choose. 
(Prior code 12-430-22; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-698 §4; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-144. - Customer complaint procedures. 
    Any owner or occupant having any complaint with respect to conduct or action of any employee of the City in connection with operation of the municipal water and sewer systems or in connection with administration or implementation of any ordinance, rule, regulation or policy related to the operation of said system, with the exception of termination of service for any of the reasons specified in Section 13-143 above, may submit a written complaint to the City Administrator, outlining in detail the basis of said complaint. The City Administrator shall make such investigation as may appear necessary and shall enter a written ruling with respect to the complaint. A copy of such ruling shall be mailed to the complaining owner or occupant by certified mail within twenty (20) working days from the date of receipt of the complaint. In the event the ruling of the City Administrator is adverse to the owner's or occupant's contentions, the owner's or occupant's administrative remedy shall be deemed to have been exhausted and the customer may thereupon pursue such other remedy as he or she may choose. 
(Prior code 12-430-23; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-698; Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-145. - Water leaks. 
    Inasmuch as it is to the benefit of the entire community to conserve water, a property owner who provides proof that they fixed a water leak on their property in a prompt and timely manner may receive a credit adjustment on their next utility bill consistent with regulations under Section 13-135. It is the intent of this policy that the City will share in the cost of the excess water in order to encourage the property owner to fix any water leaks in a timely fashion. 
(Ord. 99-739) 
Sec. 13-146. - Inactivation and termination of water and sewer services. 
(a)  An account will be considered active if the water curb stop is turned on by the City. An account will be considered inactive if the curb stop is turned off by the City for any reason. 
(b)  Upon request by the customer, the City will temporarily disconnect the premises from water service. A fifteen-dollar reconnect fee will be charged upon reconnection. The monthly base service charge for both water and sewer shall continue to accrue during the period of temporary disconnection. 
(c)  Water and sewer services may be inactivated for a period not exceeding five (5) consecutive years by the City upon written request of the owner, provided that the property is not occupied and all outstanding water and sewer fees have been paid at the time the tap is requested to be inactivated. During inactivation, there will be no water flow to the property for any purpose, nor any discharge to the sewer. If the property owner, at any time during the five-year inactive period, desires to reactivate the water and sewer tap, he or she must pay any base fees that accrued during said period before the City will allow the account to be reactivated. Property owners with active water and sewer services who abandon their property without properly requesting to inactivate their account will continue to accrue base fees until the City suspends water and sewer service pursuant to Section 13-143. 
(d)  The City may terminate water and sewer services and disconnect the water and sewer tap connections to any structure where the owner evidences in writing an intent to abandon the service connection. Selling the property to another is not sufficient intent for abandonment. Prior to a determination by the City that a water or sewer service connection is abandoned by the owner, the owner shall be provided a hearing with the City Administrator, at the owner's request. The City Administrator may determine, based upon the evidence present at such hearing, that a water or sewer tap should not be terminated, upon payment by the property owner of any fee, charge or cost identified below. 
(e)  Unless there is a separate, prior written agreement, any application for an enlargement, change in use classification or reactivation of an inactive connection pursuant to Subsection (d) above shall constitute a new connection, and all applicable water rights and requirements fees, water or sewer tap fees and charges associated with the then-current City ordinances shall fully apply. For platted lots as of January 1, 1997, any person or entity not having established water service for any such lot prior to February 28, 2002, and not having a prior written agreement to do so, shall dedicate water shares as provided herein unless, by December 31, 2002: (1) preparation for water service has been made (i.e., tap fee purchased, water meter purchased); (2) the minimum monthly service fee begins to be and continues to be paid; and (3) by February 28, 2004, a building permit is applied and paid for to develop the property for industrial, commercial or residential use. Mere irrigation of the property does not constitute such use. If these three (3) criteria are met, the water dedication requirement shall be adjusted to be a cash-in-lieu fee paid by the applicant to the City equal to the difference between the base water share cost of eleven thousand dollars ($11,000.00) as of February 28, 2002, and the market rate as of the time of the building permit, if the cost of water shares exceeds eleven thousand dollars ($11,000.00) at that time. If it does not, there shall be no dedication fee. Failure to begin water service and develop the subject property as specified in the building permit within one (1) year of its issuance shall cause the water tap to be declared inactive and void. In such a case, the water tap fee and cash-in-lieu fee shall be returned to the applicant. None of the building permit fee shall be refunded. Water service shall not thereafter be provided to the property unless available from the City and an applicant meets all standard requirements then in effect when water service may later be requested. 
(Ord. 99-739; Ord. 2001-778; Ord. 2002-798) 
Sec. 13-147. - Additional charges. 
(a)  There shall be charged and added to the water and sewer utility bill a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) each time a municipal water user or his or her agent requests that the City turn on and restore municipal water service that has been turned off at the request of or by the water user or his or her agent. Said fee shall be charged at the time the water service is turned on and shall be added to the user's water bill. During the period that a municipal water user's service is turned off, said municipal water user shall be responsible for the payment of the monthly base service charge for water and sewer service, including irrigation meters. 
(b)  Water service may be discontinued upon request by the owner, lessee or user of water. The City may require an affidavit signed by the owner, lessee or user prior to shut-off. The affidavit shall include the service address, reason for the shut-off request and whether the property is owner occupied, tenant occupied or vacant. Water shall not be discontinued if the reason for the requested shut-off is related to a landlord-tenant dispute. If the shut-off is granted, there shall be a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) to restore the water service. 
(c)  Every time a water service employee takes a reading of the meter, other than the normal monthly reading, there shall be a charge of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(d)  If a customer requests a meter check, high consumption check, leak check or reports a frozen meter yoke, the customer will not be charged for the first service call in a calendar year. The customer will be charged fifteen dollars ($15.00), on the water bill, each time thereafter. 
(e)  An emergency turn-off due to a water leak in the service line will not be charged a turn-off fee, but the customer will be charged a fifteen-dollar turn-on fee, on the utility bill, if the City turns on the water. 
(f)  Users of water from a designated City fire hydrant shall be assessed a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) permit fee which shall be valid for a period of one (1) year. The permit shall list the party taking the water, the main place of business address and the purpose for taking the water and specific location of hydrant used. The user shall also be required to pay for water taken at the current water rate. In the event any quantity charges remain unpaid sixty (60) days after the completion of the project, the user shall not be permitted to use Fort Lupton municipal water again until all outstanding amounts have been paid, and all remedies available at law shall be pursued to collect the unpaid water taken. All users of water from fire hydrants shall apply for a hydrant meter from the City and supply their own backflow prevention equipment, or may use a water meter provided by the City after payment of a one thousand five hundred dollar ($1,500.00) deposit. Any costs for damage to the water meter will be deducted from the deposit. 
(g)  There shall be no charge for unmetered standby fire protection service to the Fort Lupton Fire Protection District, but the Fire Department shall report the quantity used to the Finance Department on a monthly basis. 
(h)  Users of water for new construction shall be assessed a twenty-five-dollar fee, per month, to cover costs of water used during the time of construction, excluding the use of water for seeding or sodding a lawn. This policy authorizes use of water only for the building for which the permit is issued. Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be charged and collected at the time a building permit is issued. The charge shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per month thereafter, with no proration of days, until the water meter is installed and turned on. The remaining amounts due shall be paid prior to the issuance of the certificate of occupancy. A water meter shall be installed prior to outside seeding or sodding to measure and bill the owner for the actual water usage. 
(Ord. 99-739; Ord. 2015-994 §60) 
Secs. 13-148-13-160. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 15 - Annexation 
ARTICLE I - Annexation Procedures 

Sec. 15-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this Chapter is to establish a procedure to bring land under the jurisdiction of the City in compliance with the Colorado Municipal Annexation Act of 1965, as amended. This Chapter also provides standards for annexation and for compliance with other provisions of this Code. 
(Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 15-2. - Responsibilities of applicant. 
(a)  In addition to other duties imposed upon all applicants by this Code and the Colorado Municipal Annexation Act of 1965, as amended (the "Act"), all applicants shall have the following responsibilities: 
(1)  The applicant is responsible for having a representative at all meetings of the Planning Commission and of the City Council where the request is reviewed. Failure to have a representative present will be cause to have the item withdrawn from the agenda of that meeting. 
(2)  The applicant shall consult with the Planning Department to discuss any special conditions pertaining to the annexation and to obtain an annexation petition and application materials. 
(b)  All fees for all annexation applications shall be as shown in the "City of Fort Lupton General Fee Schedule" as adopted and revised by resolution by the City Council. 
(Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 96-692 §1; Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 15-3. - Annexation policy. 
(a)  The City Council shall have the sole discretion in the annexation of territory proposed for annexation to the City, and the City is under no obligation to approve any annexation petition. 
(b)  Land to be annexed shall conform to the goals, policies and strategies of the City. 
(c)  The petitioner for annexation of land to the City shall be responsible for paying all required fees and for all related costs and overhead incurred by the City in reviewing and processing the annexation petition. 
(d)  Annexation shall not divide tracts of land in such a way as to prevent annexation of adjoining land. 
(e)  All annexations shall be accompanied by an agreement between the petitioner and the City, stating conditions related to municipal services or other terms of annexation that are not specifically provided for in the Code. 
(f)  Unless specifically deferred by the City Council, zoning of the property shall occur concurrently with the annexation. Proposed zoning shall conform to a concept land use plan submitted with the annexation petition. In the event that sufficient planning has not been done to define zoning boundaries at the time of annexation, the City may zone the property "A," Agricultural, as an interim zoning classification. 
(g)  In accordance with this Code, sufficient water rights shall be deeded to the City at the time of annexation unless alternate provisions are approved in the annexation agreement. 
(h)  Required contiguity of noncontiguous parcels proposed for annexation may be achieved by annexation of one (1) or more portions of street right-of-way or other public way, a process commonly referred to as "flagpole" annexation. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 15-4. - Summary of the annexation process. 
(a)  Preapplication meeting with the Planning Department. 
(b)  Annexation application and petition, concept land use plan and zoning application. 
(c)  City review of application and feasibility of the annexation. 
(d)  Preliminary negotiation of the annexation agreement. 
(e)  Resolution of substantial compliance and public hearing date. 
(f)  Notice and referrals. 
(g)  Planning Commission public hearing and recommendation. 
(h)  City Council public hearing and ordinance on annexation, zoning and annexation agreement. 
(i)  Recording of annexation map, ordinance and annexation agreement. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 15-5. - Annexation process. 
(a)  Landowners considering annexation shall meet with representatives of the Planning Department prior to submitting any annexation request for the purpose of reviewing the City's requirements, obtaining annexation application materials and beginning discussion of the terms of an annexation agreement. 
(b)  Application. The applicant shall submit to the City the annexation petition and land use application materials. Complete annexation applications shall include the following: 
(1)  Annexation petition in a form provided by the City, signed by one hundred percent (100%) of the owners of the property being annexed. 
(2)  Completed land use application form. 
(3)  Completed annexation application. 
(4)  Two (2) full-size paper copies and fifteen (15) eleven-by-seventeen-inch paper reductions of the annexation map. 
(5)  A completed application for zoning the property being annexed in conformance with the requirements of this Code for amending the official zoning map. 
(6)  Two (2) full-size paper copies and fifteen (15) eleven-by-seventeen-inch paper reductions of a concept land use plan for the property, generally showing the anticipated land uses for the property being annexed. 
(7)  Required annexation fees and a deposit in an amount specified by the City for the cost of reviewing and processing the application. 
(8)  The following supportive information that will enable City staff to evaluate the impacts of the annexation on the City: 
a.  Soils description and limitation. 
b.  A statement of any known hazards and other important environmental conditions present on the property. 
c.  Preliminary utility plan. 
d.  One (1) set of No. 10 envelopes, stamped with first-class postage, with the City's address as the return address, addressed to owners of property located within five hundred (500) feet of the property proposed for annexation. Also, a statement by the applicant, indicating the source of all addresses provided. 
e.  In the case of "flagpole" annexations, a separate set of stamped, addressed envelopes for owners of all property adjoining the public way proposed to achieve contiguity, and a statement of the source of the addresses. 
f.  An affidavit concerning the amount and historical use of all water rights owned. 
g.  A vicinity map with a one-and-one-half-mile radius, at a minimum scale of one (1) inch represents two thousand (2,000) feet. 
h.  A statement on community need for proposed annexation and zoning. 
i.  For all annexations in excess of ten (10) acres, a statement from the school district governing the area to be annexed of the effect of the annexation upon the school district, including an estimate of the number of students generated by the proposed annexation and the capital construction required to educate such students. 
j.  A draft annexation impact report, conforming to the requirements of this Chapter. 
(c)  The Planning Department shall review all documents submitted for completeness and accuracy. The applicant shall be notified within a reasonable time of any deficiencies and provided an opportunity to correct such deficiencies. If all documents are complete and accurate, the Planning Department shall submit the annexation petition to the City Clerk. 
(d)  The City Clerk shall present the annexation petition and a resolution determining substantial compliance with the Act and initiating annexation proceedings to the City Council. 
(e)  The City Council shall, at a regular or special meeting, consider whether the petition is in substantial compliance with applicable provisions of the Act. 
(1)  If the petition is found to be in substantial compliance with the Act, the City Council may, by adoption of a resolution of substantial compliance, set the annexation and zoning for public hearing as provided in the Act. 
(2)  If the property proposed for annexation is contiguous with the City, the date of public hearing should be set to provide sufficient time for notice and hearing by the Planning Commission in advance of the City Council hearing. 
(3)  If the property proposed for hearing is only contiguous with the City via annexation of a street right-of-way or other "flagpole," the date of the City Council public hearing shall be not less than sixty (60) days after the date of approval of the resolution of substantial compliance. 
(4)  If the petition is found to not be in compliance with the Act, no further action shall be taken, except that such findings shall be made by resolution of the City Council. 
(f)  Upon establishment of a City Council public hearing date, the Planning Department shall schedule a public hearing on the annexation and zoning by the Planning Commission. 
(g)  Notice. Upon the establishment of a City Council public hearing date, the City Clerk shall give appropriate notice in accordance with the Act and with this Code. 
(1)  The City Clerk shall send copies of the annexation petition and the resolution of substantial compliance by certified mail to the Clerk of the Weld County Board of County Commissioners and to the County Attorney. 
(2)  Not less than twenty-five (25) days prior to the City Council public hearing, the City Clerk shall send copies of the annexation petition and the resolution by certified mail to any school district or special district having territory within the annexed area. 
(3)  Using the mailing list provided by the applicant, the City Clerk shall send a summary of the petition and a notice of the scheduled Planning Commission and City Council public hearings by first-class mail to owners of land within five hundred (500) feet of the property proposed for annexation. 
(4)  In the event of a "flagpole" annexation, and using the mailing list provided by the applicant, the City Clerk shall send a summary of the petition and a notice of the scheduled Planning Commission and City Council public hearings by first-class mail to owners of land contiguous with the public way being used to achieve contiguity, and advising such owners of their rights under the Act to petition for annexation. 
(5)  Posting. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the Planning Commission and City Council public hearings, the applicant shall post the property with a notice of the hearings as required by the Planning Department. Posting shall consist of at least one (1) sign facing and clearly legible from and within fifty (50) feet of each adjacent public street. These notices shall be in the form of signs measuring not less than three (3) feet by four (4) feet, with lettering a minimum of three (3) inches high and on posts no less than four (4) feet above the ground. Signs shall contain the following language, and shall include scheduled hearing dates: 
PUBLIC NOTICE 
A land use application is under review 
by the City of Fort Lupton.
