(2)  Construction/development sign. One (1) per development, during construction or major modification, not to exceed thirty-two (32) square feet, maximum eight (8) feet in height, minimum ten (10) feet from any property line, and nonilluminated. 
(3)  On-premises directional signs. Shall not exceed two (2) square feet and will not be placed to interfere with vision. 
(4)  Garage and yard sale signs. Posting of garage and yard sale signs shall be limited to three (3) days prior to the sale and shall be removed the following day. No sign shall be posted on any public right-of-way. Notwithstanding any provision of this Article to the contrary, off-premises garage and yard sale signs are allowed if placed on private property with the express permission of the property owner or lessee. 
(5)  Holiday decorations. Temporary decorations or displays associated with the holiday season which shall conform to health, safety, fire and building codes. 
(6)  Political signs. Shall be allowed on private property only for a period of ninety (90) days prior to and ten (10) days following a national, state, city or local governmental election. No single sign shall exceed thirty-two (32) square feet of area on any one (1) face, and the aggregate area of all political signs on one (1) lot shall not exceed fifty (50) square feet. Political signs not removed after ten (10) days following such election shall be in violation of this Article. No political sign shall be erected or placed on public rights-of-way, parks, alleys or other public areas. 
(7)  Real estate signs. Signs shall not be illuminated, shall not exceed six (6) square feet per face in total area in residential zones and shall not exceed thirty-two (32) square feet per face in commercial and industrial zones. Real estate signs in residential zones shall not exceed six (6) feet in height. Real estate signs in industrial and commercial zones shall not exceed ten (10) feet in height and shall not be placed within two hundred fifty (250) feet of each other. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-149. - Residential districts; permitted signs; illumination. 
(a)  Permitted signs. The following signs shall be permitted in residential districts: 
(1)  Family home. One (1) accessory/ identification sign (excluding numerals or written words used to identify address) per single-family dwelling, provided that such sign does not exceed two (2) square feet in area per face. 
(2)  Apartment. One (1) accessory/ identification sign (excluding numeral or written words used to identify address) per multi-family residence; provided that such sign does not exceed six (6) square feet in area per face. 
(3)  For sale or rent: one (1) "for sale" or "for rent" sign per lot; provided that such sign does not exceed six (6) square feet in area per face. 
(4)  Home occupation: one (1) identification sign for any home occupation in existence at the date of the ordinance codified herein; provided that the owner and operator of the home occupation has complied with zoning regulations related to home occupations, and provided further that the sign does not exceed six (6) square feet in area per face. 
(5)  Subdivision: one (1) identification sign for a new subdivision; provided that the sign does not exceed one hundred (100) square feet in area per face; provided further that the sign is located within the subdivision; and provided further that the sign must be removed within thirty (30) days from when the last certificate of occupancy for the subdivision is issued. 
(6)  Public or semi-public use: one (1) identification sign per public or semi-public use; provided that such sign does not exceed thirty-five (35) square feet in area per face; and provided further that such sign does not exceed eight (8) feet in height. This Subsection includes church and school bulletin boards. 
(7)  One (1) directional sign, as allowed by definition. 
(8)  One (1) construction sign, as allowed by definition. 
(b)  Illuminated signs prohibited. No sign in a residential district shall be lighted or illuminated. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-150. - Signs permitted in all commercial and industrial zones. 
(a)  Signage shall not exceed total allowable by street frontage or building frontage. (See Section 16-159.) 
(b)  One (1) ground-mount/monument or pole/freestanding per street frontage is permitted. The maximum is two (2) per site if on different street frontages and two hundred (200) feet apart as measured in a straight line. 
(c)  Projecting signs and marquee signs shall be limited in projection to two (2) feet from the building wall, marquee or any architectural appendages on which they are attached. 
(d)  Wall signs or window signs shall not exceed twenty percent (20%) of the area of the building elevation on which they are situated. Such signs may not at any point extend above the parapet wall or eaves of the structure on which they are attached. In addition, such signs may only be mounted on the side of the structure which has frontage on a public right-of-way or public street or provides public access to the building. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-151. - Flashing signs near intersections prohibited; detracting from traffic-control devices prohibited. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Article, flashing signs shall not be located within one hundred (100) feet of an intersection, and no sign shall be maintained which, because of its appearance or location, detracts from the effectiveness of any traffic-control device. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-152. - Traffic-control signs or devices exempted. 
    This Article shall not apply to or restrict any public traffic-control signs or devices or any privately maintained signs used exclusively to direct automobile traffic on private property. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-153. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16-154. - Procedures for sign variance. 
    Variances for signs shall follow the process for zoning variances as provided in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-155. - Legal nonconforming sign. 
    Legal nonconforming signs must be brought into compliance with this Article or must be removed under the following conditions: whenever a sign is damaged beyond repair and/or becomes substandard to the extent that it becomes a hazard or a danger. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-156. - Illegal sign. 
    All illegal signs shall be removed or otherwise altered in order to be brought into compliance with this Article. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-157. - Enforcement. 
    This Article shall be enforced by the Planning Department. It shall be unlawful to erect, construct, reconstruct, alter or change any sign without first obtaining a sign permit from the City, and no permit shall be issued unless plans of, and for, the proposed erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration or use fully conform to the provisions of this Chapter and the regulations herein stated. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-158. - Violations and penalties. 
    Violation of the provisions of this Article shall constitute a zoning violation, and shall be subject to the penalties as provided in this Chapter. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-159. - Sign calculations. 
(a)  Total signage allowable on a zone lot is based on street frontage. Where no street frontage exists, building frontage will be used to calculate allowed sign area. 
(b)  For the first one hundred (100) feet of frontage, one and one-half (11/2) square feet of signage per one (1) foot of frontage. For each additional foot of frontage, an additional one (1) square foot of signage. 
(c)  Wall signs may not exceed twenty-five percent (25%) of the wall face to which it is attached. 
(d)  Freestanding or monument signs shall not be located closer than two hundred (200) feet from any other freestanding or monument sign.

No sign shall exceed twenty-five (25) feet in height or one hundred seventy-five (175) square feet per face, unless permitted by Section 16-160 below. 
(e)  Height exception for State Highway 85-oriented ground-mount/monument or pole/freestanding signs. In commercial and industrial zones, all signs located within a three-hundred-fifty-foot radius of the center of an interchange shall be allowed to extend twenty-five (25) feet above the paved grade of the interchange adjacent to the property or to a maximum height of fifty (50) feet. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-160. - Criteria for bonus sign area. 
    To encourage design excellence, the maximum sign area for freestanding and wall signs for all nonresidential uses, as set forth in this Article, may be increased by the percentages shown in this Section if all criteria are met. A separate bonus shall be granted for compliance with each of the criteria and the bonus is based upon the original allowed size standard. Any bonus shall be counted toward the total allowable square footage. If fractions occur when incentives are used, the closest higher number shall be used if the fraction is five-tenths (.5) or above and the closest lower number shall be used if the fraction is less than five-tenths (.5). All site plans and sign designs submitted for this bonus sign area shall be reviewed and approved by the City Council. 
(1)  Freestanding identification sign bonuses. Bonus sign area is earned through utilizing any combination of the following three (3) categories. The maximum bonus area allowed is twenty percent (20%) of the allowed sign area as outlined in Section 16-159 above. 
a.  Integration with building architecture and design. A ten-percent bonus shall be provided if all the freestanding signs are designed to be integrated with the building structure and design. The sign will be considered well-integrated if the same or similar building materials and colors are used. 
b.  Landscaped signs. A ten-percent bonus shall be provided if all of the freestanding signs within the development are located within a landscaped area. A minimum of three (3) square feet of landscaping shall be provided for every one (1) square foot of sign face. Only one (1) face of the sign will be counted. The portion of the sign on the ground shall not count toward the landscaping. Seventy-five percent (75%) of the sign area landscaping shall be living plants for a period of three (3) years or a specific landscaping design approved by the Planning Department. 
(2)  Wall sign bonuses. Bonus sign area is earned through utilizing any combination of the following two (2) categories. The maximum bonus area allowed is thirty percent (30%) of the allowed sign area as outlined in Section 16-159 above. 
a.  A ten-percent bonus shall be provided if all wall signs are uniform in terms of at least three (3) of the following categories: materials, colors, height, lettering style, sign type and shape. For individual developments with only one (1) wall sign, the wall sign bonus may be achieved if the wall and freestanding signs are the same in terms of two (2) of the following: materials, color, lettering style and/or shape. 
b.  A fifteen-percent bonus shall be provided if all wall signs within a single or multi-tenant complex are individual letter signs. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-161. - Permits for A-frame or footed vertical signs. 
(a)  One-year permits for A-frame or footed vertical signs may be issued by the Planning Department to an applicant (the permittee) under the following conditions: 
(1)  A completed application is filed with the City, with the applicable twenty-five-dollar fee; 
(2)  A sketch plan of the sign is provided with the application; 
(3)  If an A-frame sign is to be placed on a public right-of-way or easement, proof of liability insurance for personal injury and property damage of at least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for the business or premises is provided. Said proof of insurance must be resubmitted annually, if subsequent one-year permits are approved; and 
(4)  A review by the Planning Department shows that the sign will be able to be placed in accordance with the requirements of Section 16-162. 
(b)  The sign permit shall specify the location where the sign must be placed. Location of the sign must remain as specified, and misplacement shall be immediately corrected by the permittee. 
(c)  Permits are issued subject to continued maintenance of the sign as provided in the sketch plan and compliance with placement, and the requirements of Section 16-162. Permits are subject to forthwith revocation for violation of these requirements upon written notice from the City, with appeal of such revocation available only to the Board of Adjustment. 
(d)  The size of the sign shall not be counted against the total square footage of signage otherwise allowed for a property. 
(e)  Application for a permit and maintenance of either type sign constitutes an acknowledgment and agreement by the permittee of indemnification of the City against any claim or cause of action, including attorney fees and costs, and shall be so noted on the permit. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-162. - A-frame and footed vertical signs. 
(a)  A-frame signs are freestanding signs that are no taller than four (4) feet and no wider than three (3) feet, with one (1) or two (2) message-bearing sides that are hinged or attached at the top. A-frame signs have the general appearance when viewed from the side of a capital "A." Footed vertical signs are freestanding signs with braces (feet) at the bottom to hold them upright, that are no taller than four (4) feet and no wider than three (3) feet, with one (1) or two (2) message-bearing sides that are not hinged or attached at the top, and when viewed from the side appear as a "?" and from the front as a rectangle. A-frame signs must be placed on sidewalks against the building of the business they advertise if there is no private property between the building and the street surface, or they may be placed on private property. Footed vertical signs must be placed on private property and not on sidewalks. Such signs shall be constructed of at least one-quarter-inch plywood or of metal equivalent in strength. Such signs shall be neat, attractive and visually appealing, so that they are an asset of the business, adjacent land uses and the community at large. 
(b)  Only one (1) A-frame or footed vertical sign shall be allowed per building regardless of the number of businesses at that location. 
(c)  There shall be at least ten (10) feet between either type sign at one (1) building and either type sign at the next building. 
(d)  Placement of either type sign shall allow a minimum of six (6) feet of unobstructed pedestrian walkway and shall be safely placed so as not to interfere with pedestrian traffic or access to parked vehicles, nor block the view of vehicular traffic in the sight triangle at an intersection. 
(e)  Either type sign shall be constructed, or adapted, to prevent being blown by the wind from its placement, or into persons, vehicles or other buildings. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Secs. 16-163-16-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII - Site Plans 

Sec. 16-170. - General requirements. 
(a)  Intent. It is the intent of this Article to promote orderly and sound development standards as they apply to the City. These site development standards are intended to enhance and protect the community's natural as well as man-made environments. 
(b)  Site plan required. 
(1)  Site plans are required as a step in the building permit review process for all multi-family, commercial or industrial development. 
(2)  Site plans are required for development which, in the opinion of the Planning Department, would have an adverse environmental impact upon the surrounding area or would have a major community land use impact. 
(3)  To change an approved site plan when the change involves additional land use, including but not limited to: 
a.  Additional buildings. 
b.  Increase in the size of any building as shown on an approved site plan by more than ten percent (10%) over such approved building size. 
c.  Outside storage and/or display. 
d.  Vacation or dedication of easements or rights-of-way. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-171. - Responsibilities of applicant. 
(a)  The applicant is responsible for having a representative at all meetings where the request is reviewed. Failure to have a representative present will be cause to have the item withdrawn from the agenda of that meeting. 
(b)  The applicant shall consult with the City staff for general information regarding requirements for site plans and any special considerations pertaining to the site. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-172. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16-173. - Site plan process. 
(a)  Procedure. 
(1)  Pre-application conference. Before submitting an application for a site plan, the applicant shall meet with representatives from the Planning Department to discuss the applicant's intended submittal, the City's application requirements and processes and other information relevant to the proposed application. The conference might also include a visit to the site. 
(2)  Application. The applicant shall submit an original and a sufficient number of copies of application materials, as determined by the Planning Department, for distribution and review by the City. All copies of maps and large sheets shall, unless otherwise requested by the City, be properly folded prior to submittal. 
(3)  Public hearing date. The City shall set a date for consideration of the application by the Planning Commission at a public hearing, and shall notify the applicant of the hearing date. 
(4)  Referral packets. The City will notify the applicant of the content and the number of copies of the site plan referral packets to be submitted to the City for distribution to referral agencies. Referral packets shall be provided by the applicant by a date specified by the Planning Department to ensure timely mailing prior to the Planning Commission meeting, properly folded and compiled in unsealed envelopes, stamped with sufficient first-class postage. Upon receipt of the referral packets from the applicant, the City will address the envelopes, include information on the hearing process and promptly mail the referral packets. The City will request that the referral agencies return comments in a timely manner for inclusion in Planning Commission packets prior to the hearing. Referral agencies include: 
a.  Telephone company. 
b.  Public Service Company. 
c.  Weld County School District RE-8. 
d.  City Engineer. 
e.  Fort Lupton Fire Department. 
f.  Colorado Department of Transportation (if appropriate). 
g.  United Power. 
h.  Other agencies, as determined by the Planning Department. 
(5)  Design Review Team. The Planning Department may present the application to the DRT for review and comment prior to the Planning Commission meeting. 
(6)  Publication. The City will publish notice of the Planning Commission hearing date, time and location at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing. In the event that the date of the subsequent City Council hearing can be anticipated at that time, notice of the City Council hearing may be combined with this notice. 
(7)  Posting. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the Planning Commission public hearing, the applicant shall post the property with a notice of the hearings as required by the Planning Department. Posting shall consist of at least one (1) sign facing and clearly legible from and within fifty (50) feet of each adjacent public street. These notices shall be in the form of signs measuring not less than three (3) feet by four (4) feet, with lettering a minimum of three (3) inches high and on posts no less than four (4) feet above the ground. Signs shall contain the following language, and shall include scheduled hearing dates: 
PUBLIC NOTICE 
A land use application is under review by the 
City of Fort Lupton. 
Public hearings have been scheduled for: 
Planning Commission: Tuesday, ____, 20___ 
City Council: Monday, _______, 20___ 
Time: 7:00 p.m. 
Location: 130 South McKinley Avenue 
CONTACT THE PLANNING DEPARTMENT AT: 
303-857-6694 
(8)  Notice to neighbors. Using stamped envelopes provided by the applicant, and at a reasonable time prior to the Planning Commission public hearing, the City shall send by first-class mail information about the site plan application and the scheduled public hearings to owners of property located within one hundred (100) feet of the property for which the application has been submitted. 
(9)  Planning Commission hearing. The Planning Commission shall consider the application and public testimony at a public hearing, and shall make a recommendation to the City Council to approve, approve with conditions or deny the site plan. 
(10)  The Planning Department shall advise the applicant of the Planning Commission decision and of any conditions contained in the Planning Commission's recommendation to the City Council. 
(11)  Revisions. By a date specified by the Planning Department to permit timely distribution to the City Council, the applicant shall submit revisions and/or provide documentation to the Planning Department addressing the Planning Commission's concerns and recommendations. 
(12)  Following the recommendation by the Planning Commission, the City will schedule consideration of the site plan by the City Council at a hearing, and shall notify the applicant of the meeting date and time. 
(13)  Publication. Unless previously published, the City will publish notice of the City Council hearing date, time and location at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing. 
(14)  Posting. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the City Council public hearing, the applicant shall post the property with a notice of the hearing as required by the Planning Department. Posting shall be as required for the Planning Commission hearing. 
(15)  The applicant shall submit to the City staff two (2) signed Mylars of the site plan. 
(16)  City Council hearing. The City Council shall conduct a public hearing and evaluate the application, Planning Commission recommendation and public testimony and, by resolution, shall approve, approve with conditions, continue for additional information or for further study, deny it or refer the same back to the Planning Commission for further study. 
(17)  The City shall cause the approved site plan to be recorded in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder. If construction has not substantially commenced within one (1) year after final approval, the approved site plan shall become void. 
(b)  Plans and data. All site plans shall be made with an engineer's scale, minimum scale to be one (1) inch represents forty (40) feet, shall be on a reproducible medium of one (1) or more sheets with outer dimensions of twenty-four (24) by thirty-six (36) inches, and shall conform to the site plan, as approved. 
(1)  The site plan shall contain the following information: 
a.  The location and dimensions of all existing and proposed traffic controls, trash disposal areas and enclosures, electric transformers, landscaping materials shown at mature sizes and the maintenance system for landscaping. 
b.  A complete listing of all landscaping materials, including scientific and common names, quantity, size at planting, size at maturity and a symbol or label to identify materials on the site plan. 
c.  A description of all structures to be built on the site, including size, quantity, use and the number of units per structure. 
d.  Buildings, including amount of floor space for each floor. 
e.  Parking. 
f.  Private drives. 
g.  Public streets. 
h.  Sidewalks and pathways. 
i.  Open space. 
j.  Easements. 
(2)  Certification blocks. Mylars shall include signatures on the following certification blocks: 
a.  Easement approval: 
1.  Public Works Department. 
2.  Telephone company. 
3.  Natural gas company. 
4.  Electric company. 
5.  Cable television company. 
b.  City Engineer's approval. 
c.  Planning Commission approval. 
d.  City Council approval. 
(c)  Reports and information. The following reports and information shall be submitted with the site plan application. 
(1)  Architectural elevations and specifications of signs and lighting. 
(2)  Architectural elevations of the site as it is to be developed. 
(3)  Permits from the Colorado Department of Transportation for curb cuts on state highways. Such permits must be cosigned by the City Engineer. 
(4)  A survey of the lot lines if they are not the same as originally platted. 
(5)  Dedication statement for any public land not designated on the plat. 
(6)  If the use is nonresidential, the number of employees and the type of activity shall be specified. 
(7)  If the use is residential, the type of units and the number of each unit to be built shall be specified. 
(8)  A statement explaining the phasing of the development. 
(9)  A listing of landscape material costs and installation costs. 
(10)  A complete set of construction plans. 
(11)  Evidence of current ownership, acceptable to the City Attorney, such as a copy of an updated title policy or commitment, current within thirty (30) days. 
(12)  Drainage plan in a form specified by the City Engineer. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1; Ord. 2010-914 §3; Ord. 2015-994 §63) 
Sec. 16-174. - Administrative site plans. 
(a)  The purpose of administrative site plan review is: 
(1)  To develop any nonresidential use for which site plan review by the Planning Commission and the City Council is not required. 
(2)  To redevelop existing nonresidential uses when the redevelopment results in one (1) of the following: 
a.  Additional floor space not to exceed ten percent (10%) of the space shown on an approved site plan. 
b.  Change in parking area. 
c.  Change in pedestrian or vehicular circulation. 
(3)  To change an approved administrative site plan when the change involves any of the following: 
a.  Building location or size, not to exceed ten percent (10%) of the space shown on an approved site plan. 
b.  Parking area. 
c.  Pedestrian or vehicular circulation. 
d.  Size or location of landscaping areas. 
(4)  To ensure that existing neighborhood character is preserved and/or enhanced and to minimize possible detrimental uses. 
(b)  Administrative site plan review is required when the criteria for administrative site plans is met and any of the following situations occur: 
(1)  The conversion of a single-family use to a less restrictive use. 
(2)  The demolition or removal of a single-family use for purposes of constructing a less restrictive use. 
(3)  The addition of dwelling units to an existing multiple-family structure. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 16-175. - Administrative site plan review. 
(a)  Process. 
(1)  Preapplication conference and site visit. Before submitting an application for an administrative site plan, the applicant shall meet with representatives from the Planning Department to discuss the applicant's intended submittal and the City's application requirements and processes. The meeting might also include a visit to the site. The Planning Department shall determine if the proposed application meets the criteria for administrative site plans. 
(2)  The applicant shall submit one (1) copy of the proposed site plan and all supporting information to the City. 
(3)  The Planning Department shall review the submittal for completeness and for conformance with the City's plans, policies and regulations within a reasonable period of time and shall notify the applicant of any deficiencies. The applicant shall have an opportunity to make the necessary inclusions or corrections. An incomplete submittal shall not be processed. 
(4)  Application. Once the Planning Department has determined that the submittal is complete, the City will notify the applicant of the content, format and number of copies of the application packets to be submitted to the City. The applicant shall submit an original and a sufficient number of copies of the application materials, as determined by the Planning Department, for distribution and review by the City. All copies of maps and large sheets shall, unless otherwise requested by the City, be properly folded prior to submittal. 
(5)  Upon receipt of the site plan, the City staff shall furnish the appropriate agencies and offices a copy of the site plan for review and comment. 
(6)  The applicant shall meet with the City staff to review the comments of the referral agencies. 
(7)  The applicant shall make all changes required by the referral agencies. 
(8)  The applicant shall submit to the City staff two (2) Mylars of the site plan. Both Mylars shall include signatures on the following certification blocks: 
a.  Surveyor's certificate. 
b.  Easement approval. 
1.  Public Works Department. 
2.  Telephone company. 
3.  Natural gas company. 
4.  Electric company. 
5.  Cable television company 
c.  City Engineer's approval. 
(9)  The City shall cause the approved site plan to be recorded in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder. If construction has not commenced within one (1) year after final approval, the approved site plan shall become void. 
(b)  Plans and data. 
(1)  All administrative site plans shall be made with an engineer's scale, minimum scale to be one (1) inch represents forty (40) feet, shall be on a reproducible medium of one (1) or more sheets with outer dimensions of twenty-four (24) by thirty-six (36) inches and shall contain the same information as is required for a site plan. 
(2)  Reports and information. The Planning Department may require any of the following reports and information pertaining to changes proposed to the original site plan to be submitted with the administrative site plan: 
a.  Drainage plan. 
b.  Number of residential units. 
c.  Specifications for signs and lighting. 
d.  Landscape installation and material costs. 
e.  Architectural elevations and specifications of signs and lighting. 
f.  Architectural elevations of the site as it is to be developed. 
g.  Permits from the Colorado Department of Transportation for curb cuts on state highways. Such permits must be cosigned by the City Engineer. 
h.  A survey of the lot lines if they are not the same as originally platted. 
i.  Dedication statement for any public land not designated on the plat. 
j.  If the use is nonresidential, the number of employees and the type of activity shall be specified. 
k.  If the use is residential, the type of units and the number of each unit to be built shall be specified. 
l.  A statement explaining the phasing of the development. 
m.  A listing of landscape material costs and installation costs. 
n.  A complete set of construction plans. 
o.  Evidence of current ownership, acceptable to the City Attorney, such as a copy of the updated title policy or commitment, current within thirty (30) days. 
p.  A drainage plan in a form specified by the City Engineer. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Part 1) 
Secs. 16-176-16-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX - Additional Provisions 

Sec. 16-191. - Residential Design Standards. 
    Compliance with the City of Fort Lupton Residential Design Standards (RDS), as approved and adopted by Resolution 2007-026 (and as may be thereafter amended by resolution), is required in the City. 
(Ord. 2007-888, Part 1) 
Sec. 16-192. - Unlawful to violate Residential Design Standards. 
    No person or entity shall construct, rebuild, alter, replace or use a structure, building or other covered facility, that is covered by, but not in compliance with, the RDS. The Building Official and the Planning Director have joint jurisdiction to administer and enforce the RDS. Each day of violation is a separate and distinct offense. The RDS may be enforced by court action by either or both: 
(1)  Summonses and complaints filed in the Municipal Court: Code enforcement officers or law enforcement officers may issue Municipal Court summonses and complaints for violations of the RDS; or 
(2)  District court civil actions, including restraining orders. 
(Ord. 2007-888, Part 2) 
Sec. 16-193. - Stop work order. 
    The Building Official may issue a stop work order to any person or entity not in compliance with the RDS. This stop work order may be enforced in the same manner as any other stop work order in the Building Code. 
(Ord. 2007-888, Part 3) 
Sec. 16-194. - Commercial and Industrial Design Standards. 
    Compliance with the City of Fort Lupton Commercial and Industrial Design Standards, as approved and adopted by Resolution 2007-041 (and as may be thereafter amended by resolution), is required in the City. 
(Ord. 2007-895, Part 1) 
Sec. 16-195. - Unlawful to violate Commercial and Industrial Design Standards. 
    No person or entity shall construct, rebuilt, alter, replace or use a structure or building that is not in compliance with the Commercial and Industrial Design Standards. The Building Official and Planning Director have joint jurisdiction to administer and enforce the Commercial and Industrial Design Standards. Each day of violation is a separate and distinct offense. The Commercial and Industrial Design Standards may be enforced by court action by either or both: 
(1)  Summonses and complaints filed in the Municipal Court: Code enforcement officers or law enforcement officers may issue Municipal Court summonses and complaints for violations of the Commercial and Industrial Design Standards; or 
(2)  District Court civil actions, including restraining orders. 
(Ord. 2007-895, Part 2) 
Sec. 16-196. - Stop work order. 
    The Building Official may issue a stop work order to any person or entity not in compliance with the Commercial and Industrial Design Standards. This stop work order may be enforced in the same manner as any other stop work order in the Building Code. 
(Ord. 2007-895, Part 3) 
Sec. 16-197. - City of Fort Lupton Master Plan. 
    The City of Fort Lupton's Master Plan shall be the document adopted by resolution of the City Council, as amended from time to time, to guide the land development decisions of the City. The Master Plan will be a reflection of the laws of the City and State, and shall serve in an advisory capacity to help implement the land use goals of the City. An amendment to the Master Plan requires sufficient public notice and a public hearing before the Planning Commission and City Council; approved plans will be adopted by resolution. 
(Ord. 2013-961 §1; 2017-1015 §1) 
Sec. 16-198. - City of Fort Lupton Three-Mile Area Plan. 
    The City of Fort Lupton Three-Mile Area Plan is to be an addendum to the currently approved official comprehensive land use document of the City of Fort Lupton, and adopted by resolution annually. 
(Ord. 2013-961 §2) 
Secs. 16-199-16-210. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 17 - Subdivisions 
ARTICLE I - Subdivision Regulations 

Sec. 17-1. - Purpose. 
    This Article is established to achieve the following purposes: 
(1)  To promote the general health, safety and welfare of the present and future inhabitants of the City. 
(2)  To ensure high quality land development. 
(3)  To guide future growth and development within the City, and ensure adequate and efficient transportation, water, waste disposal, schools, fire and police protection, recreation and open space opportunities and other services and facilities. 
(4)  To encourage a diversity of housing types and densities in order to assure adequate housing for all persons. 
(5)  To encourage business development within the community that will provide jobs, tax base and shopping and investment opportunities. 
(6)  To provide for the preservation and conservation of unique or distinctive natural areas, natural landmarks, critical wildlife habitats, wetlands, historic features and archaeologically sensitive sites, recognizing the irreplaceable character of such resources and their importance to the quality of life in the City. 
(7)  To minimize the conflicts between the land uses and structures by providing for: lots that are of an appropriate size and configuration for the site characteristics and intended uses; safe and convenient connections between neighborhoods, shopping and recreational areas; adequate buffering from the adverse impacts of adjoining uses through lot orientation, setbacks, landscaping or other appropriate methods; conservation of water, land and energy resources; minimization of grading, road cuts and fills; and a road system designed to preserve the integrity and function of the arterial and local roadway network. 
(8)  To ensure that the necessary services and facilities are available and have sufficient capacity to serve residents and businesses. 
(9)  To minimize the burden of new development on existing residents and businesses by ensuring that the cost and installation of necessary public improvements, which primarily benefit the land being subdivided, will be borne by the owners and developers of such land. 
(10)  To provide for adequate and accurate public land records. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-2. - Scope of regulations. 
(a)  The territory covered by these regulations shall include all lands located within the incorporated area of the City. 
(b)  The subdivision regulations shall provide for proper arrangements of streets in relation to other existing or planned streets and to the Comprehensive Plan of the City; for adequate and convenient open spaces; for traffic, utilities, access of firefighting apparatus, recreational uses, light and air; and for the minimum area, depth and width of lots. 
(c)  All subdivision fees shall be as provided for in this Chapter and as shown in the "City of Fort Lupton General Fee Schedule" as adopted and updated by resolution by the City Council. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-3. - General provisions. 
(a)  Conformance to Code and Comprehensive Plan. No sketch plat, preliminary plat, final plat or minor plat of a subdivision shall be recommended for approval by the Planning Commission or approved by the City Council unless it conforms to the provisions of this Code and of the Comprehensive Plan, as interpreted by the City Council. 
(b)  Maintenance. The City will not maintain public street improvements and other public improvements within rights-of-way which have not been accepted for maintenance purposes by the City Council. 
(c)  Building permits. Prior to the issuance of a building permit or construction of any building or structure within the City, a subdivision plat thereof shall be approved by the City and properly recorded in the records of the County Clerk and Recorder. No building permits shall be issued for construction on land that has not been properly subdivided pursuant to this Chapter. 
(d)  Withdrawal of approval. During the subdivision process, the City Council may, at a public meeting and after reasonable notice to a subdivider, suspend or withdraw any approval of a plan or plat or may require certain corrective measures be taken following a determination that the information provided by the subdivider upon which such approval was based is substantially false or inaccurate, that new significant information has been brought to the City Council's attention or for noncompliance by the subdivider. 
(e)  Changes to final plat. No changes, erasures, modifications or revisions, other than signatures, shall be made on a final plat after the approval by the City Council, except as required by the City Council as a condition of approval. 
(f)  Signatures. All original applications and original supporting materials submitted to the City, other than Mylar plats, shall be signed in blue ink by the owner and/or the owner's agent as applicant. 
(g)  Property tax. No subdivision shall be approved by the City Council unless all ad valorem taxes applicable to such subdivided land, for years prior to that year in which approval is granted, have been paid. 
(h)  Recording. It is unlawful to file for recording any subdivision plat in any public office unless it has been approved by the City in accordance with this Chapter. 
(i)  Exemption. The City Council may, pursuant to rules and regulations or resolution, exempt from the definition of the terms subdivision and subdivided land any division of land if the City Council determines that such division is not within the purposes of this Chapter. 
(j)  Subsequent approvals. Approval at any step in the subdivision process does not ensure approval at the next step. 
(k)  Combined processes. The preliminary plat and final plat processes may be combined upon the approval of the City Council, based upon, but not limited to, the following factors: design, size, public concern, public facilities, services, access and transportation network. 
(l)  Resubmittal. If a proposed subdivision application is denied by the City Council, a new subdivision application for the same or substantially the same request, as determined by the City Council, shall not be accepted within one (1) year of such denial. 
(m)  Applicant's responsibilities. The applicant or representative is responsible for understanding the provisions of this Chapter, the Comprehensive Plan and applicable zoning regulations. 
(n)  Attendance at meetings. The applicant is responsible for attending all Planning Commission and City Council hearings and meetings at which the request is considered. Failure to attend the hearings and meetings may result in the request being denied or tabled and a new hearing or meeting date scheduled. The applicant is responsible for submitting information requested by the City. 
(o)  Withdrawal of application. The applicant may withdraw an application at any phase of the process upon submittal of a written request to the City. Application fees and unexpended fee deposits will be refunded to the applicant; provided, however, that the application fee will only be refunded if the application is withdrawn by the applicant prior to consideration of a sketch plat by the Planning Commission. 
(p)  Expiration of approvals. The approval of any subdivision application shall be subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  Sketch plat approval shall be effective for a period of one (1) year from the date of approval. The City Council may grant an extension of time upon a written request by the applicant prior to the expiration of the one-year period. 
(2)  The preliminary plat approval shall be effective for a period of one (1) year from the date of approval. The City Council may grant an extension of time upon a written request by the applicant prior to the expiration of the one-year period. In the event that a final plat has been approved for a portion of an area within an approved preliminary plat, the approval of the preliminary plat for the remaining area shall be effective for one (1) year from the date of such final plat approval, or as otherwise extended by the City Council. 
(3)  Applicants requesting an extension of an expiration deadline shall include a narrative stating the reasons for the request, describing any changing conditions in the area of the subdivision and proposing a schedule for completion. In considering a request for an extension, the City Council may place additional conditions on its prior approvals. 
(q)  Survey. Within one (1) year after the date of approval or conditional approval of the preliminary plat by the City Council, the subdivider shall cause the subdivision to be accurately surveyed and the final map thereof to be prepared in accordance with the preliminary plat and with any and all alterations and changes required thereto. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-4. - Penalties. 
(a)  The erection, construction, enlargement, conversion, moving or maintenance of any building or structure and the use of any land or building which is continued, operated or maintained, contrary to any provisions of this Chapter, is hereby declared to be a violation of this Chapter and unlawful. The Building Inspector, with approval of the City Council, or any property owner who may be damaged by any violation of this Chapter may, upon any such violation having been called to either of their attention, institute injunction, abatement or any other appropriate action to prevent, enjoin, abate or remove such violation. 
(b)  The remedy provided for herein shall be cumulative and not exclusive and shall be in addition to any other remedies provided by law. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-5. - Definitions. 
(a)  Interpretation. 
(1)  The words must, shall and will are mandatory; may , can, should and might are permissive. 
(2)  As used in this Code, words used in the singular include the plural and words used in the plural include the singular. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this Chapter, the following words shall be construed to have the meanings defined below: 
    Alley shall mean a public or private way at the rear or side of the property, permanently dedicated as a means of secondary vehicular access to the abutting property, and generally having less width than a street. 
    Appeal shall mean a request by an applicant to the City Council for a review of and administrative interpretation of any provision of this Chapter. 
    Applicant shall mean a property owner or an agent of an owner who has filed an application for subdivision of land within the City pursuant to this Chapter. 
    Block shall mean an area of land within a subdivision, consisting of one (1) or more lots, which area is entirely bounded by streets or highways, or the exterior boundary or boundaries of the subdivision. 
    City shall mean the City of Fort Lupton, Colorado. 
    Code shall mean the City of Fort Lupton Municipal Code. 
    Collector street shall mean a thoroughfare ultimately designed for the movements of one (1) or more lanes of moving traffic in each direction and designated as a secondary highway by the Comprehensive Plan adopted by the City Council. 
    Comprehensive Plan shall mean the Comprehensive Plan of the City of Fort Lupton and all of its approved amendments and additions. 
    Design Review Team (DRT) shall mean an interdepartmental coordinating team comprised of the City Planner, the Public Works Director, the City Administrator and staff representatives from other City departments and from the Fire Department, meeting as needed to review development proposals. 
    Development application (application) shall mean the form or forms provided by the City that are to be completed and submitted by applicants for approval of land developments, and all required accompanying reports, fees and documentation. 
    Easement shall mean a right generally established in a real estate deed or on a recorded plat to permit the use of land by the public, a corporation or particular persons for specified uses. 
    Floor area ratio (FAR) shall mean the amount of gross floor area of all principal buildings on a property, divided by the total area of such property. 
    Frontage shall mean the line where a lot abuts a dedicated street or highway right-of-way line. 
    Improvement (public improvement) shall mean such street work and utilities to be installed by the subdivider on the land dedicated or to be dedicated for streets, highways, public ways and easements, or on existing public streets bordering on the land of the subdivider as are necessary for the general use of the lot or subdivision. 
    Local street shall mean a street intended wholly or principally for local neighborhood traffic. 
    Lot shall mean a parcel of real property with a separate and distinct number or other designation shown on a plat that has been approved by the local government having jurisdiction at the time of subdivision, and recorded in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder. 
    Major arterial highway shall mean a thoroughfare ultimately designed for the movement of two (2) or more lanes of moving traffic in each direction, and designated as a major street by the Comprehensive Plan adopted by the City Council. 
    Plat shall mean a map of certain described land showing property and lot boundaries, location of public utilities, easements and other information prepared and approved in accordance with the requirements of this Code or of the laws in effect at the time of subdivision, and recorded in the records of the County Clerk and Recorder. 
    Resubdivision shall mean the subdivision of land that is within a previously recorded subdivision plat, or any amendment to a previously recorded subdivision plat. 
    School District shall mean the Weld County School District, RE-8. 
    Service road shall mean a street adjacent to a major or secondary highway, freeway or expressway, separated therefrom by a dividing strip and providing ingress to and egress from abutting property. 
    Subdivider shall mean any person, partnership, joint venture, limited liability company, association or corporation which participates as owner, promoter, developer or sales agent in the planning, platting, development, promotion, sale or lease of a land development. 
    Subdivision shall mean the division of any real property, improved or unimproved, or a portion thereof for the purpose of sale, lease or financing, whether immediate or future. 
    Subdivision improvements agreement (SIA) shall mean a contract between the City and the owner of land being subdivided, providing for the construction and installation of public improvements and landscaping, security and warranties therefor, dedications of public improvements and land and other terms unique to a specific subdivision. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-6. - Fees. 
    Review fees. The applicant shall be responsible for payment of application fees as adopted by the City Council, and for payment of reasonable fees to cover the actual costs of administration, overhead, professional and consulting services, inspection, publication of notice and other activities of the City and its agents incurred in processing a subdivision application. Payment of the fees shall be as follows: 
(1)  Application fee. The applicant shall pay to the City an application fee in an amount set by resolution of the City Council. 
(2)  Fee deposit. In addition to the application fee, the applicant shall pay to the City the actual cost of staff time and professional or consulting services rendered in connection with the review of the proposed subdivision application, plus fifteen percent (15%) to cover administrative overhead. Professional or consulting services include, but are not limited to, legal, planning and engineering services. The City may require a deposit from the applicant to offset the City's costs for review prior to consideration of any application submittal pursuant to this Chapter. The City may also require deposit of additional fees during the consideration of a subdivision application in the event that actual costs plus overhead exceed the original deposited amount. The City may not process or continue to process a subdivision application and may not approve a subdivision unless sufficient fees have been deposited to cover such costs. Any fees paid that are remaining on deposit with the City after paying the City's actual costs plus overhead shall be refunded to the applicant upon completion or termination of the subdivision process. 
(3)  Application fees and fee deposits shall be paid upon submittal of a completed land use application or notice of appeal. Applications which are not accompanied by the appropriate fee shall be considered incomplete and shall not be processed nor shall any permit be issued until the appropriate fee is received by the City. 
(4)  The City will send statements to the applicant as necessary, including an accounting of the actual costs and overhead incurred to date in processing the application. Such statements may also include a requirement that additional funds be deposited with the City in the event that earlier deposits were insufficient. The applicant shall pay the amount due on the statement within fifteen (15) days of the date of issuance of such statement. 
(5)  If the statement is not paid in full within thirty (30) days after issuance of the statement, the City shall impose interest on the amount due and outstanding for actual costs and overhead to date at the rate of one and one-half percent (1.5%) per month from the date when due. 
(6)  The City may certify to the County Treasurer any amount due pursuant to this Section as a lien on the property for which the application is submitted, to be due and payable with the real estate taxes for the City if the applicant or the property owner does not pay such amount within thirty (30) days of written request by the City. 
(7)  Fees, as set forth within this Section, shall be due and payable regardless of whether the proposed subdivision is completed or approved, and/or regardless of whether the owner or applicant chooses to complete the City's subdivision review process. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-7. - Subdivision types and processes. 
(a)  Major subdivision process summary. 
(1)  Sketch plat. 
a.  Preapplication conference and site visit with staff. 
b.  Application submittal. 
c.  Staff confirmation of complete submittal. 
d.  Notice of meeting mailed to adjoining landowners and mineral owners. 
e.  Planning Commission review and comment. 
f.  City Council consideration. 
(2)  Preliminary plat. 
a.  Presubmittal conference. 
b.  Preliminary plat application submittal. 
c.  Staff confirmation of complete submittal. 
d.  Set hearing dates. 
e.  Referrals. 
f.  Design Review Team review. 
g.  Subdivision improvements agreement negotiation. 
h.  Publication of Planning Commission and City Council hearing dates. 
i.  Applicant posts notice of hearings on the site. 
j.  Preliminary negotiations on terms of subdivision improvements agreement. 
k.  Notice of hearings mailed to adjoining landowners and mineral owners. 
l.  Planning Commission public hearing and recommendation to City Council. 
m.  Applicant addresses Planning Commission recommendations. 
n.  Publication and posting of City Council hearing if not done previously. 
o.  City Council hearing and action. 
(3)  Final plat. 
a.  Applicant surveys the proposed subdivision. 
b.  Applicant obtains commitment to serve from all utilities and service providers. 
c.  Applicant prepares final plat submittal, incorporating all of the requirements of the City Council. 
d.  Final plat application submittal. 
e.  Staff confirmation of complete submittal. 
f.  Planning Commission public meeting and recommendation to the City Council. 
g.  Applicant addresses Planning Commission recommendations. 
h.  Applicant completes preliminary engineering and cost estimates on public improvements. 
i.  Final negotiations on subdivision improvements agreement. 
j.  Applicant prepares and signs final Mylar plats, signs final SIA and obtains improvements security. 
k.  Applicant submits final, signed materials to the Planning Department. 
l.  Planning Department confirmation of complete submittal. 
m.  City Council public meeting and action on final plat, SIA and improvements security. 
n.  Staff obtains all City signatures on final plat and SIA. 
o.  City records final plat and SIA. 
p.  Applicant completes final engineering. 
q.  Post-approval actions. 
(b)  Other subdivision types. 
(1)  Minor subdivision process summary. 
a.  Preapplication conference and site visit with staff. 
b.  Application submittal. 
c.  Staff confirmation of complete submittal. 
d.  Publication of Planning Commission and City Council hearing dates. 
e.  Referrals. 
f.  Applicant posts notice of hearings on the site. 
g.  Notice of hearings mailed to adjoining landowners and mineral owners. 
h.  Design Review Team meeting. 
i.  Planning Commission public hearing and recommendation to City Council. 
j.  Applicant addresses Planning Commission recommendations. 
k.  Applicant prepares and signs final Mylar plats. 
l.  Applicant submits final, signed materials to the City Planner. 
m.  City Council public hearing. 
n.  Applicant amends and resubmits minor plat if required to do so by City Council. 
o.  Staff obtains all City signatures on minor plat. 
p.  City records minor plat. 
(2)  Amended subdivision process summary. 
a.  Preapplication conference with staff. 
b.  Applicant prepares and signs final Mylar plats. 
c.  Applicant submits final, signed plat and application materials to the City Planner. 
d.  Planning Department confirmation of complete and accurate submittal. 
e.  Plat referred to City Administrator and Public Works Department. 
f.  Staff obtains all City signatures on amended plat. 
g.  City records amended plat. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-8. - Development application. 
(a)  Any property owner desiring to subdivide property pursuant to this Chapter shall first submit a land use application on forms provided by the City, all required fees and documentation. A land use application shall be appurtenant to the property and shall be transferable with the property. 
(b)  After confirmation of completion by the City Planner and upon payment of the required fees, the completed land use application shall be deemed valid. 
(c)  Sketch plat, preliminary plat and final plat are steps in the major subdivision process. A valid land use application , as defined herein, for any of these steps or phases shall be construed as a valid land use application for all subsequent phases of the subdivision process through final plat approval. 
(d)  Nothing in this Section shall be construed as creating any vested interest or any assurance of the approval of an annexation or land use application. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-9. - Severability. 
    Should any portion of this Chapter or the application thereof be found to be invalid by a court, such invalidity shall not affect the remaining portions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Secs. 17-10-17-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II - Major Subdivisions 

Sec. 17-20. - General. 
(a)  Intent. The major subdivision process is to provide for quality and timely land development, systematic review by interested agencies, public accountability, conformance with local and state laws and a clear set of standards. 
(b)  Definition. A major subdivision is a subdivision that includes one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  Dedication of a public right-of-way or other public land dedication; 
(2)  The entire parcel of land to be subdivided is greater than six (6) acres; or 
(3)  The subdivision consists of more than four (4) lots. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-21. - Sketch plat. 
    The subdivider shall submit a sketch plat to the Planning Commission for its review and comments prior to making application for Planning Commission review of the preliminary plat. The sketch plat shall be prepared in a manner which generally defines the layout of streets, lots and location of any public uses, such as schools and parks, and proposed zoning classifications. It is the purpose of the sketch plat to identify in a public meeting any issues and concerns related to development of the property being subdivided prior to preparation of the preliminary plat. The Planning Commission shall review the sketch plat and offer any comments to the subdivider. 
(1)  Intent. 
a.  The sketch plat is a general concept, describing an applicant's development vision and plan for a proposed major subdivision. The sketch plat gives the City an opportunity to describe the community's vision to the applicant. It provides basic information to the City that will affect the planning and design of the site. It also provides the applicant an opportunity to hear comments and concerns from the public prior to proceeding with detailed project design. 
b.  The sketch plat is an initial review of a proposed major subdivision. It is not intended to provide final comments or requirements, or to in any way restrict the City's discretion in subsequent stages of the review process. 
(2)  Sketch plat review process. 
a.  Preapplication conference and site visit. Before submitting an application for a major subdivision, the applicant shall meet with representatives from the Planning Department to discuss the applicant's intended submittal, the City's application requirements and processes, the Comprehensive Plan, development standards and other information relevant to development of the property. The meeting might also include a visit to the site. 
b.  The applicant shall submit one (1) copy of the sketch plat application package to the City. 
c.  The Planning Department shall review the submittal for completeness within a reasonable period of time and shall notify the applicant of any deficiencies. The applicant shall have an opportunity to make the necessary inclusions or corrections. An incomplete submittal shall not be processed. 
d.  Application. Once the Planning Department has determined that the sketch plat submittal is complete, the City will notify the applicant of the content, format and number of copies of the sketch plat application packets to be submitted to the City. The applicant shall submit an original and a sufficient number of copies of the following application materials, as determined by the Planning Department, for distribution and review by the City. All copies of maps and large sheets shall, unless otherwise requested by the City, be properly folded prior to submittal. 
e.  Neighbor and referral agency meetings. The applicant is encouraged to meet with interested referral agencies, selected from the list in the preliminary plat section of this Chapter, adjacent landowners and homeowners' associations concerning the sketch plat application as required by the City. 
f.  The Planning Department will notify the applicant of the date and time of the Planning Commission meeting. 
g.  Notice to neighbors and mineral owners. Using stamped envelopes provided by the applicant, and at a reasonable time prior to the Planning Commission review of the sketch plat, the City shall send by first-class mail information about the application and the scheduled meeting to owners of property located within five hundred (500) feet of the property being subdivided; owners of minerals and oil and gas leases on the property being subdivided; and other parties of interest as specified by the City. 
h.  Planning Commission meeting. 
1.  The Planning Commission shall evaluate the application and public comments, and make a recommendation to the City Council to approve, approve with conditions or deny the sketch plat. 
2.  The Planning Commission review of the sketch plat is intended to be an open exchange of ideas and may include any or all of the following topics: 
a)  How the proposed project meets the goals of the Comprehensive Plan. 
b)  The applicant's vision and understanding of the market for the proposed development. 
c)  Creative and innovative design concepts proposed for the project. 
d)  How the proposed project will relate to neighboring areas and to the community. 
e)  Environmental issues. 
f)  How the project will promote efficient use of utilities, streets and other public resources. 
g)  The fiscal impact of the project on the community. 
h)  Proposed timing and phasing of the project. 
i.  Following the recommendation by the Planning Commission, the City will schedule the sketch plat for a public meeting with the City Council, and will notify the applicant of the date and time of the meeting. 
j.  City Council meeting. The City Council shall evaluate the sketch plat, the Planning Commission recommendation and other information received, and shall approve, conditionally approve, remand to the Planning Commission or deny the sketch plat. 
k.  If denied by the City Council, the submittal of a new application and processing fee shall be required in order to pursue a subdivision of the same property. A resubmittal of the sketch plat for the same or substantially same request, as determined by the City Council, shall not be accepted within one (1) year of such denial. 
(3)  General submittal requirements. 
a.  Completed land use application. 
b.  Sketch plat application. 
c.  Application fees and fee deposits. 
d.  One (1) set of No. 10 envelopes, stamped with first-class postage, with the City's address as the return address, addressed to: owners of property located within five hundred (500) feet of the property being subdivided; owners of minerals and oil and gas leases on the property being subdivided; and other parties of interest as specified by the City. Also, a written statement by the applicant, indicating the source of all addresses provided. 
e.  Evidence of current ownership of the property being subdivided, acceptable to the City Attorney, such as a copy of the updated title policy or commitment, current within thirty (30) days. 
f.  If the applicant is other than the property owner, a notarized letter of authorization from the landowner permitting a representative to submit the application. 
g.  Sketch plat, described in Paragraph (4) below. 
h.  One (1) set of eleven-by-seventeen-inch reduced paper copies of all plats and maps. 
i.  Development reports, described below. 
(4)  Sketch plat format. 
a.  The sketch plat shall be prepared on twenty-four-inch-by-thirty-six-inch (24" x 36") paper at a scale of 1" = 100', 1" = 200' or another scale approved by the Planning Department. 
b.  The title of the project shall be placed at the top of the sheet. 
c.  Legal description. 
d.  A table listing for each proposed land use: acreage; density; proposed residential units and lot sizes; proposed commercial and industrial floor area ratios. 
e.  Existing land uses, including existing structures on the site, their uses and whether they are to remain on the site. 
f.  Existing streets, street names and easements on or adjacent to the property. 
g.  Location of existing utilities and a description of how the project will be served by utilities. 
h.  A vicinity map at a scale not greater than 1" = 1,000' that depicts the area to be subdivided and the area which surrounds the proposed subdivision within a two-mile radius. 
i.  Contour lines depicted at ten-foot intervals. The City may request that other significant topographic conditions be depicted at greater or lesser intervals where appropriate. 
j.  One-hundred-year floodplains, all existing and proposed watercourses, retention and detention areas, wetlands, aquifer recharge areas, streams and lakes on the affected property and within five hundred (500) feet of such property. 
k.  Note the land use, zoning and ownership of the adjacent land, including the intended future use of the adjacent land, if owned by the applicant. If adjacent land has been subdivided, show adjacent lots. 
l.  Historical or archaeological sites. 
m.  Other significant natural or man-made features within and adjacent to the proposed subdivision. 
n.  All potential hazard areas, including geologic hazard areas; expansive soils; shallow water table; areas of twenty percent (20%) or greater slope or other slope ranges, as determined necessary by the City. 
o.  Significant existing stands of vegetation and identify the type of vegetation. 
p.  Wildlife habitat areas, including breeding grounds, nesting areas, crossings, wintering areas, migratory routes and related matters. 
q.  Conceptual plans for all of the following: 
1.  Local, collector and arterial streets, including principal dimensions. 
2.  Pedestrian and open space systems, including connections to adjacent development, trail connections and open space areas. 
3.  Focal points, community facilities and other special features. 
4.  The treatment of potentially conflicting land uses. 
(5)  Development reports. The applicant shall submit a report with supporting materials and drawings as necessary, addressing the following: 
a.  Site features as depicted on the plan that may affect the evaluation of the proposed development. 
b.  Brief narrative, describing the proposed land uses, the relationship of the plan to the Comprehensive Plan, planned phasing and a forecast of project construction timing. 
c.  Evidence establishing soil suitability based on information from the Soil Conservation Service of the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) or another source acceptable to the City. The report shall include soil types, maps, soil suitability for proposed development, groundwater issues and recommendations regarding structural constraints and erosion control. 
d.  A report on the geologic characteristics of the site, including any potential natural or man-made hazards which would have a significant influence on the proposed uses of the land, a determination of what effect such factors would have and proposed corrective or protective measures. 
e.  A preliminary drainage plan, including estimates of flows and plans for facilities to prevent stormwaters in excess of historic runoff caused by the proposed subdivision from entering, damaging or being carried by conduits, water supply ditches and appurtenant structures and other drainage facilities. 
f.  Evidence that an adequate water supply, sufficient in terms of quality and quantity, is available. For a subdivision of land located within a water district, a letter of commitment to serve the proposed subdivision stating the amount of water available for use within the subdivision and the feasibility of extending service to that area. 
g.  Evidence of the capability to provide sanitary sewer service. For a subdivision of land located within a sanitation district, a letter of commitment to serve the proposed subdivision stating the capacity to serve and feasibility of extending service to that area. 
h.  A description of the availability and adequacy of other necessary services, including but not limited to fire and police protection, schools, recreation, utilities and open space. 
i.  A description of the proposed transportation network establishing the availability and adequacy of the system consistent with the transportation element of the Comprehensive Plan. 
j.  A discussion on the effect of the proposal on significant cultural, archaeological and historical resources and plans for protection of such resources. 
k.  A statement of whether or not there are any commercial mineral deposits on the site. 
l.  A description of how the City's public land dedication requirement will be met. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-22. - Preliminary plat. 
(a)  Intent. 
(1)  The preliminary plat process is an opportunity to review at public hearings the proposed subdivision with respect to the technical requirements, design standards, plans and improvement requirements of the City. Testimony received at public hearings will provide additional insights to be considered in the review. 
(2)  The preliminary plat process is intended to accomplish most or all of the design review and revision that will be required in order to proceed with preparation of a final plat and final design of public improvements. 
(3)  The preliminary plat shall incorporate, to the extent possible, recommendations provided by the Planning Commission and the City Council during the sketch plat process. 
(4)  The preliminary plat and final plat processes may be combined upon the approval of the City Council based upon, but not limited to, the following factors: design, size, public concern, public facilities, services, access and transportation network. 
(b)  Preliminary plat review process. 
(1)  Presubmittal conference. Before submitting an application for approval of a preliminary plat, the applicant shall meet with representatives from the Planning Department to discuss the applicant's intended submittal, the City's application requirements and processes. 
(2)  The applicant shall submit one (1) copy of the preliminary plat application package to the City. 
(3)  The Planning Department shall review the submittal for completeness within a reasonable period of time, and shall notify the applicant of any deficiencies. The applicant shall have an opportunity to make the necessary inclusions or corrections. An incomplete submittal or preliminary plat that is inconsistent with the approved sketch plat shall not be processed. 
(4)  Application. Once the Planning Department has determined that the preliminary plat submittal is complete, the City will notify the applicant of the content, format and number of copies of the preliminary plat application packets to be submitted to the City. The applicant shall submit an original and a sufficient number of copies of the application materials, as determined by the Planning Department, for distribution and review by the City. All copies of maps and large sheets shall, unless otherwise requested by the City, be properly folded prior to submittal. 
(5)  Public hearing date. The City shall set a date for consideration of the preliminary plat by the Planning Commission at a public hearing, and shall notify the applicant of the hearing date. 
(6)  Referral packets. The City will notify the applicant of the content and the number of copies of the preliminary plat referral packets to be submitted to the City for distribution to referral agencies. Referral packets shall be provided by the applicant by a date specified by the Planning Department to ensure timely mailing prior to the Planning Commission hearing, properly folded and compiled in unsealed envelopes, stamped with sufficient first-class postage. Upon receipt of the referral packets from the applicant, the City will address the envelopes and include information on the public hearing process and promptly mail the referral packets. The City will request that the referral agencies return comments in a timely manner for inclusion in Planning Commission packets prior to the public hearing. 
(7)  Referral agencies. Information describing preliminary plat applications shall, in the discretion of the Planning Department, be referred to any or all of the following for review and comment: 
a.  Weld County Planning Department. 
b.  Colorado Department of Transportation. 
c.  Colorado Division of Wildlife. 
d.  School District. 
e.  Sheriff's Department. 
f.  Appropriate special districts. 
g.  Any appropriate utility or ditch company. 
h.  Fire Department. 
i.  Police Department. 
j.  Public Works Department. 
k.  Parks Department. 
l.  Building Department. 
m.  Other interested parties that, in the opinion of the City, may be affected by the proposed development. 
(8)  Design Review Team. The Planning Department will present the application to the DRT for review and comment. 
(9)  Subdivision improvements agreement. The Planning Department and the applicant will commence negotiations on the terms of a subdivision improvements agreement that shall, at a minimum, contain provisions addressing any or all of the issues listed below: 
a.  List of all public improvements to be constructed, paid for and warranted by the subdivider, and cost estimates for such public improvements as approved by the City Engineer. 
b.  Terms under which the City may use security that has been provided to assure construction of and payment for public improvements. 
c.  Provisions for cash in lieu of public land dedication, if approved. 
d.  Development phasing. 
e.  Any approved private maintenance of public improvements. 
f.  Provisions to mitigate anticipated negative fiscal impact of a subdivision on the City. 
g.  Other provisions that are specific to a subdivision. 
(10)  Publication. The City will publish notice of the Planning Commission hearing date, time and location in a timely manner prior to the hearing. In the event that the date of the subsequent City Council hearing can be anticipated at this time, notice of the City Council hearing may be combined with this notice. 
(11)  Posting. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the Planning Commission public hearing, the applicant shall post the property with a notice of the hearings as required by the Planning Department. Posting shall consist of at least one (1) sign facing and clearly legible from and within fifty (50) feet of each adjacent public street. These notices shall be in the form of signs measuring not less than three (3) feet by four (4) feet, with lettering a minimum of three (3) inches high and on posts no less than four (4) feet above the ground. Signs shall contain the following language, and shall include scheduled hearing dates: 
PUBLIC NOTICE 
A land use application is under review by the 
City of Fort Lupton. 
Public hearings have been scheduled for: 
Planning Commission: Tuesday, ____, 20___ 
City Council: Monday, ________, 20___ 
Time: 7:00 p.m. 
Location: 130 South McKinley Avenue 
CONTACT THE PLANNING DEPARTMENT AT: 
303-857-6694 
(12)  Notice to neighbors and mineral owners. Using stamped and addressed envelopes provided by the applicant, and at a reasonable time prior to the Planning Commission public hearing, the City shall send by first-class mail information about the application and the scheduled public hearings to owners of property located within five hundred (500) feet of the property being subdivided; owners of minerals and oil and gas leases on the property being subdivided; and other parties of interest as specified by the City. 
(13)  Neighbor and referral agency meetings. The applicant is encouraged to meet with interested referral agencies, adjacent landowners and homeowners' associations concerning the preliminary plat. 
(14)  Planning Commission hearing. The Planning Commission shall consider the application, referral comments and public testimony at a public hearing, and shall make a recommendation to the City Council to approve, approve with conditions or deny the preliminary plat. The Planning Commission's comments shall be based on the evidence presented, conformance with the Comprehensive Plan and compliance with the City's standards, regulations and policies. 
(15)  The Planning Department shall advise the applicant of the Planning Commission decision and of any conditions contained in the Planning Commission's recommendation to the City Council. 
(16)  Revisions. By a date specified by the Planning Department to permit timely distribution to the City Council, the applicant shall submit revisions and/or provide documentation to the Planning Department addressing the Planning Commission's concerns and recommendations. 
(17)  Following the recommendation by the Planning Commission, the City will schedule consideration of the preliminary plat by the City Council at a public hearing or affirm the date previously set, and shall notify the applicant of the hearing date and time. 
(18)  Publication. Unless previously published, the City will publish notice of the City Council hearing date, time and location in a timely manner prior to the hearing. 
(19)  Posting. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the City Council public hearing, the applicant shall post the property with a notice of the hearing as required by the Planning Department. Posting shall consist of at least one (1) sign facing and clearly legible from and within fifty (50) feet of each adjacent public street. These notices shall be in the form of signs measuring not less than three (3) feet by four (4) feet, with lettering a minimum of three (3) inches high and on posts no less than four (4) feet above the ground.
