The sign shall be updated as necessary and shall contain the language as required for the preliminary plat posting. 
(20)  City Council hearing. The City Council shall conduct a public hearing and evaluate the preliminary plat, referral agency comments, Planning Commission recommendation and public testimony, and shall approve, conditionally approve, continue for additional information or for further study or deny the preliminary plat and the subdivision improvements agreement. The City Council's action shall be based on the evidence presented, compliance with the adopted standards, regulations and policies and other guidelines. 
(21)  If denied by the City Council, the submittal of a new application and processing fee shall be required in order to pursue the proposed subdivision. A resubmittal of the preliminary plat application for the same or substantially same request, as determined by the City Council, shall not be accepted within one (1) year of such denial. 
(c)  General submittal requirements. 
(1)  Completed preliminary plat application form. 
(2)  A narrative outlining the proposal. 
(3)  Additional fee deposit if required. 
(4)  A copy of the recorded warranty deed and title commitment or updated title commitment current within thirty (30) days. 
(5)  Preliminary plat (described in Subsection (d) below). 
(6)  Development reports (described in Subsection (e) below). 
(7)  One (1) set of No. 10 envelopes, stamped with first-class postage, with the City's address as the return address, addressed to: owners of property located within five hundred (500) feet of the property being subdivided; owners of mineral and oil and gas leases on the property being subdivided; and other parties of interest as specified by the City. Also, a statement by the applicant, indicating the source of all addresses provided. 
(d)  Preliminary plat format. The preliminary plat shall be drawn according to the following specifications and shall contain the specified information: 
(1)  The preliminary plat shall be prepared on twenty-four-inch-by-thirty-six-inch paper at a scale of 1" = 50', 1" = 100' or another scale approved by the Planning Director. 
(2)  The name of the subdivision shall be placed at the top of the sheet along the long dimension of each sheet. Subdivision names shall not duplicate existing subdivision names. 
(3)  Legal description, including the portion of the Section, Township, Range, 6th P.M. 
(4)  The total acreage. 
(5)  A block in the lower right-hand corner shall include the following: the preparation date; a north arrow designated as true north; a written and graphic scale; the names and addresses of the applicant, developer, engineer or surveyor who prepared the exhibit; sheet number and the total number of sheets. 
(6)  The boundary of the proposed subdivision in a heavy solid line. Areas not included in the subdivision designated as "Not included in this plat." 
(7)  A vicinity map that depicts the area to be subdivided and the area which surrounds the proposed subdivision within a one-mile radius. 
(8)  Depict all lots, tracts and, when appropriate, building envelopes, providing accurate dimensions for each. Lots and blocks shall be numbered consecutively; tracts shall be lettered alphabetically. On plats proposed for residential development, designation of parcels as "tracts" shall be used exclusively for nonresidential uses, such as areas to be dedicated to the City for park or school sites. 
(9)  Depict all streets, street names, easements, including existing and proposed, public or private, on and adjacent to the proposed subdivision, their use, principal dimensions and the owner or right holder of the easement along with the recorded book and page number and the name of the entity responsible for construction or maintenance. 
(10)  Show existing topographic contour lines at two-foot intervals. The City may request that other significant topographic conditions be depicted at greater or lesser intervals where appropriate. 
(11)  Delineate all one-hundred-year floodplains, all existing and proposed watercourses, retention and detention areas, wetlands, aquifer recharge areas, streams and lakes on the affected property and within one hundred (100) feet of such property. 
(12)  The location and dimensions of existing and proposed water and sewer lines and all other utilities. 
(13)  Depict all lands to be dedicated or reserved for the use of landowners, residents, public agencies or the general public. Include notes to indicate the disposition and maintenance responsibility for all such tracts. 
(14)  Boundaries of proposed phases of the development, if any. 
(15)  Locate and provide the names and dimensions of all street rights-of-way. 
(16)  Depict legal and physical public accesses to the proposed subdivision even if not part of the subdivision. 
(17)  Names, adjoining boundaries and zoning of adjacent subdivisions. 
(18)  Adjoining boundaries of adjacent parcels of land and the names of owners of such parcels. 
(19)  Note existing structures on the site, their uses and whether they are to remain on the site. 
(e)  Development reports. The applicant shall submit a report with supporting materials and completely address the items listed below as a minimum. The degree of detail for analysis of some of the following factors will depend upon the impact of the particular item on the surrounding area and the subject property. 
(1)  Street plans and profiles. 
(2)  A preliminary drainage report, erosion control plan and grading plan. 
(3)  Utility plans prepared in accordance with the regulations of the appropriate service provider. 
(4)  A preliminary landscape plan for the subdivision, including landscaping within rights-of-way, as specified by the Planning Department or by an adopted landscape plan. 
(5)  Letters of support and commitment to serve from all proposed utilities and service providers. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1; Ord. 2010-914 §3) 
Sec. 17-23. - Final plat. 
(a)  Intent. 
(1)  The final plat process is intended to provide for the review of the final engineering plans, the subdivision improvements agreement and public land dedications. 
(2)  The final plat shall be in substantial compliance with the approved preliminary plat and with any conditions of such approval set by the City Council. 
(b)  Final plat review process. 
(1)  The applicant shall submit one (1) copy of the final plat and all supporting information to the City. 
(2)  The Planning Department shall review the submittal for completeness within a reasonable period of time and shall notify the applicant of any deficiencies. The applicant shall have an opportunity to make the necessary inclusions or corrections. An incomplete submittal or final plat that is inconsistent with the approved preliminary plat shall not be processed. 
(3)  Application. Once the Planning Department has determined that the final plat submittal is complete, the City will notify the applicant of the content, format and number of copies of the final plat application packets to be submitted to the City. The applicant shall submit an original and a sufficient number of copies of the application materials, as determined by the Planning Department, for distribution and review by City departments. All copies of maps and large sheets shall, unless otherwise requested by the City, be properly folded prior to submittal. 
(4)  Meeting date. After approval of all documents by the appropriate entity, the City shall schedule the final plat for review by the City Council at a public meeting. The City shall notify the applicant of the date and time of the public meeting. 
(5)  Subdivision improvements agreement. The subdivision improvements agreement shall be reviewed by the City Attorney and be signed by the applicant prior to consideration of the final plat by the City Council. Cost estimates for public improvements shall be as approved by the City Engineer. 
(6)  City Council meeting. The City Council shall evaluate the final plat. If all conditions of the preliminary plat approval are met and all standards of the City are met, the City Council shall consider a resolution approving the final plat. 
(7)  If denied by the City Council, the submittal of a new application and processing fee shall be required in order to pursue the proposed subdivision. A resubmittal of the final plat application for the same or substantially same request, as determined by the City Council, shall not be accepted within one (1) year of such denial. 
(8)  If approved, the City shall obtain all required City signatures and record the final plat. 
(c)  Recording. The City will record the approved final plat and the SIA in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder. 
(d)  General submittal requirements. The final plat application shall contain the following items: 
(1)  Completed final plat application form. 
(2)  Additional fee deposit, if required. 
(3)  A copy of the updated title commitment current within thirty (30) days. 
(4)  Two (2) signed original Mylar final plats in a form suitable for recording with the County Clerk and Recorder. 
(5)  Final plat reports and documents (described below). 
(6)  A check, payable to the Weld County Clerk and Recorder, for the full cost of recording the final plat and the Subdivision Improvements Agreement. 
(e)  Plat exhibit. The final plat shall substantially conform to the approved preliminary plat and the City Council's conditions of approval. 
(1)  The final plat shall be prepared by or under the supervision of and shall bear the seal of a registered professional land surveyor licensed with the State for recording in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder. It shall be a neat, clear, permanent, legible and reproducible document. Inaccurate, incomplete or poorly drawn plats shall be rejected. 
(2)  The final plat shall be either an original drawing using only permanent black ink that will adhere to drafting films (no ballpoint, transfer type or sticky-backs are permitted) or an acceptable photographic reproduction (fix-line, emulsion down) of an original drawing. 
(3)  The final plat shall be prepared on twenty-four-inches-high-by-thirty-six-inches-wide flat, spliceless, tapeless and creaseless sheets of double matte Mylar film with a uniform thickness of not less than three-thousandths (.003) of an inch. A margin line shall be drawn completely around each sheet, leaving a margin of at least one-half (1/2) inch on all sides entirely blank. 
(4)  The final plat shall be drafted at a scale that best conveys the detailed survey, engineering and design of the subdivision and confines the drafting error to less than one percent (1%). Acceptable scales are 1" = 50' or 1" = 100'. When a proposal requires multiple sheets, a composite, on a paper measuring twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches, shall be provided that delineates the boundaries and identifies each sheet number. 
(5)  The title shall be placed at the top of the sheet along the long dimension of each sheet and shall include the name of the proposed subdivision or planned development and filing number (where applicable). A general legal description stating the portion of the Section, Township, Range, 6th P.M. and "City of Fort Lupton, County of Weld, State of Colorado," shall be included under the name and planning area. On the title sheet (Sheet #1), under the general legal description, include the total acreage. 
(6)  A block in the lower right-hand corner shall include the following: the preparation date; a north arrow designated as true north; a written and graphic scale; the names and addresses of the applicant, developer, engineer or surveyor who prepared the exhibit; and the number of the sheet and the total number of sheets. 
(7)  A vicinity map that depicts the area to be subdivided and the area which surrounds the proposed subdivision within a one-mile radius. 
(8)  A written metes-and-bounds legal description of the subdivision boundary with a map showing all information as required in the state statutes shall be clearly and prominently indicated on the final plat. The names and locations of all abutting subdivisions and the locations of all abutting unplatted parcels and public lands shall be depicted. All lines, names and descriptions on the final plat which do not constitute a part of the subdivision shall be depicted in dashed or screened lines. Any area enclosed by the subdivision, but not a part thereof, shall be labeled "Not a part of this Subdivision." 
(9)  Deleted lot lines, easements or rights-of-way shall be shown on the plat in dashed lines, or screened, with a note and arrow pointing to the item to be vacated, stating that the lot line, easement or right-of-way is hereby vacated. (Dashed lines shall be graphically different for existing vs. proposed vs. deleted, with a legend provided.) 
(10)  Display ties to section corners and to the state grid, if available, which show dimensions of all primary boundary survey control points with complete monument and location descriptions, all parcel lines showing dimensions with lengths, bearings and curve data, including chord lengths and bearings, and basis of bearings and relation to true meridian and similar data. Only circular curves shall be used. No spirals, parabolas, etc., shall be used. All dimensions are to be shown to the nearest one-hundredth (0.01) foot or, in the case of degrees, to the nearest second. An accuracy of 1:50,000 (second order) minimum for linear and angular (bearing) closure shall be required for the boundary. All internal lots, tracts or parcels shall have a closure accuracy of one-hundredth (0.01) foot. 
(11)  All lots, tracts and appropriate building envelopes shall be located, identified and labeled with the appropriate dimension with sufficient linear, bearing and curve data. No ditto marks shall be used for dimensions. All lots and, whenever practical, blocks shall be shown in their entirety on one (1) sheet. Lots shall be consecutively numbered and tracts shall be lettered alphabetically and in consecutive order. Include the acreage within each lot or tract, or include in a table to the nearest one hundredth (0.01) of an acre. Tract designations shall be used exclusively for nonresidential property, such as areas to be dedicated for park and school sites. All parcels or areas of land inadvertently created and not identified shall not be considered to be building lots. 
(12)  All street names, right-of-way widths at each leg of an intersection, at point of curve and point of tangent, at dead-ends and at angle points; and right-of-way line with accurate bearings and dimensions, including chord lengths and bearings, central angles and radii of all curves. If any street in the subdivision is a continuation or approximately a continuation of an existing public street, the conformity or the amount of conformity of the new street to the existing street shall be accurately shown. Whenever the centerline of a street has been established or recorded, the date shall be shown on the final plat. 
(13)  The purpose, widths and location (with fine dashed lines) of all easements and all abutting easements. Any easement already of record must be definitely located, and a statement of its existence, the nature thereof and its recorded reference must appear on the title sheet. Distances and bearings on the side lines of lots which are cut by an easement must be shown with an arrow or so shown that the plat will indicate clearly the actual length of the lot lines. The widths of all easements and sufficient data to definitely locate the same with respect to the subdivision and each lot must be shown. All easements must be clearly labeled and identified. If an easement shown on the plat is already of record, its recorded reference must be given. If an easement is being dedicated by the plat, it shall be set out in the owner's certificate of dedication. A plat note may be necessary to provide complete information of the purpose of the easement. 
(14)  Accurately locate one-hundred-year floodplains, all existing and proposed watercourses, retention and detention areas, wetlands, aquifer recharge areas, streams, lakes, inlets, storm sewers and culverts on the affected property. 
(15)  Certifications on a single sheet as specified below. 
(16)  Names and signatures of all owners of equitable interest in the property being subdivided shall be on the plat and shall be made in black permanent drawing ink. 
(17)  Plat notes which adequately explain information pertinent to the execution and maintenance of the subdivision, including the ownership of tracts, reference to the subdivision improvements agreement and conservation easements, maintenance responsibility for private streets, easements and tracts, and limitations on wells or septic systems. 
(f)  Final development reports and documents. The applicant shall submit the supporting materials necessary for the review of the final plat which address the following items: 
(1)  Final drainage report, if revisions were required at the time of preliminary plat approval, and drainage construction drawings. 
(2)  Final street construction plans. 
(3)  Final utility construction drawings prepared in accordance with the requirements of the appropriate service provider. 
(4)  Park facilities master plan and construction plans. 
(5)  Final landscape plan. 
(6)  Construction cost estimates for all public improvements. 
(7)  A signed copy of the subdivision improvements agreement. The developer shall provide for the construction, at no cost to the City, of traffic signalization, all utilities and other public infrastructure, as required by the City Council, and provide an irrevocable letter of credit in the amount of one hundred twenty-five percent (125%) of the approved cost of all public improvements, or other security needed to ensure such improvements, as required by the City Council. 
(8)  A signed warranty deed and title insurance, if such has been required, conveying certain tracts, or the development rights to such tracts, to the appropriate entity for public use. 
(9)  Warranty deeds to the City and title insurance shall be provided for rights-of-way in and adjacent to the subdivision reflecting the appropriate widths. The final plat shall not be recorded until all warranty deeds are accepted by the City. 
(10)  Water rights or an equivalent cash amount, as approved by the City, sufficient to serve the property. 
(11)  Additional documents as required by the City, including any or all of the following: 
a.  Colorado Department of Transportation permits for utilities and access. 
b.  Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment construction dewatering permit. 
c.  Army Corps of Engineers 404 permit. 
d.  Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment Air Pollution Emission Notice. 
e.  Permits from ditch companies for work in ditch rights-of-way. 
f.  U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Rare Species Occurrence Survey. 
g.  FEMA-approved applications, including Conditional Letter of Map Revisions (CLOMR) or Letter of Map Revisions (LOMR). 
h.  Draft of proposed protective covenants. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Secs. 17-24-17-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III - Minor Subdivisions 

Sec. 17-30. - General. 
(a)  Intent. The minor subdivision process is intended to expedite the processing of subdivisions that are minor in size and scope. 
(b)  Inclusion of all property. The boundary of a minor subdivision plat shall include the entire parcel being subdivided. For example, the division of an eighty-acre parcel for the purpose of selling one (1) five-acre lot will require that the parcel be platted into two (2) lots: one (1) of five (5) acres and one (1) of seventy-five (75) acres. 
(c)  Definition. A minor subdivision is a subdivision that meets all of the following conditions: 
(1)  There are no public rights-of-way dedicated. 
(2)  The entire subdivision consists of a total of four (4) or fewer lots. This is not to be interpreted as four (4) additional lots in the case of a resubdivision of existing lots. 
(3)  All proposed lots meet the requirements of the zoning and subdivision regulations of the City. 
(4)  There have not been other minor plats within the same subdivision that, in combination with the proposed minor plat, would circumvent the intent of this Chapter. 
(d)  Minor subdivision review process. 
(1)  Preapplication conference and site visit. Before submitting an application for a minor subdivision, the applicant shall meet with representatives from the Planning Department to discuss the applicant's intended submittal, the City's application requirements and processes, the Comprehensive Plan, the possible need for a subdivision improvements agreement, development standards and other information relevant to development of the property. The meeting might also include a visit to the site. 
(2)  The applicant shall submit one (1) copy of the minor subdivision plat and all supporting information to the City. 
(3)  The Planning Department shall review the submittal for completeness within a reasonable period of time and shall notify the applicant of any deficiencies. The applicant shall have an opportunity to make the necessary inclusions or corrections. An incomplete submittal shall not be processed. 
(4)  Application. Once the Planning Department has determined that the minor subdivision submittal is complete, the City will notify the applicant of the content, format and number of copies of the minor subdivision application packets to be submitted to the City. The applicant shall submit an original and a sufficient number of copies of the application materials, as determined by the Planning Department, for distribution and review by the City. All copies of maps and large sheets shall, unless otherwise requested by the City, be properly folded prior to submittal. 
(5)  All minor subdivision applications shall be referred to the departments and agencies for review and comment as listed in the requirements for a preliminary plat. 
(6)  The applicant shall notify the adjacent landowners and homeowners' association of the minor subdivision application as required by the City. 
(7)  Neighbor and referral agency meetings. The applicant is encouraged to meet with the referral agencies to address any issues prior to the Planning Commission consideration of the minor subdivision. 
(8)  When the Public Works Department has accepted all final engineering plans and the minor subdivision plat in writing, the Planning Department shall schedule the minor subdivision application for a public hearing by the Planning Commission. The City will notify the applicant of the date and time of the public meeting. 
(9)  Public hearing date. The City shall set a date for the Planning Commission public hearing to consider the minor subdivision, and shall notify the applicant of the hearing date. 
(10)  Referral packets. The City will notify the applicant of the content and the number of copies of the minor subdivision referral packets to be submitted to the City for distribution to referral agencies. Referral packets shall be provided by the applicant by a date specified by the Planning Department to ensure timely distribution prior to the Planning Commission hearing, properly folded and compiled in unsealed envelopes, stamped with sufficient first-class postage. Upon receipt of the referral packets from the applicant, the City will include information on the public hearing process and promptly mail the referral packets. The City will request that the referral agencies return comments in a timely manner for inclusion in Planning Commission packets prior to the public hearing. 
(11)  Publication. The City will publish notice of the Planning Commission hearing date, time and location in a timely manner prior to the hearing. In the event that the date of the subsequent City Council hearing can be anticipated at that time, notice of the City Council hearing may be combined with this notice. 
(12)  Posting. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the Planning Commission public hearing, the applicant shall post the property with a notice of the hearing as required by the Planning Department. Posting shall consist of at least one (1) sign facing and clearly legible from each adjacent public street. These notices shall be as specified for preliminary plats. 
(13)  Notice to neighbors and mineral owners. Using stamped and addressed envelopes provided by the applicant, and at a reasonable time prior to the Planning Commission public hearing, the City shall send by first-class mail information about the application and the scheduled public hearing to owners of property located within one hundred (100) feet of the property being subdivided; owners of mineral and oil and gas leases on the property being subdivided and other parties of interest as specified by the City. 
(14)  Neighbor and referral agency meetings. The applicant is encouraged to meet with interested referral agencies, adjacent landowners and homeowners' associations concerning the minor subdivision. 
(15)  Planning Commission hearing. The Planning Commission shall consider the application, referral comments and public testimony at a public hearing, and shall make a recommendation to the City Council to approve, approve with conditions or deny the minor subdivision. The Planning Commission's comments shall be based on the evidence presented, conformance with the Comprehensive Plan and compliance with the City's standards, regulations and policies. 
(16)  Public hearing date. Following the recommendation by the Planning Commission, the City will schedule consideration of the minor subdivision by the City Council at a public hearing and will notify the applicant of the hearing date and time. 
(17)  Subdivision improvements agreement. The Planning Department and the applicant will commence negotiations on the terms of a subdivision improvements agreement, if necessary, that shall contain provisions addressing relevant issues as listed in the SIA provisions for major plats. 
(18)  Publication. The City will publish notice of the City Council hearing date, time and location in a timely manner prior to the hearing. 
(19)  Posting. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the City Council public hearing, the applicant shall post the property with a notice of the hearing as required by the Planning Department. Posting shall consist of at least one (1) sign facing and clearly legible from each adjacent public street. These notices shall be as specified for preliminary plats. 
(20)  City Council hearing. The City Council shall evaluate the minor subdivision, referral agency comments, Planning Commission recommendation and public testimony, and shall approve, conditionally approve, continue for additional information or for further study or deny the minor subdivision and, if necessary, the subdivision improvements agreement. The City Council's action shall be based on the evidence presented, compliance with the adopted standards, regulations and policies and other guidelines. 
(21)  If denied by the City Council, the submittal of a new application and processing fee shall be required in order to pursue the proposed subdivision. A resubmittal of the minor subdivision application for the same or substantially same request, as determined by the City Council, shall not be accepted within one (1) year of such denial. 
(22)  Recording. The City will record the approved final plat and the SIA in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder. The City shall obtain all required City signatures and record the final plat. 
(e)  General minor subdivision application requirements. 
(1)  Completed minor subdivision application. 
(2)  Application fee and fee deposit. 
(3)  A copy of an updated title commitment current within thirty (30) days. 
(4)  A notarized letter of authorization from the landowner permitting a representative to process the application. 
(5)  Complete and signed minor subdivision plat. 
(6)  Written narrative description of the proposed minor subdivision. 
(7)  Development reports (described below). 
(f)  Minor subdivision plat format. The minor subdivision plat shall be drawn according to the following specifications and shall contain the specified information: 
(1)  The minor subdivision plat shall be prepared by or under the supervision of, and shall bear the seal of, a registered professional land surveyor licensed with the State for recording in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder. It shall be a neat, clear, permanent, legible and reproducible document. Inaccurate, incomplete or poorly drawn plats shall be rejected. 
(2)  The minor subdivision plat shall be drafted according to the format and specifications for a major subdivision final plat. 
(g)  Development reports and documents. The applicant shall submit the supporting materials necessary for the review of the minor subdivision which address the following items listed below: 
(1)  Final drainage report and drainage construction drawings. 
(2)  A signed copy of the subdivision improvements agreement, if required by the City. 
(3)  Evidence that an adequate water supply, sufficient in terms of quality and quantity, is available. For a subdivision of land located within a water district, a letter of commitment to serve the proposed subdivision stating the amount of water available for use within the subdivision and the feasibility of extending service to that area. 
(4)  Water rights or an equivalent cash amount, as approved by the City, sufficient to serve the property. 
(5)  Evidence of the physical and legal capability to provide sanitary sewer service. For a subdivision of land located within a sanitation district, a letter of commitment to serve the proposed subdivision stating the capacity to serve and feasibility of extending service to that area. 
(h)  Recording procedure. The process of recording the minor subdivision plat in the records of the County Clerk and Recorder shall follow the process as specified above for a major subdivision final plat. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Secs. 17-31-17-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV - Amended Plats 

Sec. 17-40. - General. 
(a)  Intent. The amended plat process is an administrative process to amend a recorded Plat. 
(b)  Definition. An amended subdivision is an administrative revision to a recorded subdivision or a portion of a recorded subdivision that meets all of the following conditions: 
(1)  The application is only to adjust existing lot lines or to correct drafting or technical errors in a properly approved and recorded plat. 
(2)  There are no public rights-of-way dedicated. 
(3)  There is no net increase in the number of lots. 
(4)  The boundaries of ten (10) or fewer lots are changed. 
(5)  All required public improvements are installed and improved, or such installation is guaranteed through the requirements of this Chapter or of the Comprehensive Plan. 
(6)  There have not been other amended plats within the same subdivision that, in combination with the proposed amended plat, would circumvent the intent of this Chapter; and 
(7)  All proposed lots meet the requirements of the zoning and subdivision regulations of the City. 
(c)  Amended plat review process. 
(1)  Preapplication conference and site visit. Before submitting an application for an amended plat, the applicant shall meet with representatives from the Planning Department to discuss the applicant's intended submittal, the City's application requirements and processes, the Comprehensive Plan, development standards and other information relevant to development of the property. The meeting might also include a visit to the site. 
(2)  The applicant shall submit one (1) copy of the amended plat and all supporting information to the City. 
(3)  The Planning Department shall review the submittal for completeness and for conformance with the City's plans, policies and regulations within a reasonable period of time and shall notify the applicant of any deficiencies. The applicant shall have an opportunity to make the necessary inclusions or corrections. An incomplete submittal shall not be processed. 
(4)  Application. Once the Planning Department has determined that the amended plat submittal is complete, the City will notify the applicant of the content, format and number of copies of the amended plat application packets to be submitted to the City. The applicant shall submit an original and a sufficient number of copies of the application materials, as determined by the Planning Department, for distribution and review by the City. All copies of maps and large sheets shall, unless otherwise requested by the City, be properly folded prior to submittal. 
(5)  All amended plat applications shall be referred to appropriate departments and agencies, as determined by the Planning Department, for review and comment. 
(6)  When the Public Works Department and the City Engineer have reviewed and approved the amended plat and the plans for any required public improvements modifications, the Mylars shall be signed by the City Administrator and the Director of Public Works. 
(d)  General amended plat application requirements. 
(1)  Completed amended plat application. 
(2)  Two (2) Mylars of the final amended plat, signed by the owner. 
(3)  Additional paper copies of the final amended plat as required by the Planning Department. 
(4)  Application fee and fee deposit. 
(5)  A copy of an updated title commitment current within thirty (30) days. 
(6)  A notarized letter of authorization from the landowner permitting a representative to process the application. 
(7)  Final plans for any utility modifications or other modifications of public improvements that will be required to serve the new lot configuration. 
(8)  A check, payable to the Weld County Clerk and Recorder, in the total amount of the recording fee. 
(e)  Amended plat format. The amended plat shall be drawn according to the following specifications and shall contain the specified information: 
(1)  The amended plat shall be prepared by or under the supervision of, and shall bear the seal of, a registered professional land surveyor licensed with the State for recording in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder. It shall be a neat, clear, permanent, legible and reproducible document. Inaccurate, incomplete or poorly drawn plats shall be rejected. 
(2)  The amended plat shall be drafted according to the format and specifications for a major subdivision final plat. 
(3)  The amended plat shall contain a statement indicating the name of the recorded plat that is being amended and the recording information, referencing the original plat location in the County records. 
(f)  Recording procedure. The process of recording an amended plat in the records of the County Clerk and Recorder shall follow the process as specified above for a major subdivision final plat. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Secs. 17-41-17-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V - Certifications 

Sec. 17-50. - Certifications required. 
    The following certifications must appear on final plats, minor subdivision plats and amended plats that are submitted to the City: 
(1)  Final plat certifications. 
a.  Description. 
b.  Dedication. 
c.  Owner's approval. 
d.  Notary. 
e.  Surveyor's certificate. 
f.  Surveyor's improvement certificate. 
g.  Easement approval. 
h.  City Engineer's approval. 
i.  Planning Commission approval. 
j.  Mayor's certificate (resolution). 
k.  City Administrator's approval. 
l.  Public Works Department approval. 
(2)  Minor plat certifications. 
a.  Description. 
b.  Dedication. 
c.  Owner's approval. 
d.  Notary. 
e.  Surveyor's certificate. 
f.  Surveyor's improvement certificate. 
g.  Easement approval. 
h.  City Engineer's approval. 
i.  Planning Commission approval. 
j.  Mayor's certificate (resolution). 
k.  City Administrator's approval. 
l.  Public Works Department approval. 
(3)  Amended plat certifications. 
a.  Description. 
b.  Dedication. 
c.  Owner's approval. 
d.  Notary. 
e.  Surveyor's certificate. 
f.  Surveyor's improvement certificate. 
g.  Easement approval. 
h.  City Administrator's approval. 
i.  Public Works Department approval. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Pt. 1) 
Sec. 17-51. - Certifications. 
(a)  Description. 
    A plat of a parcel of land in the City of Fort Lupton, Colorado, located in the _____1/4 ____1/4, Section ___ T___N R___W of the 6th P.M. and more particularly described as follows: 
Beginning at the ... (LEGAL DESCRIPTION) ... containing ____ acres. 
(b)  Dedication. 
    Know All Men By These Presents, that we . . . (names of all landowners) . . . being the sole owners of the land described herein, have caused said land to be laid out and platted under the name of _________, and do hereby dedicate to the City of Fort Lupton and its licensees for public use forever all streets, alleys and utility easements as indicated hereon. In compliance with the City of Fort Lupton Subdivision Regulations and by contractual agreement, the landowners shall bear all expenses involved in improvements. 
    IN WITNESS WHEREOF, we have hereunto set our hands and seals this ____ day of ______________, 20__. 
_________________ 
(c)  Notary certificate.

ARTICLE VI - Design Standards 

Sec. 17-60. - Design standards. 
    The general location and alignment of streets and lot size shall conform to the Comprehensive Plan and zoning requirements of the City. The design and construction of all public and private improvements within the subdivision shall conform to adopted building codes, the City of Fort Lupton Residential Design Standards, the City of Fort Lupton Commercial and Industrial Design Standards and the City of Fort Lupton Standards and Specifications for the Design and Construction of Public Improvements, as revised. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Part 1; Ord. 2007-888, Part 4; Ord. 2007-895, Part 5) 
Secs. 17-61-17-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII - Public Land Dedication 

Sec. 17-70. - General. 
(a)  Intent. Applicants for approval of new subdivisions that create a demand for parks, schools and public facilities shall be required to dedicate and, if necessary, reserve sufficient and appropriate land and/or funds to purchase sufficient land to accommodate such public facilities. 
(b)  Land dedication. Payments and dedications made under the requirements of this Section shall be made payable or dedicated to the City at the time of final plat approval. Land dedicated to the City shall be free and clear of all liens and encumbrances. The applicant shall provide for the installation of all street improvements adjacent to dedicated park and school sites, the installation of water, sewer and other public utilities to dedicated park and school site property lines, and overlot grading of the park and school sites. 
(c)  Land reservation. In addition to any requirement for dedication of land for public facilities, the City may require reservation of additional lands within the boundaries of a proposed subdivision when such reservation is necessary to provide viable sites for public facilities. Reservation of such additional land shall be for purchase at fair market value, or for other mutually agreeable consideration, within a reasonable period of time. Terms of the reservation shall be included in the subdivision improvements agreement. 
(d)  Use of dedicated land. Land dedicated for public use under the provisions of this Chapter shall be used for parks, schools, fire stations or other public facilities. Land or fees for school sites may be transferred to the School District according to agreements between the City and the District. Use of dedicated land may be specified in the subdivision improvements agreement. 
(e)  Fee in lieu of dedication. If there is not sufficient property on the plat to provide land for the entire school, park or other public facility required, with the approval of the City Council, the subdivider may, in lieu of dedication of all or part of the land requirements, pay fees equivalent to the value of required land dedication. Fees are to be calculated in the following manner: 
(1)  Fees shall be calculated based on the full market value of the land, assuming that the plat has been approved and proper zoning exists. 
(2)  Full market value shall be determined by mutual agreement between the subdivider and the City Council. In the event of inability of any of the above parties to agree on the value of the required land dedication, the subdivider shall submit to the City a written appraisal from a qualified appraiser meeting the value requirements set forth herein. Said appraisal shall be made by an individual or entity that does not have a financial interest in the subdivision and shall be a member of the Appraisal Institute, a member of the Society of Real Estate Appraisers or such other qualified person mutually agreeable to the administrator and the applicant. The applicant shall pay the cost of said appraisal. 
(3)  Such appraisal may be submitted during the review period of the final plat. If the City Council believes that the appraised value is not accurate, it may obtain its own appraisal from a qualified appraiser or determine the fair market value by such procedure as the City Council deems appropriate. 
(4)  All fees in lieu of dedications are to be paid prior to the approval of the final plat unless otherwise agreed by the City Council in the subdivision improvements agreement. 
(5)  For subdivisions that are platted in phases, the above calculations can be made on a phase-by-phase basis through methods to be devised by the City Council realizing that, by virtue of developing one (1) phase, the value of the undeveloped adjacent phase will increase. The subdivider has the option of paying the fees for all phases upon the due date of fees for the first phase. 
(f)  Land unacceptable for dedication. Land proposed for dedication shall be appropriate for the proposed uses as determined by the City Council in its sole discretion. Small remnants of land, rugged or hazardous sites, drainage ways, land encumbered by easements and land that is otherwise inappropriate for public use will not be acceptable in fulfillment of public land dedication requirements. 
(g)  Plat of dedicated and reserved land. The final subdivision plat shall include all land to be dedicated or reserved for public use as separate and defined tracts. The plat shall include appropriate dedication certifications as required by the City. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Part 1) 
Sec. 17-71. - Requirements. 
(a)  Land dedication requirements for residential subdivisions. 
(1)  The amount of land to be dedicated to the City as a condition of approval of a final plat of a residential subdivision shall be ten (10) acres per one thousand (1,000) residents who might potentially occupy the subdivision. Residential occupancy shall be calculated at a rate of three (3) residents per single-family dwelling, and two and one-half (2.5) residents per multi-family dwelling. The number of potential dwellings within a subdivision shall be the maximum number of units that could be built on the property, considering the subdivision configuration and the ultimate zoning. 
(2)  School sites. The amount of land to be dedicated to the City or cash in lieu of land for school sites as a condition of approval of a final plat shall be based on the prevailing student generation and corresponding facility demand estimates published by the School District. 
(b)  Land dedication requirements for nonresidential subdivisions. The amount of land to be dedicated to the City as a condition of approval of a final plat of a nonresidential subdivision shall be five percent (5%) of the gross land area within the subdivision. 
(Ord. 2006-869 Part 1) 
Secs. 17-72-17-80. - Reserved. 
CHAPTER 18 - Building Regulations 
ARTICLE I - Administration and Building Permits 

Sec. 18-1. - Building permit applications. 
(a)  All applications for building permits shall comply with the requirements set forth in the adopted Building Code. 
(b)  All applications shall be accompanied by: (1) a plan (to scale) showing dimensions of lot, location of all buildings (existing and new), streets, alleys and easements; (2) two (2) complete sets of plans and specifications showing elevations, size of building, floor plan of all floors including unfinished areas (such as basement), a wall section; and (3) any additional information as may be necessary to provide for the enforcement of these regulations and as requested by the Building Official. 
(Ord. 518 §9.01.1, 1984; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 2014-980 §1) 
Sec. 18-2. - Certificate of occupancy. 
    A certificate of occupancy shall be issued by the Building Official upon the completion of a building which has met all building code requirements and before occupancy of any building can take place. 
(Ord. 518 §9.01.2, 1984) 
Sec. 18-3. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-4. - Subdivision and development requirements. 
    Subdivision and development regulations apply to all new development or redevelopment for multifamily (more than a fourplex on one [1] lot) or commercial or industrial sites or combinations thereof. 
(Ord. 518 §9.01.10, 1984) 
Sec. 18-5. - Building permits; enhancement assessment. 
(a)  There is imposed an enhancement assessment fee on all undeveloped real property now in the City or to be annexed into the City, in addition to other existing City fees, except that this enhancement assessment includes the former park fee. Said enhancement assessment is to be payable to the City at the time a building permit is obtained from the City. Under no circumstances shall the City issue a building permit or certificate of occupancy to an applicant until and unless the enhancement assessment fee has been paid in full. 
(b)  The fee schedule for the enhancement assessment fee may be amended by resolution of the City Council from time to time and shall be reviewed by the Council as often as needed. The categorical minimums establishing a base line of assessments may be increased by the City Council by resolution where the need for assessments higher than the base line can be demonstrated by reason of increased impact of the proposed development, by reason of the size or scope of the individual unit or project. 
(c)  Substitution of equivalents may be negotiated in lieu of fees for an individual unit or an entire project, subject to Council approval. 
(d)  A separate interest-bearing fund shall be created by the Finance Director to maintain enhancement fees paid hereunder for creation, improvement, acquisition, maintenance and capital replacement reserves for recreational, historical, cultural and parks purposes as generally outlined in the ordinance codified herein. 
(e)  Payment or agreement to pay the enhancement fee hereunder is an admission of the City's authority and the reasonable exercise of that authority to collect this fee and an acknowledgement that the City will rely on the payment of this fee as an estoppel upon the payor from challenging the amount or necessity of the fee. 
(Prior code 6-537-1, 6-537-2, 6-537-3, 6-543-4; Ord. 543 §§1, 2, 1986; Ord. 666 §2, 1995; Ord. 2000-762, Part 1) 
Sec. 18-6. - Building permits; infrastructure and equipment impact assessments. 
(a)  There is imposed an infrastructure and equipment impact assessment fee on all undeveloped real property now in the City or to be annexed into the City, in addition to the enhancement assessment and other existing City fees, except that this infrastructure and equipment impact assessment includes the former drainage fee and development fee. Said infrastructure and equipment impact assessment is to be payable to the City at the time a building permit is obtained from the City in addition to all other assessments and fees. Under no circumstances shall the City issue a building permit to or a certificate of occupancy to an applicant until and unless the infrastructure and equipment impact assessment fee has been paid in full. 
(b)  The fee schedule for the infrastructure and equipment impact assessment fee may be amended by resolution of the City Council from time to time and shall be reviewed by the Council as often as needed. The categorical minimums establishing a base line of assessments may be increased by the City Council by resolution where the need for assessments higher than the base line can be demonstrated by reason of increased impact of the proposed development, by reason of the size or scope of the individual unit or project. 
(c)  Substitution of equivalents may be negotiated in lieu of fees for an individual unit or an entire project, subject to Council approval. 
(d)  A separate interest-bearing fund shall be created by the Finance Director to maintain infrastructure and equipment assessment fees paid hereunder for the creation, operation, maintenance and capital replacement reserves for infrastructure and equipment as generally outlined in the ordinance codified herein. 
(e)  Payment of or agreement to pay the infrastructure and equipment impact assessment fee hereunder is an admission of the City's authority and the reasonable exercise of that authority to collect this fee and an acknowledgement that the City will rely on the payment of this fee as an estoppel upon the payor from challenging the amount or necessity of the fee. 
(Ord. 667 §2, 1995; Ord. 2000-762, Part 1)

Sec. 18-8. - Fair contributions for public school sites. 
(a)  There is imposed a Fair Contribution for Public School Sites requirement on the development of all real property now in the City or to be annexed into the City, in addition to other existing City requirements. Said requirement is due in the form of land or cash in lieu of land in accordance with the intergovernmental agreement between the City of Fort Lupton and the Weld RE-8 School District (see AM 2001-063). Under no circumstances shall the City issue a building permit or certificate of occupancy to an applicant until or unless the Fair Contributions for Public School Sites requirement has been satisfied or determined to be inapplicable under the agreement. If, at any time, the IGA is terminated (without replacement) or voided by final court judgment, this Section shall cease to be effective. 
(b)  The schedule for the Fair Contribution for Public School Sites may be amended by the City Council, as provided for in the intergovernmental agreement between the City of Fort Lupton and the Weld RE-8 School District, from time to time and shall be reviewed by City Council in accordance with said agreement. 
(Ord. 2001-781 §1) 
Sec. 18-9. - Requirements for small wind energy systems. 
(a)  Definition. Small wind energy system means a wind energy conversion system consisting of up to three (3) wind turbines, towers and associated control or conversion electronics, which have a rated capacity of not more than one hundred (100) kilowatts and which are intended to primarily reduce on-site consumption of utility power. 
(b)  Permitted use. Small wind energy systems shall be permitted uses or special uses as provided by this Code, subject to certain qualifications and criteria as set forth below: 
(1)  Height. Total height, including blade length, shall not exceed sixty (60) feet. 
(2)  Setback, minimum lot size and access restriction. No part of the wind system structure, including guy wire anchors, may extend closer than ten (10) feet to the property boundaries of the installation site. Placement must be such that if the system collapses, no occupied structure on adjacent property is within its collapse zone. It is understood that this restriction may prevent most residential zone placement. If physical access to the system by business invitees or even trespassers, like children, would pose a danger by climbing on or otherwise touching the system, adequate access restriction must be constructed. Minimum lot size for each unit is four thousand (4,000) square feet. 
(3)  Noise. Small wind energy systems shall not exceed sixty (60) dBA, as measured at the closest corner of the closest neighboring residential structure, or eighty (80) dBA, as measured from the closest corner of the closest neighboring business structure. The level, however, may be exceeded during severe wind storms, as the combination of high wind, high rotation and wind turbulence around the tower or guy wires may temporarily exceed these noise standards. 
(4)  Wind turbines. Small wind turbines must have been approved under the Emerging Technologies program of the California Energy Commission or any other small wind certification program recognized by the American Wind Energy Association and must demonstrate by those approvals or otherwise that the system meets accepted standards of safety under tornadic conditions. 
(5)  Compliance with International Building Code. Building permit applications for small wind energy systems shall be accompanied by standard drawings of the wind turbine structure, including the tower, base and footings. An engineering analysis of the tower showing compliance with the International Building Code and certified by a licensed professional engineer shall also be submitted. This analysis is frequently supplied by the manufacturer. Wet stamps shall not be required. 
(6)  Compliance with FAA regulations. Small wind energy systems must comply with applicable FAA regulations, including any necessary approvals for installations close to airports. 
(7)  Compliance with National Electric Code. Building permit applications for small wind energy systems shall be accompanied by an engineer's stamped one-line drawing of the electrical components in sufficient detail to allow for a determination that the manner of installation conforms to the National Electrical Code. This information is frequently supplied by the manufacturer. 
(8)  Utility notification. No small wind energy system shall be installed until evidence has been given that the utility company is informed and has approved the customer's intent to install an interconnected customer-owned generator. Off-grid systems shall be exempt from this requirement. 
(9)  Color. The tower cannot be painted another color other than the manufacturer's color without consent of the Planning Department. The Planning Department shall use its discretion consistent with the concept colors being compatible with the area in question. 
(10)  Advertising. The tower shall not be used for advertising purposes. No signs, lettering, balloons, banners or other attention-getting media shall be placed on the tower other than high voltage signs and other signs that exhibit manufacturer warnings and statistical information about the system. 
(11)  Overrides. All towers shall be equipped with a manual override system to shut down the unit in case of an emergency. 
(12)  Miscellaneous. If a tower is abandoned for more than a one-year period, the building permit is automatically revoked and the tower shall be removed at the owner's expense. As part of the building permit process, the applicant must provide the City with written permission to enter and remove the system after abandonment, should the owner fail to do so, and permission to lien the property for the cost of such removal, if necessary, and that such recorded lien shall run with the land and inure to successors and assigns of the owner at the time of installation. 
(13)  If all of these qualifications and criteria are not met, then an applicant may apply for a special use pursuant to Section 16-7 of this Code. The above qualifications and criteria shall be a guide for the Planning Commission and the City Council in determining whether a special use should be granted. 
(Ord. 2009-905 Part 3; Ord. 2014-980 §3) 
Secs. 18-10-18-30. - Reserved.

(Ord. 518 §8.03.1, 1984)

ARTICLE III - Building Code 

Sec. 18-51. - Adoption. 
    Pursuant to Title 31, Article 16, Parts 1 and 2, C.R.S., there is adopted by reference the 2012 International Building Code (IBC) promulgated and published as such by the International Code Council, 4051 West Flossmoor Road, Country Club Hills, Illinois, 60478-5795. This code includes comprehensive provisions covering building regulations, including regulations concerning erection, construction, enlargement, alterations, repair, moving, removal, conversion, demolition, occupancy, equipment, use, height, area and maintenance of buildings or structures in the City; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and providing penalties for the violation thereof and for the enforcement of this Chapter and the building codes by the Building Official. This code presents in a compact and concise manner national test, material and special design standards. It deals with tests of combustibility of various materials in buildings, grading of lumber, cement, aggregates, steel, material specification, roof and foundation standards, sprinkler systems and doors, bonding agents, soil testing methods and other building standards. 
(Ord. 2014-980 §4) 
Sec. 18-52. - Reserved. 
Sec. 18-53. - Certification; copy on file. 
    The City Clerk shall certify to the passage of this Article and make not less than one (1) copy of the adopted codes available for inspection by the public during regular business hours. 
(Prior code 6-544-22; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 2014-980 §5) 
Sec. 18-54. - Application. 
    This Article shall apply to the jurisdiction of the City. 
(Prior code 6-544-20) 
Sec. 18-55. - Interpretation. 
    This Article shall be so interpreted and construed to conform to the International Building Code. 
(Prior code 6-544-21; Ord. 645 §1, 1993; Ord. 2007-884, Pt. 4; Ord. 2014-980 §6) 
Sec. 18-56. - Erosion and migration control and abatement. 
    In addition to all other references in the International Building Code to erosion control and abatement, the following provisions shall apply to all construction projects, subdivision improvements and land grading or moving projects within or affecting property within the City: 
(1)  It is unlawful to begin a project for construction of structures, improvements to real property (such as underground utility infrastructure, street or landscaping installment or repair) or earth moving or grading, until a plan for applied water or storm water, or dust and mud erosion and migration control has been submitted to and approved by the Building Official and Public Works Manager. 
(2)  It is unlawful to disobey a stop work order issued under the authority of this Section. 
(3)  Any work on projects not having an approved erosion control plan or not applying or continuing to apply the plan properly to the project may be stopped on order of the Building Official or Public Works Manager or any law enforcement officer. A stop work order may, at first, be issued orally, but if the order is to be effective for more than forty-eight (48) hours, it shall be put in writing within forty-eight (48) hours of its issuance, citing the violation and what is needed to be done to recommence the project. The project may not continue until a plan has been approved and properly applied to the project. 
(4)  Any erosion plan must include provisions to mitigate water, dust or mud potentially migrating from the property to adjacent property or streets, alleys or rights-of-way or easements of another. 
(5)  Immediate action by the owner, contractor or persons working on any project must be taken to reduce or eliminate, if reasonably possible, the failure of a plan to mitigate off-property water, dust or mud migration. Any work on the project may be ordered stopped to prevent further migration until a revised plan or implementation occurs. Any work may be ordered stopped until clean-up occurs of any damage, refuse or residual mud. 
(6)  Violation of any of these provisions may subject the owner, manager, contractor or all persons working in violation of these provisions to being arrested and charged with a criminal violation and/or subject to damages and/or injunctive relief in civil court. Arrest should only be made if unauthorized work continues after a stop work order has been issued. 
(7)  After oral or written warning, the City may abate violations of this Section and the owner or contractor shall be liable for the cost of such abatement, and such costs may become a lien upon the subject property through direct filing by the City or by collection of the lien as a tax upon the property through the County Treasurers office. Abatement may occur for a lack of an approved control plan (example: erecting barriers where inadequate provision has been made on a project), failure to properly apply and continue to apply an approved plan or changing a plan where new evidence or circumstance has warranted different or increased measures. 
(8)  This Section does not apply to ongoing street and infrastructure maintenance projects of the City itself, projects at existing single-family residences, projects at existing commercial properties in a C1 or C2 zone district or emergency actions such as floodwater control. 
(Ord. 2001-787; Ord. 2014-980 §7) 
Sec. 18-57. - Amendments to International Building Code. 
    The following sections of the International Building Code are revised as follows: 
    " 101.1 Title . These regulations shall be known as the Building Code of the City of Fort Lupton, hereinafter referred to as 'this code.' 
    " 101.4.3 Plumbing . The provisions of the International Plumbing Code shall apply to the installation, alteration, repair and replacement of plumbing systems, including equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings and appurtenances, and where connected to a water or sewage system and all aspects of a medical gas system. 
    " 101.4.5 Fire prevention . The provisions of the adopted Fire Code shall apply to matters affecting or relating to structures, processes and premises from the hazard of fire and explosion arising from the storage, handling or use of structures, materials or devices; from conditions hazardous to life, property or public welfare in the occupancy of structures or premises; and from the construction, extension, repair, alteration or removal of fire suppression, automatic sprinkler systems and alarm systems or fire hazards in the structure or on the premises from occupancy or operation. 
    " 101.4.6 Energy . The provisions of the 2006 International Energy Conservation Code shall apply to all matters governing the design and construction of buildings for energy efficiency. 
    " 105.1 Required . Any owner or authorized agent who intends to construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish, or change the occupancy of a building or structure, or to erect, install, enlarge, alter, repair, remove, convert or replace any electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system, the installation of which is regulated by this code, or to cause any such work to be done, shall first make application to the City and obtain the required permit. 
    " 109.4 Work commencing before permit issuance . Any person who commences any work on a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system before obtaining the necessary permits may be subject to an investigation fee established by the City. The amount of the investigation fee may be in the amount up to the amount of the permit fee that would normally be assessed for the specific type of construction activity, with any such investigation fee being in addition to all other required permit fees. The investigation fee shall be collected whether or not a permit is then subsequently issued. 
    " 109.6 Refunds . Refunds are at the discretion of City Staff and will be handled on a case-by-case basis. 
    " 111.3 Temporary occupancy . The City is authorized to issue a temporary certificate of occupancy before the completion of the entire work covered by the permit, provided that such portion or portions shall be occupied safely. The building official shall set a time period during which the temporary certificate of occupancy is valid. 
    " 113.1 General . In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the building official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a board of appeals. The Board of Appeals shall be comprised of the members of the Board of Adjustment. 
    " 114.2 Notice of violation . The building official is authorized to serve a notice of violation or order on the person responsible for the erection, construction, alteration, extension, repair, moving, removal, demolition or occupancy of a building or structure in violation of the provisions of this code, or in violation of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this code. Such order shall direct the discontinuance of the illegal action or condition and the abatement of the violation. Notice of Violations shall be delivered in accordance with Section 107 of the International Property Maintenance Code. 
    " 202 Definitions is amended by the addition of the following definition 'Sleeping Room' (Bedroom) is any enclosed habitable space within a dwelling unit, which complies with the minimum room dimension requirements of International Building Code Section 1208 and contains a closet, an area that is useable as a closet, or an area that is readily convertible for use as a closet, and contains a code compliant egress. 
    " 1301.1.1 Criteria . Buildings shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the 2006 International Energy Conservation Code. 
    " 105.2 Work exempt from permit is adopted in its entirety, except that Exemptions #1 and #2 under Building are excluded in order to retain the requirement for permits for fences and utility sheds in the Fort Lupton Municipal Code. New exemption #14 shall read as follows: Shingle repair or replacement work not exceeding one hundred (100) square feet in area of covering per building." 
(Ord. 2014-980 §8)
